later on Thursday.\n\nThe Queensland senator has rallied against the burqa since returning to Parliament last year.\n\nSenate President Stephen Parry admitted there was not a lot he could do about the stunt.\n\nSenator Hanson entered the chamber shortly after Question Time started at 2pm, eliciting groans from the chamber.\n\nWhile media rushed in to cover the performance, senators from all sides did their best to ignore it, studiously avoiding looking in her direction.\n\nThey were forced to look her way when she dramatically shrugged off the garment to ask a question of Attorney-General George Brandis, calling on him to ban the burqa.\n\nBut the Attorney-General's response, in which he called the stunt \"appalling\" and both \"counselled and cautioned\" Senator Hanson for causing offence to religious groups, received an extraordinary standing ovation from Labor and the Greens.\n\nLabor cheered as Senator Brandis said the vast majority of those who practiced the Islamic faith were law-abiding citizens\n\n\"No, Senator Hanson, we will not ban the burqa,\" he said.\n\nCoalition MPs remained seated during the standing ovation.\n\nAfter receiving her answer, Senator Hanson "storyUri": "eng-3368046", "body": "Face fully covered, the woman in black didn't need to say anything as she entered the Senate.\n\nFace fully covered, the woman in black didn't need to say anything as she entered the Senate.\n\nPauline Hanson had made her point.\n\nThe One Nation leader took her seat for question time wearing a black burqa, ahead of her motion to ban the garment that was due for debate later on Thursday.\n\nThe Queensland senator has rallied against the burqa since returning to Parliament last year.\n\nSenate President Stephen Parry admitted there was not a lot he could do about the stunt.\n\nSenator Hanson entered the chamber shortly after question time started at 2pm, eliciting groans from the chamber.\n\nWhile media rushed in to cover the performance, senators from all sides did their best to ignore it, studiously avoiding looking in her direction.\n\nThey were forced to look her way when she dramatically shrugged off the garment to ask a question of Attorney-General George Brandis, calling on him to ban the burqa.\n\nBut the Attorney-General's response, in which he called the stunt \"appalling\" and both \"counselled and cautioned\" Senator Hanson for causing offence to religious groups, received an extraordinary standing ovation from Labor and the Greens.\n\nLabor cheered as Senator Brandis said the vast majority of those who practised the Islamic faith were law-abiding citizens\n\n\"No, Senator Hanson, we will not ban the burqa,\" he said.\n\nCoalition MPs remained seated during the standing ovation.\n\nAfter receiving her answer, Senator Hanson left the chamber, to calls of \"good on you George\" from Labor senators.\n\nMore to come\n\nFollow us on Facebook\n\nThe story One Nation leader Pauline Hanson wears burqa in Senate {"timeCrawl": "07:11:00", "uri": "710733951", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T07:11:00Z", "sim": 0.8941176533699036, "source": {"title": "News.com.au", "uri": "news.com.au", "id": "308"}, "url": "http://www.news.com.au/national/pauline-hanson-turns-up-to-parliament-in-full-burqa/news-story/c04fe220ba1722f63fe9e321c7cd50f8", "eventUri": "eng-3368046", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368046", "body": "PAULINE Hanson has admitted the stunt she pulled, where she entered the Senate covered head to toe in a burqa, was \"extreme\". But she's unrepentant saying any anger it may have sparked was fine as it started a debate about face coverings.\n\nHanson has also suggested \"these people\" who wear burqas \"should go to a country that suits their needs\".\n\nHanson said she wasn't challenged as to her identity. Although she has conceded security may have suspected the One Nation leader was beneath the face covering.\n\nThe stunt on Thursday is the latest round in Hanson's battle against the burqa.\n\nGasps of \"what on earth?\" could be heard from the Senate as she sat down. Attorney-General George Brandis looked bemused by the spectacle and later berated Hanson for \"mocking\" law abiding Australian Muslims.\n\nOn Sydney radio station 2GB she said the burqa was \"un-Australian\".\n\nTalking to presenter Ben Fordham, she said, \"Is it extreme? yes. Is it getting my point across? I hope so.\"\n\nHanson said she entered the Senate without being checked.\n\n\"No security guards at any point in time asked to see my face,\" she said.\n\n\"One of the attendants on the floor of parliament, he just gasped.\n\n\"He did not ask to see my face. Apparently they were told I was going to do it, they did not check if it was me.\"\n\nShe said that in five years or more time, Australian women might be forced to wear the burqa. \"This is a western country. If these people want to dress up, go to a country that suits your needs.\"\n\nSenator Hanson also claimed Greens Senator Peter Whish Wilson shook her hand in the corridor while she was wearing the burqa. He'd never greeted her or shaken her hand previously.\n\nOn Twitter, Senator Whish Wilson didn't address the claims but did retweet another social media user who said shaking someone's hand proved they were not \"confronting\".\n\nAn expert on Islam has said Hansons's remarks could incite hatred towards women.\n\nDirector of the Institute for Religion, Politics and Society at Australian Catholic University, Dr Joshua Roose, said, \"knowing that Muslim women are likely to be targeted in verbal and physical attacks due to their more recognisable appearance, Senator Hanson's stunt is likely to directly and indirectly increase the risk of violence towards Muslim communities.\"\n\nPauline Hanson's stunt today was a hurtful, offensive & dangerous display for her own ignorance. The Senate stood up to her as we should. -- Sarah Hanson-Young\u17064 (@sarahinthesen8)\n\nAugust 17, 2017\n\nGeorge Brandis was just brilliant in the chamber. Just brilliant. Strongest I have ever heard him. -- Sam Dastyari (@samdastyari)\n\nAugust 17, 2017\n\nAs she entered the chamber, Senator Derryn Hinch immediately took exception.\n\n\"We've been assured by you that the Clerk (of the Senate) has identified this person here as Senator Hanson,\" said.\n\n\"As a point of order I would like to know if Senator Hanson can stay here unchallenged. I understand she is not a Muslim. She is not of the Islamic faith.\n\n\"Can I appear tomorrow in fancy dress unchallenged?\n\nSenate President Stephen Parry said he wouldn't tell senators what to wear.\n\nIn a statement on her Facebook page, the noted critic of Islam said she had attended Question Time \"dressed modestly in a full burqa\" and would deliver a speech calling for the Government to ban full face coverings in public.\n\n\"Senator Hanson said that she believed that full face covering, such as the burqa, were oppressive, presented barriers to assimilation, disadvantaged women from finding employment, were causing issues inside our justice system, presented a clear security threat and had no place in modern Western society,\" the statement read.\n\nThe stunt continued when Senator Hanson removed the covering to ask Brandis if the burqa could be banned as a matter of national security.\n\nShe was told \"No\" by Senator Brandis who criticised her for \"mocking\" religious garments.\n\nHe was given a standing ovation by Labor senators, and was congratulated by Labor Leader Penny Wong, and was given applause from his own Coalition side.\n\nThe Attorney-General said: \"Senator Hanson no, we will not be banning the burqa.\n\n\"Now Senator Hanson, I'm not going to pretend to ignore the stunt you have tried to pull today by arriving in the Chamber dressed in a burqa, when we all know you are not an adherent of the Islamic faith.\n\n\"And I would caution you and counsel you Senator Hanson, with respect, to be very, very careful of the offence you may do to the religious sensibilities of other Australians.\n\n\"We have about half a million Australians of the Islamic faith in this country, and the vast majority of them are law-abiding good Australians.\n\n\"Senator Hanson, it is absolutely consistent with being a good, law-abiding Australian and being a strict adherent Muslim.\"\n\nAt one point Senator Brandis could be seen to choke back tears.\n\nSenator Hanson had couched her call for a ban on national security lines.\n\n\"In light of our national security of this nation, will you work with me to actually ban the burqa in Australia considering there have been 13 foiled national threats against us with terrorism, three that have been successful that Australians have lost their lives.\n\n\"Terrorism is a true threat to our country. Many Australians are in fear of it.\n\n\"What I would like to ask on behalf of the Australian people, considering there has been a large majority of Australians wish to see the banning of the burqa.\"\n\nThat's Pauline Hanson in a full burqa in the Senate chamber at the bottom left of the shot. pic.twitter.com/TDU3871fEM -- Charles Croucher (@ccroucher9)\n\nAugust 17, 2017\n\nA person wearing a burqa in the seat of Senator Pauline Hanson, during Question Time pic.twitter.com/k2eNrMKcb0 -- Alex Ellinghausen (@ellinghausen)\n\nAugust 17, 2017\n\nHere's the video of Pauline Hanson wearing a burqa in the Senate. The reaction of the Liberal senators was mouth open shock. pic.twitter.com/85eh8LW9Iz -- Alice Workman (@workmanalice)\n\nAugust 17, 2017\n\nThe stunt comes just days after the Trump administration called out Hanson for her anti-Muslim rhetoric.\n\nOn Tuesday, US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson introduced his department's annual report on global religious freedom.\n\nTillerson reserved his deepest criticism for the terrorists of Islamic State.\n\nBut turn to the page on religious freedom in Australia and it's Pauline Hanson's One Nation that gets the most focus.\n\nThe 2016 International Religious Freedom Report noted the election of four One Nation senators and that their campaign platform included \"ceasing Muslim immigration, holding a royal commission on Islam, halting construction of mosques, installing surveillance cameras in mosques, banning wearing of the burqa and niqab in public places, and prohibiting members of parliament from being sworn in under the Koran.\"\n\nThe report turned to Ms Hanson in particular.\n\n\"In her first senate speech, One Nation Party Leader Pauline Hanson said the country was 'in danger of being swamped by Muslims.'\"\n\nIt contrasted Hanson's speech with that of the PM. \"Malcolm Turnbull disagreed with her views and said 'my commitment is to an inclusive multicultural society which is based on mutual respect. Brandis on the verge of tears. -- Brihony Speed (@brihonyspeed)\n\nAugust 17, 2017\n\nI have given up predicting what will happen next in this Senate - today Senator Hanson is in a Burka for question time. pic.twitter.com/7V9tZ6xvd2 -- Linda Reynolds (@lindareynoldswa)\n\nAugust 17, 2017\n\nhere's video of Hanson entering the Senate, in a full black face covering - \"what on earth?\" says one senator pic.twitter.com/HyBSITxYrU -- Josh Butler (@JoshButler)\n\nAugust 17, 2017\n\nOne Nation leader Pauline Hanson removes a burqa during #qt #auspol pic.twitter.com/bq6Qp2ZQwk -- Lukas Coch (@cochl)\n\nAugust 17, 2017\n\nBrandis ruled out banning the burka which led to Labor and the Greens giving him a standing ovation.\n\nAttorney General George Brandis told Hanson:\n\n\"We will not be banning the burqa. And I would caution you and counsel you, Senator Hanson, with respect, to be very, very cautious of the offense you may do to the religious sensibilities of other Australians.\n\n\"We have about half a million Australians in this country of the Islamic faith and the vast majority of them are law abiding good Australians, and Senator Hanson, it is absolutely consistent to be a good law abiding Australian and be a good strict adherent Muslim.\n\n\"Now, Senator Hanson, for the last four years I have had responsibility, preeminently amongst the ministers, subject to the Prime Minister, for national security policy, and I can tell you Senator Hanson, it has been the advice of all of the attorney generals of security with whom I have worked, and each commissioner of the Australian Federal Police, with whom I have worked, that it is vital for their intelligence and law enforcement work, that we work cooperatively with the Muslim community... and to ridicule that community, to drive it into a corner, to mock its religious garments is an appalling thing to do and I would ask you to reflect on what you have done.\"\n\nLabor's Senate leader Penny Wong backed Brandis' remarks, saying: \"It is one thing to wear religious dress as a sincere act of faith, there is another to wear it as a stunt here in the chamber.\"\n\nHanson initially sat quietly wearing the burqa, but eventually removed it. When she rose to ask Brandis about Muslim face coverings and security, he delivered his thoroughly seething takedown.\n\nWhen Hanson arrived in the chamber, Senate president Stephen Parry told those present that her identity had been already been established.\n\nSenator Derryn Hinch questioned the appropriateness of Hanson's attire, asking if he would be \"unchallenged\" if he entered the chamber in fancy dress.\n\nParry replied that he would not dictate the standard of dress worn in the chamber.\n\nHanson had earlier given notice that she wanted to debate a burqa ban in the Senate on Thursday afternoon, saying that \"she believed the need to ban full face coverings in public was an important issue facing modern Australia that needed to be discussed\".\n\nALP senator mutters Senator Hanson has \"got what she wants\" because media (inc me) have rushed in to cover the One Nation leader's burqa. -- Louise Yaxley (@louiseyaxley)\n\nAugust 17, 2017\n\nHanson is leaving the Senate chamber with a smile, burqa in hand. Labor senators heckling \"you're a disgrace\" #auspol #qt -- Paul Karp (@Paul_Karp)\n\nAugust 17, 2017\n\nFollowing the end of Question Time, conservative senator Cory Bernardi said while he agreed with One Nation's stance on banning head coverings, he didn't agree with Hanson's \"blunt\" stunt, HuffPost Australia reported.\n\n\"I happen to agree the burqa has no place in Australia... so I accept the point but I really do think it diminished the status of the parliament,\" Bernardi told 2GB radio.\n\n\"I don't agree with stunts by politicians. I actually care about the standards of the parliament.\"\n\nHanson has been a polarising figure in Australian politics and has often been accused of racism with her opinions on race, immigration and Islam causing wide debate. {"timeCrawl": "05:09:00", "uri": "710687231", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T05:09:00Z", "sim": 0.8784313797950745, "source": {"title": "The Area News", "uri": "areanews.com.au", "id": "13211"}, "url": "http://www.areanews.com.au/story/4862799/one-nation-leader-pauline-hanson-wears-burqa-in-senate/", "eventUri": "eng-3368046", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368046", "body": "Face fully covered, the woman in black didn't need to say anything as she entered the Senate.\n\nSenator Pauline Hanson pulls off the burqa. Photo: Alex Ellinghausen\n\nPauline Hanson had made her point.\n\nThe One Nation leader took her seat for Question Time wearing a black burqa, ahead of her motion to ban the garment due for debate later on Thursday.\n\nThe Queensland senator has rallied against the burqa since returning to Parliament last year.\n\nSenate President Stephen Parry admitted there was not a lot he could do about the {"timeCrawl": "08:09:00", "uri": "710757843", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T08:09:00Z", "sim": 0.8705882430076599, "source": {"title": "The Nation", "uri": "nation.com.pk", "id": "468"}, "url": "http://nation.com.pk/international/17-Aug-2017/aussie-politician-wears-burqa-in-senate-while-calling-for-ban", "eventUri": "eng-3368046", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368046", "body": "The leader of Australia's rightwing One Nation party has been rebuked by the Turnbull government for entering the Senate chamber wearing a black burqa: reported The Guardian.\n\nPauline Hanson caused a commotion by arriving at the Senate chamber for the daily question time session dressed in a black burqa, which was designed to underscore a call she intended to make to ban the religious garment, citing national security concerns.\n\nBut Hanson was rebuked sharply for her behaviour.\n\nPlus attorney general George Brandis condemns Hanson's burqa 'stunt' and cautions her not to offend religious sensibilities of other Australians\n\nRead more\n\nThe leader of the government in the Senate, the attorney general George Brandis, told the One Nation leader the ruling Coalition had no intention of banning the burqa.\n\nIn remarks that secured him a standing ovation from the opposition Labor party, and the Greens party, as well as other crossbench senators, Brandis warned Hanson against indulging in behaviour that Muslim Australians would find offensive.\n\n\"Senator Hanson, no, we will not be banning the burqa,\" Brandis told the Senate on Thursday. \"Senator Hanson, I'm not going to pretend to ignore the stunt that you have tried to pull today by arriving in the chamber dressed in a burqa when we all know you are not an adherent of the Islamic faith.\n\n\"I would caution you and counsel you, Senator Hanson, with respect, to be very very careful of the offence you may do to the religious sensibilities of other Australians.\"\n\n\"We have about half a million Australians in this country of the Islamic faith, and the vast majority of them are law abiding, good Australians, and Senator Hanson, it is absolutely consistent with being a good law abiding Australian and a strict, adherent, Muslim.\"\n\nBrandis reminded Hanson that as attorney general, he held preeminent portfolio responsibility for national security, and the advice from intelligence agencies was clear - countering the risks of extremism required close cooperation with the Islamic community.\n\nThe attorney general, who was clearly infuriated by Hanson's behaviour, rebuked her sharply for causing offence to a faith community. \"To ridicule that community, to drive it into a corner, to mock its religious garments, is an appalling thing to do, and I would ask you to reflect on your behaviour.\"\n\nHanson smiled throughout Brandis' answer, and visibly delighted with the commotion caused by her intervention, left the Senate chamber shortly after her designated question.\n\nThe Brandis rebuke prompted Labor, Greens and some crossbenchers to stand and applaud. Some but not all government MPs also applauded but kept their seats.\n\nOne Nation leader Pauline Hanson pulls off the burqa she wore to question time in the Senate chamber. Photograph: Reuters\n\nThe leader of the opposition in the Senate, the Labor senator Penny Wong, said if the standing orders permitted, she would have issued a vote of thanks to Brandis for his remarks.\n\nWong, also clearly infuriated, told Hanson: \"It is one thing to wear religious dress as a sincere act of faith and another to wear it here as a stunt in the Senate chamber.\"\n\nHanson's call for the banning of the burqa prompted disorderly interjections from across the chamber.\n\nThe One Nation leader's question was posed to Brandis along the following lines: \"In light of our national security of this nation, will [the government] work with me to actually ban the burqa in Australia considering there have been 13 foiled national threats against us with terrorism, three that have been successful that Australians have lost their lives?\n\n\"Terrorism is a true threat to our country. Many Australians are in fear of it. What I would like to ask on behalf of the Australian people, considering there has been a large majority of Australians wish to see the banning of the burqa.\"\n\nThe Labor senator Sam Dastyari, who is of Iranian heritage, and a non-practising Muslim, shouted that Hanson was a threat to national security, and a \"disgrace\".\n\nAnother Labor MP interjected that Hanson would next enter the chamber wearing a white hood - a reference to white supremacist groups.\n\nHanson later took to Facebook to double down on her behaviour in the parliament.\n\nHanson's One Nation party proposes anti-Islamic policies including a ban on Muslim immigration, and a royal commission into Islam. No onE, no security guard at any point of time asked to see my face.\n\nScroll down for video\n\nThe Queensland Senator donned the Islamic garb when she appeared at Parliamentary Question Time on Thursday afternoon\n\n'One of the attendants who was on the floor of parliament, he just gasped. You should have seen the look on his face.'\n\nSenator Hanson said the Senate attendant didn't know what to do, even though she didn't identify herself.\n\nAfter making a dramatic entrances on the floor of parliament, Senator Hanson took off her black burqa and called for the government to ban 'oppressive' full-face coverings.\n\n'I'm quite happy to remove this, because this is not what should belong in this Parliament,' she said.\n\nHer appearance was met with laughter and outrage, prompting Senate President Stephen Parry to call for order.\n\n'In light of our national security of this nation, will you work to ban the burqa in Australia?' she said.\n\n'There have been 13 foiled national threats against us with terrorism, three that have been successful and Australians have lost their lives.\n\n'Terrorism is a true threat to our country. Many Australians are very much in fear of it.\n\n'A large majority of Australians wish to see the banning of the burqa.'\n\nMs Hanson said the idea for her burqa stunt was born when Senate President Stephen Parry told her last year that anyone could wear a burqa in Parliament.\n\n'I'm quite happy to remove this, because this is not what should belong in this Parliament,' Ms Hanson said as she stood to speak\n\nShe said the burqa was an 'important issue' facing modern Australia.\n\nIn a statement released on Wednesday, Senator Hanson said the burqa 'presented barriers to assimilation'.\n\nShe said the Islamic dress 'disadvantaged women from finding employment, was causing issues inside our justice system, presented a clear security threat and had no place in modern Western society'.\n\n'I'm quite happy to remove this, because this is not what should belong in this Parliament,' Ms Hanson (pictured) said when she stood to speak\n\nIn a statement released on Wednesday, Senator Hanson (pictured) said the burqa was 'oppressive'\n\nMs Hanson's dress choice prompted Senate President Stephen Parry to call for order in the chamber.\n\n'I've been advised by the clerk that the identity of Senator Hanson was established before she entered the chamber,' Senate President Stephen Parry said.\n\nThe stunt drew anger from the opposition benches, with crossbencher Derryn Hinch questioning whether Senator Hanson could remain in the chamber.\n\n'I understand that she is not a Muslim, not of Islamic faith. Can I appear tomorrow in fancy dress unchallenged?' he asked the president.\n\nSenator Parry said he was not going to dictate the standard of dress for senators.\n\nSenator Hanson will move a motion in parliament on Thursday, to be debated in the afternoon, calling on the federal government to ban the burqa\n\nSenator Hanson will move a motion in parliament on Thursday, to be debated in the afternoon, calling on the federal government to ban the burqa.\n\nIndependent senator Cory Bernardi also weighed in on the stunt.\n\n'I did warn you that proroguing the parliament was in national interest. And the vast majority of them are law abiding good Australians.'\n\nThe government's top law enforcement official, Senator Brandis said he had responsibility for national security policy.\n\n'And I can tell you, Senator Hanson, that is it has been the advice of each Director-General of security with whom I have worked and each Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police with whom I have worked that it is vital for their ntelligence and law enforcement work that they work cooperatively with the Muslim community.\n\n'And to ridicule that community, to drive it into a corner, to mock its religious garments is an appalling thing to do and I would ask you to reflect on what you have done.'\n\nMs Hanson's stunt sparked a social media frenzy.\n\n'Pauline Hanson has absolutely no shame. {"timeCrawl": "12:16:00", "uri": "710869488", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T12:16:00Z", "sim": 0.8509804010391235, "source": {"title": "Yeni \u015eafak", "uri": "yenisafak.com", "id": "19266"}, "url": "http://www.yenisafak.com/en/world/australian-senator-slams-appalling-burqa-stunt-defends-muslims-2780991", "eventUri": "eng-3368046", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368046", "body": "Criticism pours in after a senator wore a burqa in federal parliament\n\nPauline Hanson, leader of Australia's One Nation Party, was rebuked on Thursday by George Brandis, the leader of the Australian government in the Senate, for wearing a burqa as part of a stunt in federal parliament.\n\nDressed in a black burqa, Hanson arrived in the Senate chamber for the daily session in order to make a call for the banning of the burqa for national security concerns.\n\nAppalled by Hanson's behavior, attorney general George Branson strongly criticized the stunt. \"Senator Hanson, no, we will not be banning the burqa,\" Brandis said.\n\n\"I am not going to pretend to ignore the stunt that you have tried to pull today by arriving in the chamber dressed in a burqa when we all know that you are not an adherent of the Islamic faith. I would caution you and counsel you, Senator Hanson, with respect, to be very, very careful of the offence you may do to the religious sensibilities of other Australians,\" he continued.\n\nReminding Hanson of his seniority and experience, Brandis outlined his portfolio and expressed that to counter terrorism, the Islamic community's cooperation and council was necessary.\n\n\"We have about half a million Australians in this country of the Islamic faith, and the vast majority of them are law abiding, good Australians, and Senator Hanson, it is absolutely consistent with being a good law abiding Australian and a strict, adherent, Muslim,\" he said.\n\n\"I can tell you, Senator Hanson, that it is vital for intelligence and law enforcement work that they work cooperatively with the Muslim community. To ridicule that community, to drive it into a corner, to mock its religious garments, is an appalling thing to do, and I would ask you to reflect on what you have done,\" Brandis added.\n\nBrandis' speech was met with a standing ovation by senators.\n\nCRITICISM POURS IN\n\nBrandis was not the only one who was clearly infuriated. {"timeCrawl": "14:05:00", "uri": "710922594", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T09:14:00Z", "sim": 0.8509804010391235, "source": {"title": "GULF NEWS", "uri": "gulfnews.com", "id": "3935"}, "url": "http://gulfnews.com/news/asia/australia/hanson-wears-burqa-in-australian-senate-while-calling-for-ban-1.2075731", "eventUri": "eng-3368046", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368046", "body": "Sydney: The leader of Australia's right wing One Nation party has been rebuked by the Turnbull government for entering the Senate chamber wearing a black burqa.\n\nPauline Hanson caused a commotion by arriving at the Senate chamber for the daily question time session dressed in a black burqa, which was designed to underscore a call she intended to make to ban the religious garment, citing national security concerns.\n\nBut Hanson was rebuked sharply for her behaviour.\n\nThe leader of the government in the Senate, the attorney-general George Brandis, told the One Nation leader the ruling Coalition had no intention of banning the burqa.\n\nIn remarks that secured him a standing ovation from the opposition Labour party, and the Greens party, as well as other cross-bench senators, Brandis warned Hanson against indulging in behaviour that Muslim Australians would find offensive.\n\n\"Senator Hanson, no, we will not be banning the burqa,\" Brandis told the Senate on Thursday.\n\n\"Senator Hanson, I'm not going to pretend to ignore the stunt that you have tried to pull today by arriving in the chamber dressed in a burqa when we all know you are not an adherent of the Islamic faith.\n\n\"I would caution you and counsel you, Senator Hanson, with respect, to be very very careful of the offence you may do to the religious sensibilities of other Australians.\"\n\n\"We have about half a million Australians in this country of the Islamic faith, and the vast majority of them are law abiding, good Australians, and Senator Hanson, it is absolutely consistent with being a good law-abiding Australian and a strict, adherent, Muslim.\"\n\nBrandis reminded Hanson that as attorney-general, he held pre-eminent portfolio responsibility for national security, and the advice from intelligence agencies was clear -- countering the risks of extremism required close cooperation with the Islamic community.\n\nThe attorney-general, who was clearly infuriated by Hanson's behaviour, rebuked her sharply for causing offence to a faith community. \"To ridicule that community, to drive it into a corner, to mock its religious garments, is an appalling thing to do, and I would ask you to reflect on your behaviour.\"\n\nHanson smiled throughout Brandis' answer, and visibly delighted with the commotion caused by her intervention, left the Senate chamber shortly after her designated question.\n\nThe Brandis rebuke prompted Labour, Greens and some cross-benchers to stand and applaud. Some but not all government MPs also applauded but kept their seats. The leader of the opposition in the Senate, the Labour senator Penny Wong, said if the standing orders permitted, she would have issued a vote of thanks to Brandis for his remarks.\n\nWong, also clearly infuriated, told Hanson: \"It is one thing to wear religious dress as a sincere act of faith and another to wear it here as a stunt in the Senate chamber.\"\n\nHanson's call for the banning of the burqa prompted disorderly interjections from across the chamber.\n\nThe One Nation leader's question was posed to Brandis along the following lines: \"In light of our national security of this nation, will [the government] work with me to actually ban the burqa in Australia considering there have been 13 foiled national threats against us with terrorism, three that have been successful that Australians have lost their lives?\n\n\"Terrorism is a true threat to our country. Many Australians are in fear of it. What I would like to ask on behalf of the Australian people, considering there has been a large majority of Australians wish to see the banning of the burqa.\"\n\nThe Labour senator Sam Dastyari, who is of Iranian heritage, and a non-practising Muslim, shouted that Hanson was a threat to national security, and a \"disgrace\".\n\nAnother Labour MP interjected that Hanson would next enter the chamber wearing a white hood -- a reference to white supremacist groups.\n\nHanson later took to Facebook to double down on her behaviour in the parliament. Hanson's One Nation party proposes anti-Islamic policies including a ban on Muslim immigration, and a royal commission into Islam. I met two security guards and I walked straight up the chamber.\n\n\"No one, no security guard at any point of time asked to see my face.\n\n\"When I walked into the chamber one of the attendants ... he just gasped.\"\n\nSenator Hanson described the experience of wearing the burqa as \"horrible\".\n\nShe said the idea for the stunt was her own and was designed to expose the security threats to Parliament and to call for the ban.\n\n\"It's been an idea of mine to actually expose the burqa,\" she said.\n\n\"I'm very much against the burqa. I think it's confronting. I think it's un-Australian.\n\n\"It's hard to describe -- I feel for these women who are actually forced to wear it because the pressure is put on them by their husbands and their fathers,\" she said.\n\n\"It's not a religious requirement, let's get that clear.\"\n\nThe One Nation Leader was in full black burqa when she walked into Senate Question Time on Thursday, to the outrage of Labor Senators.\n\nHer identity was checked before she entered the red chamber.\n\nSenator Hanson, who exclusively spoke to The Courier-Mail before she entered the Senate, will give a significant speech at 4pm to call for the face covering to be banned in Parliament and across the country.\n\nSenators continued on with Question Time in the Upper House as normal while Senator Hanson sat in the full black covering.\n\nLabor senators called \"shame\" and \"you're a disgrace\" as Senator Hanson rose to ask if the Government would work towards implementing the ban.\n\nSenator Derryn Hinch questioned why she was allowed in \"fancy dress''.\n\nThe Speaker Stephen Parry said he would not dictate what people could wear.\n\nAttorney-General George Brandis received a standing ovation from the Labor senators when he called Hanson's stunt \"appalling\".\n\n\"Senator Hanson, no, we will not be banning the burqa,\" Brandis said.\n\n\"I am not going to pretend to ignore the stunt that you have tried to pull today by arriving in the Chamber dressed in a burqa when we all know that you are not an adherent of the Islamic faith.\n\n\"I would caution and counsel you with respect to be very, very careful of the offence you may do to the religious sensibilities of other Australians.\"\n\nCory Bernardi also weighed in on the stunt. \"I did warn you that proroguing the parliament was in national interest. Things are getting seriously weirder by the day,\" he posted to Twitter.\n\nSenator Hanson has previously vowed to ban the garb in all official buildings in Queensland if her party wins the upcoming state election, but she has also called for the ban to be implemented nationally.\n\nShe has previously called the burqa an \"evil tool of oppression\" and \"an extreme national security risk\".\n\nThe incredible stunt comes after Senator Hanson met with prominent Australian businessman Dick Smith to discuss immigration policy in Canberra today.", "id": "9627997", "details": {}, {"timeCrawl": "15:12:00", "uri": "710956138", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T15:12:00Z", "sim": 0.8470588326454163, "source": {"title": "News.com.au", "uri": "news.com.au", "id": "308"}, "url": "http://www.news.com.au/national/pauline-hanson-wears-a-burqa-in-the-senate/news-story/431d3e825ede1d7807a5e2ab3bf1a2e0", "eventUri": "eng-3368046", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368046", "body": "In an interview on Sky News' Paul Murray Live tonight Senator Hanson revealed she bought the religious garment that she wore during Question Time online.\n\nSenator Hanson took her seat today while wearing the full-face black garment, before taking it off.\n\nThe One Nation leader Hanson fired back at claims she was mocking the Islamic faith.\n\n\"It was in the making months ago,\" she told the program.\n\n\"I thought it needs to be done. It needs to be done to press a point and today was the day to actually do it. I had one of my staff by in on eBay. It was one size fits all. I had trouble getting into it.\n\n\"Of course there was (nerves). This was a big decision I don't have to make headlines. I don't need to do it.\"\n\nSenator Hanson said she was attempting to make a point about national security.\n\n\"What I am putting across is national security,\" she said.\n\n\"Most Australians don't want the burqa. We have to be logical about it and listen to the Australian people.\n\n\"It stops social cohesion and we have to address it.\"\n\n\"I want people to take out of this that I am an Australian who has not lost my voice due to political correctness and minoroty groups\n\n\"I am going to be true to myself and the people that elected me. I am sick and tired of these gutless pollies behind the scnees that agree with me. I will walk away and say I have done the best on my principles.\n\nEarlier after carrying out her stunt, Senator Hanson told 2GB radio her One Nation colleague Brian Burston identified her to the senate security guards but said none of the guards checked to confirm her identity before she walked in.\n\n\"I put it on in my office, the media were taking photos, I walked straight down the hallway, down the stairs. I met two security guards and I walked straight up the chamber.\n\n\"No one, no security guard at any point of time asked to see my face.\n\n\"When I walked into the chamber one of the attendants ... he just gasped.\"\n\nSenator Hanson described the experience of wearing the burqa as \"horrible\".\n\nShe said the idea for the stunt was her own and was designed to expose the security threats to Parliament and to call for the ban.\n\n\"It's been an idea of mine to actually expose the burqa,\" she said.\n\n\"I'm very much against the burqa. I think it's confronting. I think it's un-Australian.\n\n\"It's hard to describe - I feel for these women who are actually forced to wear it because the pressure is put on them by their husbands and their fathers,\" she said.\n\n\"It's not a religious requirement, let's get that clear.\"\n\nHer provocative move comes ahead of her call to ban the garment in Australia.\n\nThe One Nation leader made a speech to the Parliament about the ban, which she has called for in the past. Her bid to ban the burqa was rejected by all Labor, Greens, and Coalition senators.\n\nWhile in the chamber, Senator Hanson asked why someone should be allowed to take their place in the Senate while obscuring their face and argued it should be banned from parliament.\n\nShe eventually removed the garment before asking her question and said: \"I'm quite happy to remove this, because this is not what should belong in this Parliament\".\n\nShe left the chamber to jeers from Labor senators at around 2.30pm before issuing a statement.\n\nSenator Hanson said she made the decision to attend Question Time in a full face covering because she believed \"the need to ban full face coverings in public was an important issue facing modern Australia that needed to be discussed\".\n\nWatch Senator Brandis' stinging attack on Senator Hanson below.\n\nSenator Hanson said she wished to raise the issue of full face covering presenting a security threat not only to Parliament House, but also to the greater Australian public.\n\nShe said she believed that full face covering, such as the burqa, were \"oppressive, presented barriers to assimilation, disadvantaged women from finding employment, were causing issues inside our justice system, presented a clear security threat and had no place in modern Western society\".\n\nLabor senators called \"shame\" and \"you're a disgrace\" as Senator Hanson rose to ask if the Government would work towards implementing the ban.\n\nAttorney-General George Brandis received a standing ovation from the Labor senators when he said her actions were \"appalling\" and \"disgraceful\" and that her stunt was ridiculing and mocking the Muslim community.\n\n\"Senator Hanson, no, we will not be banning the burqa,\" Brandis said.\n\n\"I am not going to pretend to ignore the stunt that you have tried to pull today by arriving in the Chamber dressed in a burqa when we all know that you are not an adherent of the Islamic faith.\n\n\"I would caution and counsel you with respect to be very, very careful of the offence you may do to the religious sensibilities of other Australians.\"\n\n\"We have about 500,000 Australians in this country of the Islamic faith and the vast majority of them are law abiding good Australians.\n\n\"Senator Hanson, for the last four years, I have had responsibility pre-eminently among the ministers subject to the Prime Minister for national security policy.\n\n\"And I can tell you, Senator Hanson, that it has been the advice of each Director-General of security with whom I have worked and each Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police with whom I have worked that it is vital for their intelligence and law enforcement work that they work cooperatively with the Muslim community and to ridicule that community, to drive it into a corner, to mock its religious garments is an appalling thing to do and I would ask you to reflect on that.\"\n\nIn defence of her act, Senator Hanson also told 2GB radio: \"Don't the Australian people have the right to know that whoever sits in the chamber, that is actually the person they voted for,\" she said.\n\n\"How do I know, that if you have someone ... in a burqa in that chamber it is that person who walks in that chamber every time?\"\n\n\"These are questions that need to be asked.\n\n\"To blatantly come out, as Senator Brandis did with a definite no, 'we're not going to ban the burqa, we're not going to have equality as far as anyone wearing full faced coverings into a bank or into the chamber, a blatant 'No' straight off without saying 'Let's discuss this' ... it was just a definite 'No'.\n\nSenator Hanson hit back at the suggestions she was mocking the Islamic faith.\n\n\"That's absolute rubbish - I'm not mocking anyone,\" she said.\n\n\"People have a right to their own faith and what they believe in, I've got no problems with that.\n\n\"But when that faith stops at a religion and then becomes a political ideology, that's what I have problems with.\n\n\"The burqa is not a religious requirement. It is a matter of controlling women.\"\n\n\"Is it extreme? Yes. Is this getting my message across? I hope so.\"\n\n\"I hope it's creating debate. Because we have overall probably more than 55 per cent of Australians want to see the burqa banned. And I think there's no better place to start than with the Parliament.\"\n\nSenator Hanson said while she was walking to the chamber in the burqa, a Greens senator, Peter Whish-Wilson, shook her hand.\n\nShe described it as \"tokenism\".\n\nHanson also condemned the standing ovation from the Greens and Labor senators to Senator Brandis's response.\n\n\"It's basically saying this is the future, we're not going to stop the spreading of Islam, we're not going to stop this division happening in our society.\"\n\nSenate President Stephen Parry made no comment on the stunt beyond that the chamber had a rule that people with face coverings had to identify themselves before entering.\n\nSenator Hanson has previously vowed to ban the garb in all official buildings in Queensland if her party wins the upcoming state election, but she has also called for the ban to be implemented nationally.\n\nShe has previously called the burqa an \"evil tool of oppression\" and \"an extreme national security risk\".\n\nHANSON STUNT AN EYE-ROLL MOMENT\n\nCounter-terrorism expert and Labor MP Anne Aly, who was the first Muslim woman to be elected to federal parliament, said Senator Hanson's stunt would be \"just another eye-roll moment\" for most Muslim Australians.\n\n\"I think most young muslims and I think most muslims in general know Pauline Hanson, they know what her agenda is,\" Dr Aly told News Corp.\n\n\"This is probably just another eye-roll moment, although one that has reached a new level of low, and quite disgraceful to carry out such a stunt in our Parliament.\n\n\"Most Australians are already disaffected with politics and with politicians.\n\n\"This is not the way to increase that trust between individuals and groups in our society and the political institutions and the politicians that represent them.\"\n\nDr Aly said while she personally did not agree with the call to ban the burqa, the discussion could be had respectfully.\n\n\"If people want to have a conversation about it, have a conversation about it respectfully,\" she said.\n\n\"You do not need to wear a burqa in the senate and absolutely make a mockery of the parliament and a mockery of the office that you're elected into by the Australian people to make that point.\"\n\nDr Aly said a handful of women wearing a burqa in Australian society did not add to the risk of terrorism.\n\n\"If that literature exists, if that research exists, if that empirical evidence exists, I'd like to see it - but I haven't seen it anywhere,\" she said.\n\n\"It's an argument designed to make her real agenda a little bit more palatable.\n\n\"That is to ban Muslims from Australia ... basically to disenfranchise and isolate and create division between all Australians and Muslim Australians. Most Australians, who are decent people who treasure our social harmony, who treasure our multicultural society, wouldn't stand for that.\"\n\nHANSON AND DICK SMITH UNITE\n\nThe incredible stunt comes after Senator Hanson met with prominent Australian businessman Dick Smith to discuss immigration policy in Canberra today.\n\nThe One Nation leader tweeted a film clip of her meeting with Mr Smith, who recently launched a 'grim reaper' anti-immigration ad campaign, to argue Australia's annual intake should be capped at 70, 000.\n\n\"Every Australian family doesn't have 20 kids. They have the number of kids they can give a good life too. I want our politicians to have a similar plan for the nation,\" Mr Smith said in the video.\n\nTRUMP ADMINISTRATION'S ONE NATION WARNING\n\nSenator Hanson's stunt comes two days after the Trump administration named Pauline Hanson's One Nation Party among threats to religious freedom in Australia.\n\nThe annual report on threats to religious freedom internationally, released by Secretary of State Rex Tillerson on Wednesday, highlighted the party's calls for \"ceasing Muslim immigration, holding a royal commission on Islam, halting construction of mosques, installing surveillance cameras in mosques, banning wearing of the burqa and niqab in public places, and prohibiting members of parliament from being sworn in under the Quran\".\n\nThe report also noted that Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull disagreed with the party's position.\n\nMPS REACT TO HANSON'S STUNT AND BRANDIS' ATTACK\n\nMPs from boths houses of Federal Parliament took to social media to condemn Senator Hanson for her stunt and praise Senator Brandis for his remarks.\n\nGreens Leader Richard Di Natale also labelled her actions \"disgraceful\" and argument for a multicultural code of conduct for the parliament to prevent future stunts.\n\nLabor frontbencher Penny Wong said the \"bigotry and divisiveness\" Senator Hanson displayed \"has no place in our society\".\n\n\"It certainly has no place in our parliament,\" she said.\n\n\"Today our parliament showed leadership when it was needed.\n\n\"It is one thing to wear religious dress as an act of faith. It is another to wear it as a stunt. That can only give offence and divide.\n\n\"Nobody needs to defend Senator Hanson's right to speak. The people that need defending are the people she attacks.\"\n\nSenator Wong said leaders have an obligation to stand up for the people in Australia, and said Senator Brandis and the Parliament had done so.\n\nLabor senator Sam Dastyari, who is fond of a stunt himself, told 2GB Senator Hanson had crossed a line.\n\nHanson's stunt beneath contempt. Response from Brandis is spot on. Now let's give her the attention she deserves - absolutely none. -- Bill Shorten (@billshortenmp)\n\nAugust 17, 2017\n\nPauline Hanson's divisive stunt has no place in our parliament. The Greens stand with him in condemning Senator Hanson's appalling actions in Question Time. -- Richard Di Natale (@RichardDiNatale)\n\nAugust 17, 2017\n\nTrue leadership shown by Senator Brandis today. Photo: Reuters\n\nAccording to Reuters, Hanson appeared in the assembly wearing the burqa. She removed the burqa after 20 minutes before speaking on the banning of the attire for the sake of 'public and security reasons'.\n\nThe leader of the far-right One Nation Party spoke to the Senate, \"I m quite happy to remove this because this is not what should belong in this parliament,\" Hanson, who leads the far-right One Nation party, told the Senate.\n\n\"If a person who wears a balaclava or a helmet in to a bank or any other building, or even on the floor of the court, has to remove it, why is it not the same case for someone who is covering up their face and cannot be identified?\"\n\nHanson gained popularity during the 90s because of her vocal opposition towards the immigration from Asia and to asylum seekers. In her recent campaigns Hanson talks against Islamic clothing and the building of mosques.\n\nHanson's burqa stunt wasn't received well by some Senators who were appalled. Attorney General George Brandis admonished Hanson. He condemned her for offending religious groups.\n\n\"I am not going to pretend to ignore the stunt that you have tried to pull today by arriving in the chamber dressed in a burqa,\" he said.\n\nThe leader of the government in the Senate, the attorney general George Brandis, who was appalled by Hanson's burqa stunt told the One Nation leader the ruling Coalition had no intention of banning the burqa.\n\nBrandis received applause from opposition parties. He also stated Senator Hanson's action has alienated approximately 500,000 Muslim Australians.\n\n\"We all know that you are not adherent of the Islamic faith. I would caution and counsel you with respect to be very, very careful of the offense you may do to the religious sensibilities of other Australians.\"\n\nBrandis also added: \"No, Senator Hanson, we will not ban the burqa.\"\n\nSenators criticised Hanson's stunt in the Assembly and stated that: \"It is one thing to wear religious dress as a sincere act of faith, there is another to wear it as a stunt here in the chamber,\" said Labor Senator Penny Wong.\n\nAdel Salman, vice president of the Islamic Council of Victoria state, said Hanson s action was \"a mockery of her position\". \"It is very disappointing, but not surprising as she has sought to mock the Islamic faith time and time again.\"\n\nAccording to BBC, Hanson's motion to ban the garment (burqa) will be debated further on Thursday. "dailymail.co.uk", "id": "214"}, "url": "http://www.dailymail.co.uk/~/article-4799172/index.html", "eventUri": "eng-3368046", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368046", "body": "A conservative senator who agrees with Pauline Hanson on Islam has slammed her for wearing a burqa in parliament.\n\nSenator Hanson, the firebrand One Nation leader, shocked her Senate colleagues on Thursday afternoon by wearing a black burqa into the chamber for Question Time.\n\nAustralian Conservatives leader Cory Bernardi disagreed with her parliamentary theatrics, even though he agrees her idea of banning the burqa.\n\n'She made a particularly blunt point but I'm not sure it's a point that should be made in the Senate chamber,' he told the ABC's 7.30 program on Thursday.\n\nScroll down for video\n\nSenator Pauline Hanson donned the burqa and fronted the Senate for Question Time\n\n'I don't like stunts of this nature,' said Australian Conservatives leader Cory Bernardi\n\n'I'm just as concerned about the dignity of our parliamentary system as I am about preserving our culture and I don't like stunts of this nature to take place in our parliament.'\n\nSenator Bernardi, a former Liberal Party member, does share the One Nation leader's dislike of the burqa, however.\n\n'It's a direct affront to our national values, the expectation of how we deal with each other,' he said.\n\n'Wearing a facial veil in Australia is tantamount to saying, \"I don't want to be part of you, I don't want to engage with you, I want to isolate and shut myself off from society\".'\n\nHe slammed the 'double standards' of Senator Hanson's critics, who say they favour the right of women to choose to wear the burqa, only to slam her for choosing to put on an Islamic outfit.\n\n'The burqa and those who wear it are essentially Islamic fundamentalists,' he said, contradicting Senator Hanson's argument that it's not a religious garment.\n\nAfter making a dramatic entrance on the floor of parliament, Senator Hanson took off her black burqa and called for the government to ban 'oppressive' full-face coverings.\n\n'I'm quite happy to remove this, because this is not what should belong in this Parliament,' she said.\n\nHer appearance was met with outrage and laughter, prompting Senate President Stephen Parry to call for order.\n\n'In light of our national security of this nation, will you work to ban the burqa in Australia?' she said.\n\n'There have been 13 foiled national threats against us with terrorism, three that have been successful and Australians have lost their lives.\n\n'Terrorism is a true threat to our country. Many Australians are very much in fear of it.\n\n'A large majority of Australians wish to see the banning of the burqa.'\n\nSenator Hanson said the idea for her burqa stunt was born when Senate President Stephen Parry told her last year that anyone could wear a burqa in Parliament.\n\n'I'm quite happy to remove this, because this is not what should belong in this Parliament,' Ms Hanson said as she stood to speak\n\nShe said the burqa was an 'important issue' facing modern Australia.\n\nIn a statement released on Wednesday, Senator Hanson said the burqa 'presented barriers to assimilation'.\n\nShe said the Islamic dress 'disadvantaged women from finding employment, was causing issues inside our justice system, presented a clear security threat and had no place in modern Western society'.\n\n'I'm quite happy to remove this, because this is not what should belong in this Parliament,' Ms Hanson (pictured) said when she stood to speak\n\nIn a statement released on Wednesday, Senator Hanson (pictured) said the burqa was 'oppressive'\n\nSenator Hanson's dress choice prompted Senate President Stephen Parry to call for order in the chamber.\n\n'I've been advised by the clerk that the identity of Senator Hanson was established before she entered the chamber,' he said.\n\nThe stunt drew anger from the opposition benches, with crossbencher Derryn Hinch questioning whether Senator Hanson could remain in the chamber.\n\n'I understand that she is not a Muslim, not of Islamic faith. Can I appear tomorrow in fancy dress unchallenged?' he asked the president.\n\nSenator Parry said he was not going to dictate the standard of dress for senators.\n\nSenator Hanson will move a motion in parliament on Thursday, to be debated in the afternoon, calling on the federal government to ban the burqa\n\nSenator Hanson will move a motion in parliament on Thursday, to be debated in the afternoon, calling on the federal government to ban the burqa.\n\nIndependent senator Cory Bernardi also weighed in on the stunt.\n\n'I did warn you that proroguing the parliament was in national interest. Things are getting seriously weirder by the day,' he posted to Twitter.\n\nSenator Hanson will move a motion in parliament on Thursday, to be debated in the afternoon, calling on the federal government to ban the burqa\n\nAttorney-General George Brandis choked back tears as he tore into Senator Hanson for wearing the Islamic garb onto the floor of the Senate.\n\nThe former small business owner had urged the government to ban the burqa for 'national security reasons' but Senator Brandis was having none of it.\n\n'I am not going to pretend to ignore the stunt that you have tried to pull today by arriving in the chamber dressed in a burqa,' he said.\n\n'We all know that you are not an adherent of the Islamic faith. I would caution and counsel you with respect to be very, very careful of the offence you may do to the religious sensibilities of other Australians.\n\n'I am not going to pretend to ignore the stunt that you have tried to pull today by arriving in the Chamber dressed in a burqa,' Attorney-General George Brandis said\n\n'We have about 500,000 Australians in this country of the Islamic faith. And the vast majority of them are law abiding good Australians,' Senator Brandis said\n\n'We have about 500,000 Australians in this country of the Islamic faith. And the vast majority of them are law-abiding, good Australians.'\n\nThe government's top legal official, Senator Brandis, said he had responsibility for national security policy.\n\n'And I can tell you, Senator Hanson, that is it has been the advice of each Director-General of security with whom I have worked and each Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police with whom I have worked that it is vital for their intelligence and law enforcement work that they work cooperatively with the Muslim community.\n\n'And to ridicule that community, to drive it into a corner, to mock its religious garments is an appalling thing to do and I would ask you to reflect on what you have done.'\n\n'Pauline Hanson has absolutely no shame. She is beyond any level of decency. Should be banned from parliament,' one Twitter user said\n\nBefore the stunt, Senator Hanson made a video in her office calling the burqa 'un-Australian'.\n\n'It is important we know who is behind that veil is the person you voted for, the person that represents you,' she said.\n\n'And I think for security reasons as well, it is very important and another thing, it is un-Australian.'\n\nShe later told Ben Fordham on 2GB that Australia had to prepare for a Muslim woman being elected to Parliament and choosing to wear the burqa.\n\nBut she added Labor wouldn't speak out because its safe {"timeCrawl": "16:30:00", "uri": "710995351", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T16:30:00Z", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "source": {"title": "Mail Online", "uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "id": "214"}, "url": "http://www.dailymail.co.uk/~/article-4799952/index.html", "eventUri": "eng-3368046", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368046", "body": "A Labor senator who describes himself as a 'non-practising Muslim' says he doesn't like the burqa.\n\nSam Dastyari said the Muslim garment covering the face was something he had fought against.\n\n'I don't particularly like the burqa, I'm a non-practising Muslim,' he told Sydney 2GB radio broadcaster Ben Fordham.\n\n'I've rejected those kind of things my entire life.'\n\nScroll down for video\n\nQueensland Senator Pauline Hanson wore a burqa and fronted the Senate for Question Time\n\nLabor senator Sam Dastyari said he disliked the burqa as a non-practising Muslim Australian\n\nHowever, the Iranian-born Labor powerbroker likened One Nation leader Pauline Hanson wearing the burqa into the Senate chamber to a Greens colleague hypothetically dressing as a Catholic priest.\n\n'It would be equally offensive if one of the Greens senators had tried to walk in as a priest to make some kind of a ridiculous point about the royal commission into child sexual abuse,' he said.\n\nThe 34-year-old senator, who moved to Australia when he was four, said mocking the burqa was unhelpful to Australia's security agencies, and chastised her for laughing during her Senate appearance.\n\n'I don't believe that this kind of a stunt does anything or achieves anything or helps in any way,' Senator Dastyari said.\n\nSam Dastyari clashed with Pauline Hanson on the ABC when she asked if he was a Muslim\n\nPauline Hanson also rejected Sam Dastyari's election night offer of having a halal snack pack\n\nSenator Dastyari and Senator Hanson clashed in July last year on the ABC's Q&A program when she asked him if he was a Muslim.\n\nA few weeks earlier on election night, the One Nation leader rejected his suggestion she join him for a halal snack pack.\n\nAustralian Conservatives leader Cory Bernardi also criticised Senator Hanson for wearing the burqa in parliament, even though he agrees with her idea of banning the burqa.\n\n'She made a particularly blunt point but I'm not sure it's a point that should be made in the Senate chamber,' he told the ABC's 7.30 program on Thursday.\n\n'I don't like stunts of this nature,' said Australian Conservatives leader Cory Bernardi\n\n'I'm just as concerned about the dignity of our parliamentary system as I am about preserving our culture and I don't like stunts of this nature to take place in our parliament.'\n\nSenator Bernardi, a former Liberal Party member, does share the One Nation leader's dislike of the burqa, however.\n\n'It's a direct affront to our national values, the expectation of how we deal with each other,' he said.\n\n'Wearing a facial veil in Australia is tantamount to saying, 'I don't want to be part of you, I don't want to engage with you, I want to isolate and shut myself off from society'.'\n\nSenator Bernardi said his heart 'skipped a beat' when he saw Senator Hanson walk past him in a 'flag of fundamentalism'.\n\n'I jumped back and thought, 'What the heck is going on here?',' he said.\n\nAfter making a dramatic entrance on the floor of parliament, Senator Hanson took off her black burqa and called for the government to ban 'oppressive' full-face coverings.\n\n'I'm quite happy to remove this, because this is not what should belong in this Parliament,' she said.\n\nHer appearance was met with outrage and laughter, prompting Senate President Stephen Parry to call for order.\n\n'In light of our national security of this nation, will you work to ban the burqa in Australia?' she said.\n\n'There have been 13 foiled national threats against us with terrorism, three that have been successful and Australians have lost their lives.\n\n'Terrorism is a true threat to our country. Many Australians are very much in fear of it.\n\n'A large majority of Australians wish to see the banning of the burqa.'\n\nSenator Hanson said the idea for her burqa stunt was born when Senate President Stephen Parry told her last year that anyone could wear a burqa in Parliament.\n\n'I'm quite happy to remove this, because this is not what should belong in this Parliament,' Ms Hanson said as she stood to speak\n\n'I'm quite happy to remove this, because this is not what should belong in this Parliament,' Ms Hanson (pictured) said when she stood to speak\n\nSenator Hanson's dress choice prompted Senate President Stephen Parry to call for order in the chamber.\n\n'I've been advised by the clerk that the identity of Senator Hanson was established before she entered the chamber,' he said.\n\nThe stunt drew anger from the opposition benches, with crossbencher Derryn Hinch questioning whether Senator Hanson could remain in the chamber.\n\n'I understand that she is not a Muslim, not of Islamic faith. Can I appear tomorrow in fancy dress unchallenged?' he asked the president.\n\nSenator Parry said he was not going to dictate the standard of dress for senators.\n\nSenator Hanson will move a motion in parliament on Thursday, to be debated in the afternoon, calling on the federal government to ban the burqa\n\nSenator Hanson will move a motion in parliament on Thursday, to be debated in the afternoon, calling on the federal government to ban the burqa\n\nAttorney-General George Brandis choked back tears as he tore into Senator Hanson for wearing the Islamic garb onto the floor of the Senate.\n\nThe former small business owner had urged the government to ban the burqa for 'national security reasons' but Senator Brandis was having none of it.\n\n'I am not going to pretend to ignore the stunt that you have tried to pull today by arriving in the chamber dressed in a burqa,' he said.\n\n'We all know that you are not an adherent of the Islamic faith. I would caution and counsel you with respect to be very, very careful of the offence you may do to the religious sensibilities of other Australians.\n\n'We have about 500,000 Australians in this country of the Islamic faith. And the vast majority of them are law abiding good Australians,' Senator Brandis said\n\n'We have about 500,000 Australians in this country of the Islamic faith. And the vast majority of them are law-abiding, good Australians.'\n\nThe government's top legal official, Senator Brandis, said he had responsibility for national security policy.\n\n'And I can tell you, Senator Hanson, that is it has been the advice of each Director-General of security with whom I have worked and each Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police with whom I have worked that it is vital for their intelligence and law enforcement work that they work cooperatively with the Muslim community.\n\n'And to ridicule that community, to drive it into a corner, to mock its religious garments is an appalling thing to do and I would ask you to reflect on what you have done.'\n\nBefore the stunt, Senator Hanson made a video in her office calling the burqa 'un-Australian'.\n\n'It is important we know who is behind that veil is the person you voted for, the person that represents you,' she said.\n\n'And I think for security reasons as well, it is very important and another thing, it is un-Australian.'\n\nShe later told Ben Fordham on 2GB that Australia had to prepare for a Muslim woman being elected to Parliament and choosing to wear the burqa.\n\nBut she added Labor wouldn't {"timeCrawl": "14:05:00", "uri": "710922585", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T09:14:00Z", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "source": {"title": "Australian Times", "uri": "australiantimes.co.uk", "id": "6778"}, "url": "https://www.australiantimes.co.uk/pauline-hansons-outrageous-senate-burqa-stunt-ridiculed-by-shocked-colleagues-watch/", "eventUri": "eng-3368046", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368046", "body": "VIDEO: George Brandis received a standing ovation from his political rivals across the chamber for his devastating condemnation of Pauline Hanson wearing a full burqa in the Senate.\n\nPauline Hanson set out to shock parliament on Thursday and absolutely succeeded. The controversial right wing One Nation leader appeared in Parliament dressed in a full burqa.\n\nApparently seeking to generate debate (and headlines) about the place of Muslim culture in Australian society, when she took off the black Islamic cloak, Ms Hanson - whose political career is founded on xenophobic stances on a number of issues - goaded Liberal Attorney-General George Brandis, asking if the government would back her policy of banning the burqa.\n\nSee the video, above.\n\nThe reply from a visibly furious Mr Brandis was swift and brutal.\n\n\"Senator Hanson, no, we will not be banning the burqa,\" he said sternly.\n\n\"I am not going to pretend to ignore the stunt that you have tried to pull today by arriving in the chamber dressed in a burqa when we all know that you are not an adherent of the Islamic faith.\n\n\"I would caution and counsel you with respect to be very, very careful of the offence you may do to the religious sensibilities of other Australians.\"\n\n\"We have about 500,000 Australians in this country of the Islamic faith and the vast majority of them are law-abiding good Australians.\n\n\"Senator Hanson, for the last four years, I have had responsibility pre-eminently among the ministers subject to the Prime Minister for national security policy.\n\n\"And I can tell you, Senator Hanson, that it has been the advice of each director-general of security with whom I have worked and each commissioner of the Australian Federal Police with whom I have worked that it is vital for their intelligence and law enforcement work that they work co-operatively with the Muslim community, and to ridicule that community, to drive it into a corner, to mock its religious garments is an appalling thing to do.\n\n\"I would ask you to reflect on that.\"\n\nThe speech was met with a standing ovation from his opposition Labor and Greens senators on the other side of the chamber.\n\nLater on radio 2GB, Ms Hanson sought to explain her burqa wearing stunt.\n\n\"It is foreign to us. This is not our way of life. "couriermail.com.au", "id": "2778"}, "url": "http://www.couriermail.com.au/news/george-brandis-attacks-pauline-hansons-move-to-wear-a-burqua-in-the-senate/news-story/ca26619246eb6d4e0bcdb9f2985cbdfb", "eventUri": "eng-3368046", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368046", "body": "ATTORNEY-GENERAL George Brandis launched a withering and emotional condemnation of Pauline Hanson's decision to wear a burqa to Question Time.\n\nWith his voice cracking, Senator Brandis described Ms Hanson's move to wear the Muslim garment to the Senate and then remove it as \"appalling\".\n\n\"Senator Hanson, no, we will not be banning the burqa,\" a clearly emotional Brandis said.\n\n\"I am not going to pretend to ignore the stunt that you have tried to pull today by arriving in the Chamber dressed in a burqa when we all know that you are not an adherent of the Islamic faith.\n\n\"I would caution and counsel you with respect to be very, very careful of the offence you may do to the religious sensibilities of other Australians.\"\n\n\"We have about 500,000 Australians in this country of the Islamic faith and the vast majority of them are law abiding good Australians.\n\n\"Senator Hanson, for the last four years, I have had responsibility pre-eminently among the ministers subject to the Prime Minister for national security policy.\n\nRELATED: Australia's weirdest political stunts\n\n\"And I can tell you, Senator Hanson, that it has been the advice of each Director-General of security with whom I have worked and each Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police with whom I have worked that it is vital for their intelligence and law enforcement work that they work cooperatively with the Muslim community and to ridicule that community, to drive it into a corner, to mock its religious garments is an appalling thing to do and I would ask you to reflect on that.\"\n\nThe speech received a standing ovation from opposition members of the parliament.\n\nNick Xenophon praised Senator Brandis's stance describing what Ms Hanson did as \"toxic behaviour\".\n\n\"George Brandis spoke like a true statesman,\" he said.\n\n\"He displayed the leadership and clarity of purpose the country needs on an issue like this. So good on you George.\n\n\"He has shown what it means to be a statesman when many other politicians would have shied away, he did the right thing.\"\n\nGreens Leader Richard Di Natale also labelled Ms Hanson's actions \"disgraceful\" and argument for a multicultural code of conduct for the parliament to prevent future stunts.\n\nOf the stunt, Senator Hanson told radio station 2GB her One Nation colleague Brian Burston identified her to the senate security guards but said none of the guards checked to confirm her identity before she walked in.\n\n\"I put it on in my office, the media were taking photos, I walked straight down the hallway, down the stairs. I met two security guards and I walked straight up the chamber,\" she said.\n\n\"No one, no security guard at any point of time asked to see my face.\n\n\"When I walked into the chamber one of the attendants ... he just gasped.\n\n\"Doesn't the Australian people have the right to know that whoever sits in the chamber, that is actually the person they voted for,\" she said.\n\n\"How do I know, that if you have someone ... in a burqa in that chamber it is that person who walks in that chamber every time?\"\n\n\"These are questions that need to be asked.\n\n\"To blatantly come out, as Senator Brandis did with a definite no, 'we're not going to ban the burqa, we're not going to have equality as far as anyone wearing full faced coverings into a bank or into the chamber, a blatant 'No' straight off without saying 'Let's discuss this' ... it was just a definite 'No'.\n\nSenator Hanson hit back at the suggestions she was mocking the Islamic faith.\n\n\"That's absolute rubbish - I'm not mocking anyone,\" she said.\n\n\"People have a right to their own faith and what they believe in, I've got no problems with that. But when that faith stops at a religion and then becomes a political ideology, that's what I have problems with.\n\n\"The burqa is not a religious requirement. It is a matter of controlling women.\"\n\nSenator Hanson said while she was walking to the chamber in the burqa, a Greens senator, Peter Whish-Wilson, shook her hand.\n\nShe described it as \"tokenism\".\n\nHanson also condemned the standing ovation from the Greens and Labor senators to Senator Brandis's response.\n\n\"It's basically saying this is the future, we're not going to stop the spreading of Islam, we're not going to stop this division happening in our society.\"\n\nSenator Hanson has described the experience of wearing the burqa as \"horrible\".\n\nShe said the idea for the stunt was her own and was designed to expose the security threats to Parliament and to call for the ban.\n\n\"It's been an idea of mine to actually expose about the burqa,\" she said.\n\n\"I'm very much against the burqa. I think it's confronting. I think it's un-Australian.\n\n\"It's hard to describe - I feel for these women who are actually forced to wear it because the pressure is put on them by their husbands and their fathers,\" she said.\n\n\"It's not a religious requirement, let's get that clear.\"\n\n\"Is it extreme? Yes. Is this getting my message across? I hope so.\"\n\n\"I hope it's creating debate. Because we have overall probably more than 55 per cent of Australians want to see the burqa banned. And I think there's no better place to start than with the Parliament.\"\n\nLabor frontbencher Penny Wong said the \"bigotry and divisiveness\" Senator Hanson displayed \"has no place in our society\".\n\n\"It certainly has no place in our parliament,\" she said.\n\n\"Today our parliament showed leadership when it was needed.\n\n\"It is one thing to wear religious dress as an act of faith. It is another to wear it as a stunt. That can only give offence and divide.\n\n\"Nobody needs to defend Senator Hanson's right to speak. The people that need defending are the people she attacks.\"\n\nSenator Wong said leaders have an obligation to stand up for the people in Australia, and said Senator Brandis and the Parliament had done so.\n\nLabor senator Sam Dastyari, who is fond of a stunt himself, told 2GB Senator Hanson had crossed a line.\n\nSenator Derryn Hinch said Senator Hanson's behaviour was \"disgusting\".\n\n\"Pauline Hanson mocked the religion of some Australians, she was insulting their religion,\" he told Sky News.\n\nSenator Hinch said Senator Hanson should not have been allowed into Question Time wearing the religious garment.\n\n\"It is like in court, you have to be able to see people's faces,\" he said.\n\n\"She made a mockery of an honourable place. To pull a stunt like this I find it insulting.\"\n\nSenator Hanson also praised the Attorney-General's speech and the positive reaction it received.\n\n\"He gave the best speech I have heard from him,\" he said.\n\n\"He did a very good job and it was an act of all decent members of Parliament to show the Hansonites that this doesn't work, this won't work.\"\n\nHowever Senator Hinch did concede Senator Hanson's supporters would approve of the stunt.\n\n\"People that irrationally hate all Muslims, they will be happy about this,\" he said.", "id": "9640520", "details": {}, "date": Can I appear tomorrow in fancy dress unchallenged?\" he asked the president.\n\nSenator Parry said he was not going to dictate the standard of dress for senators.\n\nSenator Hanson will move a motion in parliament on Thursday, to be debated in the afternoon, calling on the federal government to ban the burqa.\n\nIndependent senator Cory Bernardi also weighed in on the stunt.\n\n\"I did warn you that proroguing the parliament was in national interest.
