{"timeCrawl": "08:35:00", "uri": "710770819", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T08:35:00Z", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "source": {"title": "The Maitland Mercury", "uri": "maitlandmercury.com.au", "id": "3181"}, "url": "http://www.maitlandmercury.com.au/story/4863532/hanson-burqa-stunt-ignites-firestorm-over-religious-freedoms/", "eventUri": "eng-3368046", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368046", "body": "One Nation leader Pauline Hanson has triggered a firestorm around religious freedoms after wearing a burqa into Parliament.\n\nHanson burqa stunt ignites firestorm over religious freedoms\n\nThe Opposition praise Senator Brandis after he repudiated Senator Pauline Hanson for wearing a burqa during question time at Parliament House in Canberra on Thursday 17 August 2017. Fedpol. Photo: Andrew Meares\n\nof\n\n\u2573exitView More Local BusinessList Your Business Here\n\nOne Nation leader Pauline Hanson has triggered a firestorm around religious freedoms, after wearing a burqa into Parliament, a stunt that has united all sides of politics in condemnation.\n\nThe Queensland senator, accompanied by colleague Brian Burston, entered the Senate dressed in a black Islamic dress shortly after question time began on Thursday afternoon - her senator pin still on display.\n\nAs senators could be heard groaning and gasping at her entrance, Senate President Stephen Parry confirmed it was Senator Hanson beneath the face covering, while seeming unsure of how to officially respond to the performance.\n\nAttorney-General George Brandis showed no hesitation.\n\nWhen Senator Hanson whipped off the garment with a dramatic flourish, exclaiming how glad she was to be free of it, and asked Senator Brandis if the government would join her in banning the burqa, he did not hold back.\n\n\"Senator Hanson, no, we will not be banning the burqa,\" he said, visibly angry, and looking at one point like he was close to tears.\n\n\"I am not going to pretend to ignore the stunt that you have tried to pull today by arriving in the chamber dressed in a burqa when we all know that you are not an adherent of the Islamic faith.\n\n\"I would caution and counsel you with respect to be very, very careful of the offence you may do to the religious sensibilities of other Australians.\"\n\n\"We have about 500,000 Australians in this country of the Islamic faith and the vast majority of them are law-abiding good Australians.\n\n\"Senator Hanson, for the last four years, I have had responsibility pre-eminently among the ministers subject to the Prime Minister for national security policy.\n\n\"And I can tell you, Senator Hanson, that it has been the advice of each director-general of security with whom I have worked and each commissioner of the Australian Federal Police with whom I have worked that it is vital for their intelligence and law enforcement work that they work co-operatively with the Muslim community, and to ridicule that community, to drive it into a corner, to mock its religious garments is an appalling thing to do.\n\n\"I would ask you to reflect on that.\"\n\nIn extraordinary scenes, Labor and Greens senators burst into spontaneous applause, before getting to their feet in enthusiastic praise, while his Coalition colleagues remained seated.\n\nSenator Hanson and Senator Burston left the chamber shortly after, to calls of \"good on you, George\" from the opposing side.\n\nBut she had made her point, reigniting a debate that flamed in 2014 when then-prime minister Tony Abbott was forced to reverse a decision by Speaker Bronwyn Bishop and Senator Parry to isolate women wearing a burqa or niqab in glass enclosures away from the public galleries.\n\nASIO head Duncan Lewis rebuked Senator Hanson earlier this year after she asked whether a terrorist threat was \"being brought in\" with Middle Eastern refugees.\n\n\"We've made it plain on a number of occasions, senator, that we have no security reason to be concerned about the wearing of a burqa other than the requirement for individuals to identify themselves to authorities, and there are regulations in place for that,\" Mr Lewis said in May.\n\nHe stood by his assessment despite criticism from One Nation and conservative members of the Coalition in the following days.\n\nBut while politicians from across the political divide united in their praise of Senator Brandis for his swift and unwavering condemnation of her actions, Senator Hanson - whose party was recently named by the Trump administration as a threat to religious freedoms - was relishing having \"started the debate\". \"???It was a horrible feeling, I felt just cut off from the rest of the world,\" she told Radio 2GB.\n\n\"Here I am, no one can see my facial features, no one can see if I have given them a smile, or look at my eyes, or my reaction to them - isn't that a part of our society, that we have to interact with people?\n\n\"???It is foreign to us. This is not our way of life. And so many in the suburbs of Sydney, if you are honest about it, if you are not a Muslim, you really don't want to go to these places because you don't feel welcome there.\"\n\nIslamic Friendship Association of Australia spokesman Keysar Trad predicted some \"women who wear the burqa will feel hurt and will feel that they are under siege again\" by the Senator's actions.\n\n\"Why isn't Pauline Hanson supporting their right to dress as they choose?\"\n\nIslamic Council of Victoria vice-president Adel Salman said the stunt was offensive, and \"doesn't really help the debate\".\n\n\"The current discourse is really negative. It's about time [Senator Hanson] is ridiculed and her platform is ridiculed,\" he said.\n\nBoth Mr Trad and Mr Salman praised Senator Brandis' strong response.\n\nLabor, Greens and other crossbench senators, including Derryn Hinch and Nick Xenophon, called for Senator Hanson's stunt to be ignored.\n\nUndeterred, Senator Hanson took to the Senate floor later that same day to deliver a speech calling for the burqa ban and claiming Islam was \"threatening our way of life\", speaking to an almost empty room.\n\nFollow us on Facebook\n\nThe story Hanson burqa stunt ignites firestorm over religious freedoms first appeared on The Sydney Morning Herald.", "id": "9643500", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-17", "title": "Hanson burqa stunt ignites firestorm over religious freedoms", {"timeCrawl": "08:17:00", "uri": "710761514", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T03:26:00Z", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "source": {"title": "Business Insider Australia", "uri": "businessinsider.com.au", "id": "7794"}, "url": "https://www.businessinsider.com.au/someone-is-sitting-in-pauline-hansons-seat-in-the-senate-wearing-a-burka-2017-8", "eventUri": "eng-3368046", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368046", "body": "One Nation leader Pauline Hanson appeared in the Australian senate today wearing the full black covering of a burqa, drawing an immediate rebuke from the attorney-general in a speech that earned an extended ovation from the chamber.\n\nHanson wore the covering for several minutes before getting to her feet, when invited by the Senate President, to ask about banning the burqa in Australia \"in light of national security\".\n\nHanson's call is part of a long-running campaign by the controversial Queensland senator, who, when she returned to parliament last year, claimed that the country was going to be over-run with Muslims - a variation on her claim 20 years earlier that Australia was being \"swamped by Asians\".\n\nShe claimed there was a \"large majority of Australians\" who wished to see Australia following France in outlawing the garment.\n\nIn response, attorney-general George Brandis with an emphatic \"no\" and then chastised Hanson for her behaviour.\n\n\"I'm not going to pretend to ignore the stunt that you have tried to pull today by arriving in the chamber dressed in a burqa when we all know that you are not an adherent of the Islamic faith,\" he said.\n\n\"I would caution you and counsel you senator Hanson, with respect, to be very, very careful of the offence you may do to the religious sensibilities of other Australians.\n\n\"We have about half a million Australians in this country of the Islamic faith and the vast majority of them are law-abiding, good Australians... It is absolutely consistent with being a good, law-abiding Australian and a strict, adherent Muslim.\"\n\nSenator Brandis said he'd had responsibility for the national security for four years and intelligence and law enforcement officials worked closely with the Muslim community.\n\nHis voice quivered with emotion as he concluded his response, saying: \"To ridicule that community, to drive it into a corner, to mock its religious garments is an appalling thing to do and I would ask you to reflect on what you do\".\n\nThe senate erupted with applause as he concluded his reply and Labor senators and many on the crossbench stood to applaud.\n\nGeorge Brandis on the verge of tears as he tells Pauline Hanson her behaviour is \"appalling\". Standing ovation from ALP/Greens. #auspol #QT pic.twitter.com/KQpc6q5RVN\n\n-- Michael Koziol (@michaelkoziol) August 17, 2017\n\nSenate President Stephen Parry said that when Hanson entered the chamber, he confirmed her identity, and declined to comment on her attire.\n\nShe also had her red senator's pin, which identifies her as a member of the chamber, pinned to the outside of her garment.\n\nIn subsequent debate, Labor's Penny Wong said Hanson's actions were \"disgraceful\" and \"disrespectful\".\n\n\"I make this point on behalf of all of us on this side of the chamber, it is one thing to wear religious dress as a sincere act of faith, there is another to wear it as a stunt here in the chamber,\" Wong said.\n\nAnd the attorney-general's response won praise from Labor senator Sam Dastyari, who is Muslim.\n\nGeorge Brandis was just brilliant in the chamber. Just brilliant. Strongest I have ever heard him.\n\n-- Sam Dastyari (@samdastyari) August 17, 2017\n\nWhen question time in the senate ended at 3pm Greens senators crossed the chamber and shook hands with senator Brandis.\n\nHanson subsequently issued the following media release on Facebook:\n\nSenator Pauline Hanson has attended question time dressed modestly in a full burqa and will later be delivering a speech in Parliament calling for the Government to ban full face coverings in public.\n\nSenator Hanson said she made the decision to attend question time in a full face covering because she believed the need to ban full face coverings in public was an important issue facing modern Australia that needed to be discussed.\n\nSenator Hanson said she wished to raise the issue of full face covering presenting a security threat not only to Parliament House, but also to the greater Australian public.\n\nSenator Hanson said that she believed that full face covering, such as the burqa, were oppressive, presented barriers to assimilation, disadvantaged women from finding employment, were causing issues inside our justice system, presented a clear security threat and had no place in modern Western society.\n\nSenator Hanson said that this was a debate that was happening across the world and Australia could not hide from a difficult conversation out of fear of causing offence.\n\nSenator Hanson is scheduled to deliver a speech outlining the full extent of her position later today.", "id": "9640518", "details": {"liCnt": 80}, "date": "2017-08-17", "title": "'DISGRACEFUL, {"timeCrawl": "10:41:00", "uri": "710826763", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T04:21:00Z", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "source": {"title": "The New Daily", "uri": "thenewdaily.com.au", "id": "4714"}, "url": "http://thenewdaily.com.au/news/national/2017/08/17/pauline-hanson-burqa/", "eventUri": "eng-3368046", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368046", "body": "One Nation Leader Pauline Hanson walked into the Senate wearing a burqa on Thursday afternoon in a parliamentary stunt branded \"appalling\" by Attorney-General George Brandis.\n\nDuring Senate Question Time, Senator Hanson entered the chamber dressed in the religious garment and sat wearing it for more than 20 minutes.\n\nWhen it was her time to ask a question, she rose to her feet and tore off the burqa, sparking outrage from all quarters of the chamber.\n\n\"I am quite happy to remove this because this is not what should be in this Parliament,\" she said.\n\n\"Senator Brandis, in light of our national security in this nation, will you work to actually ban the burqa in Australia?\"\n\nSenator Hanson linked the garment to terrorism and claimed that a large number of Australians supported a ban.\n\nIn an unequivocal condemnation of Senator Hanson's stunt, a furious Senator Brandis said the government did not support a ban.\n\n\"Now, Senator Hanson, I am not going to pretend to ignore the stunt that you have tried to pull today by arriving in the chamber dressed in a burqa,\" he said.\n\n\"We all know you are not an adherent of the Islamic faith.\n\n\"We have about half a million Australians of Islamic faith. And the vast majority of them are law-abiding, good Australians. And Senator Hanson, it is absolutely consistent with being a good, law-abiding Australian and a strict adherent Muslim.\"\n\nSenator Brandis said the advice he'd received from authorities as a minister responsible for national security was that \"it is vital for their intelligence and law enforcement that they work they Muslim community\".\n\nHe added, seeming to fight back tears: \"To ridicule that community, to drive it into a corner, to mock its religious garment is an appalling thing to do. I would ask you to reflect on what you have done.\"\n\nSenator Brandis's comments drew a standing ovation and sustained applause from Labor and the Greens in what must go down as one of most extraordinary moments witnessed in the Senate.\n\nSenator Hanson then asked the Attorney-General if the government would ban the burqa in the Parliament as a \"security risk\".\n\nSenate President Stephen Parry said the issue was up to him and Speaker Tony Smith, not the government.\n\nSenator Parry said he and Mr Smith always made an effort to ascertain the identity of anyone entering the chamber, and he had been able to do so when Senator Hanson walked in on Thursday.\n\nIn response to Senator Hanson's question, Senator Brandis responded: \"No.\"\n\nSenator Hanson then left the chamber, burqa in her hand, amid cries of \"shame on you\" from the opposition benches.\n\nLabor's leader in the Senate, Penny Wong, congratulated Senator Brandis for his rebuke of the One Nation leader's stunt.\n\n\"It is one thing one thing to wear religious dress as a sincere act of faith, it another wear it as a stunt here in the chamber,\" she said.\n\nGreens leader Richard Di Natale also condemned Senator Hanson's actions.\n\nLabor Senator Sam Dastyari, who identifies as a non-practising Muslim, said the stunt was \"hurtful, offensive and wrong\".\n\nSenator Hanson clashed with ASIO head Duncan Lewis during Senate Estimates earlier in the year over the burqa.\n\nMr Lewis rejected her claims that the garment was a security risk.", "id": "9665874", "details": {}, "date": {"timeCrawl": "07:50:00", "uri": "710749212", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T07:50:00Z", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "source": {"title": "International Business Times UK", "uri": "ibtimes.co.uk", "id": "713"}, "url": "http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/australia-right-wing-leader-pauline-hanson-wears-black-burqa-senate-stunt-1635382", "eventUri": "eng-3368046", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368046", "body": "Pauline Hanson's party calls for 'anti-Islamic' policies, including ban on burqa and Muslims migrants.\n\nThe leader of Australia's right-wing One Nation party entered the Senate chamber at Parliament House in Canberra wearing a black burqa, ahead of a motion on violent extremism her party would submit later in the day.\n\nThe burqa is a garment that covers the entire body with the exception of a semi-transparent cloth over the eyes. It is typically worn by Muslim women when in public.\n\nSenator Pauline Hanson attended question time dressed in the burqa and asked the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Attorney-General George Brandis, whether the government would ban the garment on grounds of national security.\n\n\"In light of our national security of this nation, will [the government] work with me to actually ban the burqa in Australia considering there have been 13 foiled national threats against us with terrorism, three that have been successful that Australians have lost their lives?\" Hanson asked, according to the Guardian Australia.\n\n\"Terrorism is a true threat to our country. Many Australians are in fear of it. What I would like to ask on behalf of the Australian people, considering there has been a large majority of Australians wish to see the banning of the burqa,\" she continued.\n\nBrandis rejected Hanson's request and condemned her behaviour. \"Senator Hanson, no, we will not be banning the burqa,\" he said, according to the Sidney Morning Herald.\n\n\"Senator Hanson, I'm not going to pretend to ignore the stunt that you have tried to pull today by arriving in the chamber dressed in burqa when we all know you are not an adherent to the Islamic faith.\"\n\nBrandis also said Hanson's behaviour was offensive towards Muslims in Australia.\n\n\"I caution you and counsel you Senator Hanson, with respect, to be very, very careful of the offence you may give to the religious sensibilities of other Australians,\" he said.\n\n\"We have about half a million Australians in this country of the Islamic faith, and the vast majority of them are law abiding, good Australians, and Senator Hanson, it is absolutely consistent with being a good law abiding Australian and a strict, adherent, Muslim.\"\n\nHis speech was met with applause by Labor and Greens senators, while Coalition senators thumped their desks. Hanson left the senate chamber shortly after.\n\nThe right-wing leader stirred criticism last year after claiming Australia was in danger of \"being swamped by Muslims\".\n\nHer party has proposed policies perceived as anti-Muslim, including bans on the burqa, on Muslim immigrants until the safety of Australia \"can be ensured\", on halal products, and the construction of more mosques in the country.\n\nIn 2014, Australia implemented a ban on the burqa and other garments covering people's face during parliament visits.\n\nThe regulation sparked outrage by the opposition and rights activists, with some claiming it would target Muslim women living in the country.\n\nFollowing the outrage, then Prime Minister Tony Abbott publicly announced he was taking into consideration a U-turn on the legislation. Source: AAP\n\n\"Senator Brandis, in light of the national security of this nation, will you work with me to ban the burqua in Australia.\n\n\"There has been 13 foiled national threats against us with terrorism, three that have been successful, and Australians have lost their lives.\n\n\"Terrorism is a true threat to our country,\" she said. \"Many Australians are very much in fear of it.\n\n\"What I would like to ask on behalf of the Australian people, considering there has been a large majority of Australians wish to see the banning of the burqa.\"\n\nAttorney-General George Brandis slammed the One Nation leader for \"the stunt\".\n\n\"I would caution and counsel you with respect to be very, very careful of the offence you may do to the religious sensibilities of other Australians,\" Senator Brandissaid.\n\n\"We have about 500,000 Australians in this country of the Islamic faith and the vast majority of them are law abiding good Australians. Senator Hanson, it is absolutely consistent with being a good, law-abiding Australian and being a strict adherent Muslim.\"\n\nSource: AAP\n\n'Can I appear in fancy dress?': Senator Hinch\n\nSenator Penny Wong congratulated the Attorney General for condemning the One Nation leader.\n\n\"I make this point on behalf of all of us on this side of the Chamber, it is one thing to wear religious dress as a sincere act of faith, there is another to wear it as a stunt here in the Chamber,\" she said.\n\nSenate President Stephen Parry said Senator Hanson's identity had been confirmed before she entered the chamber.\n\nCrossbencher Derryn Hinch questioned whether Senator Hanson could remain in the chamber.\n\nSenator Hanson caused an outcry when she wore a burqa in parliament today. Photo: AAP\n\nSenator Hanson starts to rip off the burqa before she begins to speak. Photo: AAP\n\n\"I understand that she is not a Muslim, not of Islamic faith. Can I appear tomorrow in fancy dress unchallenged?\" he asked the president.\n\nSenator Parry said he was not going to dictate the standard of dress for senators.\n\nGreens leader Richard di Natale said the chamber had \"seen the most disgraceful disrespectful shameful behaviour\".\n\n\"With a senator of this Parliament mocking a community of decent, hardworking, law-abiding citizens of this country there is no stronger example of why this Parliament needs a Parliamentary code of multicultural ethics than this,\" he said.\n\nSenator Hanson takes off the burqa before announcing her motion on banning them. Photo: AAP\n\nIndependent senator Cory Bernardi also weighed in on the stunt.\n\n\"I did warn you that proroguing the parliament was in national interest. Pauline Hanson reaches a new low,\" another user tweeted.\n\nAnother user suggested the Senator try a different type of garment next time.\n\n\"Next time maybe Pauline Hanson can wear Harry Potter's {"timeCrawl": "07:43:00", "uri": "710747546", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T07:43:00Z", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "source": {"title": "The Times of India", "uri": "timesofindia.indiatimes.com", "id": "1185"}, "url": "http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/world/rest-of-world/australian-far-right-leader-wears-burqa-to-senate-in-bid-to-ban-them/articleshow/60099588.cms", "eventUri": "eng-3368046", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368046", "body": "NEW DELHI: The debate over the burqa took a theatrical turn in the Australian Senate on Thursday, as senator Pauline Hanson donned the garment to House proceedings, before taking it off with a flourish, in a bid to get it banned in the country.\n\nHanson, leader of the far-right One Nation party, wore the burqa for 20 minutes during the Senate's daily question time session. She removed it to demand the garment be banned in public for national security reasons.\n\n\"I'm quite happy to remove this because this is not what should belong in this parliament. If a person who wears a balaclava or a helmet in to a bank or any other building, or even on the floor of the court, they must be removed. Why is it not the same case for someone who is covering up their face and cannot be identified?\" Hanson told the assembly.\n\nThe senator's action was roundly criticized, with attorney general George Brandis stating unequivocally that the government does not plan on banning the burqa. In remarks that elicited a standing ovation from bipartisan parliamentary benches, Brandis condemned Hanson's stunt and \"counselled and cautioned\" her against causing offence to religious communities.\n\nSenator Pauline Hanson takes off a burqa she wore into the Senate chamber at Parliament House in Canberra, Australia (AP photo)\n\n\"Senator Hanson, we will not be banning the burqa. We all know that you are not adherent of the Islamic faith. I would caution and counsel you with respect to be very, very careful of the offense you may do to the religious sensibilities of other Australians,\" Brandis said.\n\nLabor senator Sam Dastyari, an Iranian-born Muslim, said Hanson's behaviour was a \"disgrace\" and called her a threat to national security.\n\n\"We have seen the stunt of all stunts in this chamber by Sen Hanson,\" Dastyari jibed.\n\nThe Guardian reported that Hanson looked \"visibly delighted with the commotion caused by her\" and took Brandis's rebuke in good humour.\n\nHanson, who first rose to prominence in the 1990s because of her strident opposition to immigration from Asia and to asylum seekers, has in recent years campaigned against Islamic clothing and the building of mosques in Australia.\n\n(With inputs some Muslim women, drawing a quick rebuke from the government and Muslims.\n\nHanson sat in her seat in the assembly for about 20 minutes covered by the black burqa before removing it to call for them to be banned in public for national security reasons.\n\n\"I'm quite happy to remove this because this is not what should belong in this parliament,\" Hanson, who leads the far-right One Nation party, {"timeCrawl": "07:39:00", "uri": "710745634", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T07:39:00Z", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "source": {"title": "Dawn", "uri": "dawn.com", "id": "1853"}, "url": "https://www.dawn.com/news/1352114", "eventUri": "eng-3368046", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368046", "body": "Australian senator and leader of the right-wing One Nation party, Pauline Hanson, wore the burqa to the Senate chamber for the daily questioning time session on Thursday, The Guardian reported.\n\nAccording to the daily, Hanson's move -- meant to push for a ban on the burqa -- caused commotion in the chamber and drew strong criticism from Australian attorney general George Brandis who issued a warning that the action may be offensive to the \"religious sensibilities of other Australians\".\n\n\"Senator Hanson, I'm not going to pretend to ignore the stunt that you have tried to pull today by arriving in the chamber dressed in a burqa when we all know you are not an adherent of the Islamic faith,\" said Brandis in a video shared on The Guardian.\n\n\"To ridicule that community, to drive it into a corner, to mock its religious garments, is an appalling thing to do, and I would ask you to reflect on your behaviour.\"\n\n\"We have about half a million Australians in this country of the Islamic faith, and the vast majority of them are law abiding, good Australians, and Senator Hanson, it [burqa] is absolutely consistent with being a good law abiding Australian and a strict, adherent, Muslim,\" Brandis was quoted as saying.\n\nThe attorney general made clear to the right-wing leader that there is no intention of banning the burqa as his remarks drew applause from those present in the chamber.\n\nAccording to The Guardian, during the questioning time, Hanson asked the attorney general if the government would work to ban the burqa \"in light of [the country's] national security\".\n\nShe pointed out that there have been 13 foiled terror attacks in Australia and three in which lives have been lost.\n\n\"Terrorism is a true threat to our country,\" added Hanson, saying that she was speaking on \"behalf of the Australian people\".\n\nHanson was called a \"threat to national security\" and a \"disgrace\" by Senator Sam Dastyari who, according the The Guardian, is a non-practicing Muslim of Iranian heritage.\n\nHanson left the Senate chamber after posing her question to the attorney general.\n\nLast year, amid deteriorating race relations and an escalating fear of violence, Hanson's One Nation party called for a ban on Muslim immigration\n\nIn 2015, she defended the \"Reclaim Australia\" rallies which called for a ban on the burqa and were criticised by rival protesters as anti-Muslim.", "news.com.au", "id": "308"}, "url": "http://www.news.com.au/national/politics/george-brandis-attacks-pauline-hansons-move-to-wear-a-burqua-in-the-senate/news-story/ca26619246eb6d4e0bcdb9f2985cbdfb", "eventUri": "eng-3368046", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368046", "body": "ATTORNEY-GENERAL George Brandis launched a withering and emotional condemnation of Pauline Hanson's decision to wear a burqa to Question Time.\n\nWith his voice cracking, Senator Brandis described Ms Hanson's move to wear the Muslim garment to the Senate and then remove it as \"appalling\".\n\n\"Senator Hanson, no, we will not be banning the burqa,\" a clearly emotional Brandis said.\n\n\"I am not going to pretend to ignore the stunt that you have tried to pull today by arriving in the Chamber dressed in a burqa when we all know that you are not an adherent of the Islamic faith.\n\n\"I would caution and counsel you with respect to be very, very careful of the offence you may do to the religious sensibilities of other Australians.\"\n\n\"We have about 500,000 Australians in this country of the Islamic faith and the vast majority of them are law abiding good Australians.\n\n\"Senator Hanson, for the last four years, I have had responsibility pre-eminently among the ministers subject to the Prime Minister for national security policy.\n\nRELATED: Australia's weirdest political stunts\n\n\"And I can tell you, Senator Hanson, that it has been the advice of each Director-General of security with whom I have worked and each Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police with whom I have worked that it is vital for their intelligence and law enforcement work that they work cooperatively with the Muslim community and to ridicule that community, to drive it into a corner, to mock its religious garments is an appalling thing to do and I would ask you to reflect on that.\"\n\nThe speech received a standing ovation from opposition members of the parliament.\n\nALY: HANSON'S EYE-ROLL MOMENT\n\nCounter-terrorism expert and Labor MP Anne Aly, who was the first Muslim woman to be elected to federal parliament, said Senator Hanson's stunt would be \"just another eye-roll moment\" for most Muslim Australians.\n\n\"I think most young muslims and I think most muslims in general know Pauline Hanson, they know what her agenda is,\" Dr Aly told News Corp.\n\n\"This is probably just another eye-roll moment, although one that has reached a new level of low, and quite disgraceful to carry out such a stunt in our Parliament.\n\n\"Most Australians are already disaffected with politics and with politicians.\n\n\"This is not the way to increase that trust between individuals and groups in our society and the political institutions and the politicians that represent them.\"\n\nDr Aly said while she personally did not agree with the call to ban the burqa, the discussion could be had respectfully.\n\n\"If people want to have a conversation about it, have a conversation about it respectfully,\" she said.\n\n\"You do not need to wear a burqa in the senate and absolutely make a mockery of the parliament and a mockery of the office that you're elected into by the Australian people to make that point.\"\n\nDr Aly said a handful of women wearing a burqa in Australian society did not add to the risk of terrorism.\n\n\"If that literature exists, if that research exists, if that empirical evidence exists, I'd like to see it - but I haven't seen it anywhere,\" she said.\n\n\"It's an argument designed to make her real agenda a little bit more palatable.\n\n\"That is to ban Muslims from Australia ... basically to disenfranchise and isolate and create division between all Australians and Muslim Australians. Most Australians, who are decent people who treasure our social harmony, who treasure our multicultural society, wouldn't stand for that.\"\n\nOTHER MPS REACT TO HANSON\n\nNick Xenophon praised Senator Brandis's stance describing what Ms Hanson did as \"toxic behaviour\".\n\n\"George Brandis spoke like a true statesman,\" he said.\n\n\"He displayed the leadership and clarity of purpose the country needs on an issue like this. So good on you George.\n\n\"He has shown what it means to be a statesman when many other politicians would have shied away, he did the right thing.\"\n\nGreens Leader Richard Di Natale also labelled Ms Hanson's actions \"disgraceful\" and argument for a multicultural code of conduct for the parliament to prevent future stunts.\n\nHANSON FIGHTS BACK IN ANGER\n\nOf the stunt, Senator Hanson told radio station 2GB her One Nation colleague Brian Burston identified her to the senate security guards but said none of the guards checked to confirm her identity before she walked in.\n\n\"I put it on in my office, the media were taking photos, I walked straight down the hallway, down the stairs. I met two security guards and I walked straight up the chamber,\" she said.\n\n\"No one, no security guard at any point of time asked to see my face.\n\n\"When I walked into the chamber one of the attendants ... he just gasped.\n\nPauline Hanson's stunt today was a hurtful, offensive & dangerous display for her own ignorance. The Senate stood up to her as we should. -- Sarah Hanson-Young\u17064 (@sarahinthesen8)\n\nAugust 17, 2017\n\n\"Doesn't the Australian people have the right to know that whoever sits in the chamber, that is actually the person they voted for,\" she said.\n\n\"How do I know, that if you have someone ... in a burqa in that chamber it is that person who walks in that chamber every time?\"\n\n\"These are questions that need to be asked.\n\n\"To blatantly come out, as Senator Brandis did with a definite no, 'we're not going to ban the burqa, we're not going to have equality as far as anyone wearing full faced coverings into a bank or into the chamber, a blatant 'No' straight off without saying 'Let's discuss this' ... it was just a definite 'No'.\n\nSenator Hanson hit back at the suggestions she was mocking the Islamic faith.\n\n\"That's absolute rubbish - I'm not mocking anyone,\" she said.\n\n\"People have a right to their own faith and what they believe in, I've got no problems with that. But when that faith stops at a religion and then becomes a political ideology, that's what I have problems with.\n\n\"The burqa is not a religious requirement. It is a matter of controlling women.\"\n\nSenator Hanson said while she was walking to the chamber in the burqa, a Greens senator, Peter Whish-Wilson, shook her hand.\n\nShe described it as \"tokenism\".\n\nHanson also condemned the standing ovation from the Greens and Labor senators to Senator Brandis's response.\n\n\"It's basically saying this is the future, we're not going to stop the spreading of Islam, we're not going to stop this division happening in our society.\"\n\nSenator Hanson has described the experience of wearing the burqa as \"horrible\".\n\nShe said the idea for the stunt was her own and was designed to expose the security threats to Parliament and to call for the ban.\n\n\"It's been an idea of mine to actually expose about the burqa,\" she said.\n\n\"I'm very much against the burqa. I think it's confronting. I think it's un-Australian.\n\n\"It's hard to describe - I feel for these women who are actually forced to wear it because the pressure is put on them by their husbands and their fathers,\" she said.\n\n\"It's not a religious requirement, let's get that clear.\"\n\n\"Is it extreme? Yes. Is this getting my message across? I hope so.\"\n\n\"I hope it's creating debate. Because we have overall probably more than 55 per cent of Australians want to see the burqa banned. And I think there's no better place to start than with the Parliament.\"\n\nHANSON ATTACKED BY MORE MPS\n\nLabor frontbencher Penny Wong said the \"bigotry and divisiveness\" Senator Hanson displayed \"has no place in our society\".\n\n\"It certainly has no place in our parliament,\" she said.\n\n\"Today our parliament showed leadership when it was needed.\n\n\"It is one thing to wear religious dress as an act of faith. It is another to wear it as a stunt. That can only give offence and divide.\n\n\"Nobody needs to defend Senator Hanson's right to speak. The people that need defending are the people she attacks.\"\n\nSenator Wong said leaders have an obligation to stand up for the people in Australia, and said Senator Brandis and the Parliament had done so.\n\nLabor senator Sam Dastyari, who is fond of a stunt himself, told 2GB Senator Hanson had crossed a line.\n\nSenator Derryn Hinch said Senator Hanson's behaviour was \"disgusting\".\n\n\"Pauline Hanson mocked the religion of some Australians, she was insulting their religion,\" he told Sky News.\n\nSenator Hinch said Senator Hanson should not have been allowed into Question Time wearing the religious garment.\n\n\"It is like in court, you have to be able to see people's faces,\" he said.\n\n\"She made a mockery of an honourable place. To pull a stunt like this I find it insulting.\"\n\nSenator Hanson also praised the Attorney-General's speech and the positive reaction it received.\n\n\"He gave the best speech I have heard from him,\" he said.\n\n\"He did a very good job and it was an act of all decent members of Parliament to show the Hansonites that this doesn't work, this won't work.\"\n\nHowever Senator Hinch did concede Senator Hanson's supporters would approve of the stunt.\n\n\"People that irrationally hate all Muslims, they will be happy about this,\" he said.\n\nHanson's stunt beneath contempt. Response from Brandis is spot on. Now let's give her the attention she deserves - absolutely none. -- Bill Shorten (@billshortenmp)\n\nAugust 17, 2017\n\nVery proud to be a friend and colleague of George Brandis - a fine, appropriate and necessary statement. -- Simon Birmingham (@Birmo)\n\nAugust 17, 2017\n\nCredit where credit is due - a fine and necessary response from Senator Brandis, restoring dignity to the Senate. https://t.co/54prQyKJTk -- Mark Dreyfus (@markdreyfusQCMP)\n\nAugust 17, 2017\n\nIt's not often I agree with George Brandis. {"timeCrawl": "05:55:00", "uri": "710702796", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T05:50:00Z", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "source": {"title": "The Guardian", "uri": "theguardian.com", "id": "260"}, "url": "http://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2017/aug/17/pauline-hanson-wears-burqa-in-australian-senate-while-calling-for-ban", "eventUri": "eng-3368046", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368046", "body": "The leader of Australia's rightwing One Nation party has been rebuked by the Turnbull government for entering the Senate chamber wearing a black burqa.\n\nPauline Hanson caused a commotion by arriving at the Senate chamber for the daily question time session dressed in a black burqa, which was designed to underscore a call she intended to make to ban the religious garment, citing national security concerns.\n\nBut Hanson was rebuked sharply for her behaviour.\n\nThe leader of the government in the Senate, the attorney general George Brandis, told the One Nation leader the ruling Coalition had no intention of banning the burqa.\n\nIn remarks that secured him a standing ovation from the opposition Labor party, and the Greens party, as well as other crossbench senators, Brandis warned Hanson against indulging in behaviour that Muslim Australians would find offensive.\n\n\"Senator Hanson, no, we will not be banning the burqa,\" Brandis told the Senate on Thursday. \"Senator Hanson, I'm not going to pretend to ignore the stunt that you have tried to pull today by arriving in the chamber dressed in a burqa when we all know you are not an adherent of the Islamic faith.\n\n\"I would caution you and counsel you, Senator Hanson, with respect, to be very very careful of the offence you may do to the religious sensibilities of other Australians.\"\n\n\"We have about half a million Australians in this country of the Islamic faith, and the vast majority of them are law abiding, good Australians, and Senator Hanson, it is absolutely consistent with being a good law abiding Australian and a strict, adherent, Muslim.\"\n\nBrandis reminded Hanson that as attorney general, he held preeminent portfolio responsibility for national security, and the advice from intelligence agencies was clear - countering the risks of extremism required close cooperation with the Islamic community.\n\nThe attorney general, who was clearly infuriated by Hanson's behaviour, rebuked her sharply for causing offence to a faith community. \"To ridicule that community, to drive it into a corner, to mock its religious garments, is an appalling thing to do, and I would ask you to reflect on your behaviour.\"\n\nHanson smiled throughout Brandis' answer, and visibly delighted with the commotion caused by her intervention, left the Senate chamber shortly after her designated question.\n\nThe Brandis rebuke prompted Labor, Greens and some crossbenchers to stand and applaud. Some but not all government MPs also applauded but kept their seats.\n\nThe leader of the opposition in the Senate, the Labor senator Penny Wong, said if the standing orders permitted, she would have issued a vote of thanks to Brandis for his remarks.\n\nWong, also clearly infuriated, told Hanson: \"It is one thing to wear religious dress as a sincere act of faith and another to wear it here as a stunt in the Senate chamber.\"\n\nHanson's call for the banning of the burqa prompted disorderly interjections from across the chamber.\n\nThe One Nation leader's question was posed to Brandis along the following lines: \"In light of our national security of this nation, will [the government] work with me to actually ban the burqa in Australia considering there have been 13 foiled national threats against us with terrorism, three that have been successful that Australians have lost their lives?\n\n\"Terrorism is a true threat to our country. Many Australians are in fear of it. What I would like to ask on behalf of the Australian people, considering there has been a large majority of Australians wish to see the banning of the burqa.\"\n\nThe Labor senator Sam Dastyari, who is of Iranian heritage, and a non-practising Muslim, shouted that Hanson was a threat to national security, and a \"disgrace\".\n\nAnother Labor MP interjected that Hanson would next enter the chamber wearing a white hood - a reference to white supremacist groups.\n\nHanson later took to Facebook to double down on her behaviour in the parliament.\n\nHanson's One Nation party proposes anti-Islamic policies including a ban on Muslim immigration, and a royal commission into Islam. {"timeCrawl": "08:10:00", "uri": "710758541", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T08:10:00Z", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "source": {"title": "Stock & Land", "uri": "stockandland.com.au", "id": "13129"}, "url": "http://www.stockandland.com.au/story/4863532/hanson-burqa-stunt-ignites-firestorm-over-religious-freedoms/", "eventUri": "eng-3368046", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368046", "body": "One Nation leader Pauline Hanson has triggered a firestorm around religious freedoms after wearing a burqa into Parliament.\n\nOne Nation leader Pauline Hanson has triggered a firestorm around religious freedoms, after wearing a burqa into Parliament, a stunt that has united all sides of politics in condemnation.\n\nThe Queensland senator, accompanied by colleague Brian Burston, entered the Senate dressed in a black Islamic dress shortly after question time began on Thursday afternoon - her senator pin still on display.\n\nAs senators could be heard groaning and gasping at her entrance, Senate President Stephen Parry confirmed it was Senator Hanson beneath the face covering, while seeming unsure of how to officially respond to the performance.\n\nAttorney-General George Brandis showed no hesitation.\n\nWhen Senator Hanson whipped off the garment with a dramatic flourish, exclaiming how glad she was to be free of it, and asked Senator Brandis if the government would join her in banning the burqa, he did not hold back.\n\n\"Senator Hanson, no, we will not be banning the burqa,\" he said, visibly angry, and looking at one point like he was close to tears.\n\n\"I am not going to pretend to ignore the stunt that you have tried to pull today by arriving in the chamber dressed in a burqa when we all know that you are not an adherent of the Islamic faith.\n\n\"I would caution and counsel you with respect to be very, very careful of the offence you may do to the religious sensibilities of other Australians.\"\n\n\"We have about 500,000 Australians in this country of the Islamic faith and the vast majority of them are law-abiding good Australians.\n\n\"Senator Hanson, for the last four years, I have had responsibility pre-eminently among the ministers subject to the Prime Minister for national security policy.\n\n\"And I can tell you, Senator Hanson, that it has been the advice of each director-general of security with whom I have worked and each commissioner of the Australian Federal Police with whom I have worked that it is vital for their intelligence and law enforcement work that they work co-operatively with the Muslim community, and to ridicule that community, to drive it into a corner, to mock its religious garments is an appalling thing to do.\n\n\"I would ask you to reflect on that.\"\n\nIn extraordinary scenes, Labor and Greens senators burst into spontaneous applause, before getting to their feet in enthusiastic praise, while his Coalition colleagues remained seated.\n\nSenator Hanson and Senator Burston left the chamber shortly after, to calls of \"good on you, George\" from the opposing side.\n\nBut she had made her point, reigniting a debate that flamed in 2014 when then-prime minister Tony Abbott was forced to reverse a decision by Speaker Bronwyn Bishop and Senator Parry to isolate women wearing a burqa or niqab in glass enclosures away from the public galleries.\n\nASIO head Duncan Lewis rebuked Senator Hanson earlier this year after she asked whether a terrorist threat was \"being brought in\" with Middle Eastern refugees.\n\n\"We've made it plain on a number of occasions, senator, that we have no security reason to be concerned about the wearing of a burqa other than the requirement for individuals to identify themselves to authorities, and there are regulations in place for that,\" Mr Lewis said in May.\n\nHe stood by his assessment despite criticism from One Nation and conservative members of the Coalition in the following days.\n\nBut while politicians from across the political divide united in their praise of Senator Brandis for his swift and unwavering condemnation of her actions, Senator Hanson - whose party was recently named by the Trump administration as a threat to religious freedoms - was relishing having \"started the debate\". \"???It was a horrible feeling, I felt just cut off from the rest of the world,\" she told Radio 2GB.\n\n\"Here I am, no one can see my facial features, no one can see if I have given them a smile, or look at my eyes, or my reaction to them - isn't that a part of our society, that we have to interact with people?\n\n\"???It is foreign to us. This is not our way of life. And so many in the suburbs of Sydney, if you are honest about it, if you are not a Muslim, you really don't want to go to these places because you don't feel welcome there.\"\n\nIslamic Friendship Association of Australia spokesman Keysar Trad predicted some \"women who wear the burqa will feel hurt and will feel that they are under siege again\" by the Senator's actions.\n\n\"Why isn't Pauline Hanson supporting their right to dress as they choose?\"\n\nIslamic Council of Victoria vice-president Adel Salman said the stunt was offensive, and \"doesn't really help the debate\".\n\n\"The current discourse is really negative. It's about time [Senator Hanson] is ridiculed and her platform is ridiculed,\" he said.\n\nBoth Mr Trad and Mr Salman praised Senator Brandis' strong response.\n\nLabor, Greens and other crossbench senators, including Derryn Hinch and Nick Xenophon, called for Senator Hanson's stunt to be ignored.\n\nUndeterred, Senator Hanson took to the Senate floor later that same day to deliver a speech calling for the burqa ban and claiming Islam was \"threatening our way of life\", speaking to an almost empty room.\n\nFollow us on Facebook\n\nThe story Hanson burqa stunt ignites firestorm over religious freedoms first appeared on The Sydney Morning Herald.\n\nShareTweetAa", "id": "9639274", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-17", "title": "Hanson burqa stunt ignites firestorm over religious One Nation has a policy of banning the burqa in all government buildings, including parliament, but that doesn't really explain why Hanson herself would put one on in the Senate chamber.\n\nBut when Hanson stood up to ask a question, all was revealed. It turns out she was wearing a burqa in parliament in some kind of bizarre protest against wearing the burqa in parliament.\n\nIn a media release sent out by her office Hanson said she was \"dressed modestly in a full burqa\" because \"she believed the need to ban full-face coverings in public was an important issue facing modern Australia that needed to be discussed\". She went on to describe full-face coverings as a \"security threat\".\n\nIf she was trying to demonstrate that \"security threat\" with her stunt, it backfired pretty heavily. The Senate President, Stephen Parry, said that because Hanson had established her identity in the chamber, prior to donning the burqa, there was no security threat and she was able to take part in the parliamentary proceedings.\n\nHanson's question about banning the burqa was directed at the attorney-general, George Brandis. Brandis responding by declaring Hanson's actions a \"stunt\".\n\n\"I would caution and counsel you to be very, very careful of the offence you may do to the religious sensibilities of other Australians,\" Brandis said. \"It is absolutely consistent being a good, law abiding Australian, and being a strict, adherent Muslim.\"\n\nBrandis' response drew spontaneous applause from the entire Senate, including Labor and Greens politicians.\n\nPauline Hanson is vile. I am not embarrassed by what I did. I have created debate, it needed to be done,\" she told Sunrise on Friday in the wake of her stunt.\n\nSenator Hanson was slammed for \"the stunt\". {"timeCrawl": "19:53:00", "uri": "711084726", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T16:02:00Z", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "source": {"title": "Standard Republic", "uri": "standardrepublic.com", "id": "18909"}, "url": "http://www.standardrepublic.com/2017/08/australian-senator-wears-burqa-in-parliament-to-push-for-national-ban-of-face-coverings/26052.htm", "eventUri": "eng-3368046", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368046", "body": "An Australian senator provoked an angry backlash from fellow lawmakers Thursday by wearing a burqa in Parliament as part of her campaign for a national ban on Islamic face coverings.\n\nPauline Hanson, leader of the anti-Muslim, anti-immigration One Nation minority party, sat wearing the black head-to-ankle garment for more than 10 minutes before taking it off as she rose to explain her reasoning for a ban on such outfits on national security grounds.\n\nHanson said she wore the garment to highlight the fact she believes \"it does not belong\" in Parliament, Sky News Australia reported.\n\n\"I'm quite happy to remove this because this is not what should belong in this Parliament,\" she said.\n\nHanson, an outspoken fan of President Trump, added \"There has been a large majority of Australians [who] wish to see the banning of the burqa.\"\n\nAttorney General George Brandis drew a standing ovation from the chamber when he said his government would not ban the burqa, and he chastised Hanson for what he described as a \"stunt\" that offended Australia's Muslim minority.\n\n\"To ridicule that community, to drive it into a corner, to mock its religious garments is an appalling thing to do and I would ask you to reflect on what you have done,\" Brandis said.\n\nOpposition Senate leader Penny Wong told Hanson: \"It is one thing to wear religious dress as a sincere act of faith; it is another to wear it as a stunt here in the Senate.\"\n\nLabor MP Anne Aly also voiced her criticisms of the One Nation senator to Sky News Australia, calling the action \"a mockery of our Parliament.\"\n\n\"All this was a stunt designed to get attention for Pauline Hanson because that's all she wants,\" Aly said.\n\nSam Dastyari, an opposition senator and an Iranian-born Muslim, said: \"We have seen the stunt of all stunts in this chamber by Sen. Hanson.\"\n\nHe added: \"The close to 500,000 Muslim Australians do not deserve to be targeted, do not deserve to be marginalized, do not deserve to be ridiculed, do not deserve to have their faith made some political point by the desperate leader of a desperate political party.\"\n\nSenate President Stephen Parry said Hanson's identity had been confirmed before she entered the chamber. {"timeCrawl": "14:05:00", "uri": "710922597", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T08:14:00Z", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "source": {"title": "The Conversation", "uri": "theconversation.com", "id": "574"}, "url": "http://theconversation.com/unrepentant-hanson-hopes-burqa-stunt-will-create-debate-82652", "eventUri": "eng-3368046", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368046", "body": "Republish our articles for free, online or in print, under Creative Commons licence.\n\nPauline Hanson's stunt of wearing a burqa into the Senate on Thursday drew a swingeing attack from Attorney-General George Brandis, amid widespread condemnation.\n\nBut an unrepentant Hanson - who admitted her action, which she's been considering for months, was \"extreme\" - told 2GB she hoped it was \"creating debate\".\n\nBrandis' denunciation, delivered with emotion, was greeted with a standing ovation from Labor and the Greens, and more limited and hesitant clapping on his own side.\n\nEducation Minister Simon Birmingham tweeted:\n\nSenators were shocked when Hanson - who has called for a ban on Muslim immigration - appeared in the chamber shrouded in the voluminous black garment. She removed it as she rose to ask Brandis whether he would work to ban the burqa, citing foiled and actual terrorist incidents. \"There has been a large majority of Australians [who] wish to see the banning of the burqa,\" she said.\n\n\"Senator Hanson, no, we will not be banning the burqa,\" Brandis said. He said he was not going to pretend to ignore her stunt - and warned of the damage such behaviour could do.\n\n\"I would caution you and counsel you, senator Hanson, with respect, to be very, very careful of the offence you may do to the religious sensibilities of other Australians.\n\n\"We have about half-a-million Australians in this country of the Islamic faith, and the vast majority of them are law-abiding, good Australians. Senator Hanson, it is absolutely consistent being a good, law-abiding Australian and being a strict-adherent Muslim.\"\n\nHe said the advice of each director-general of security and each commissioner of the Australian Federal Police with whom he had worked was \"that it is vital for their intelligence and law enforcement work that they work co-operatively with the Muslim community.\n\n\"To ridicule that community, to drive it into a corner, to mock its religious garments is an appalling thing to do, and I would ask you to reflect on what you have done.\"\n\nHanson then asked whether the government would \"ban the burqa in this house ... as a security risk\" and \"also, the fact is the people of Australia have the right to see the face of a person that they elect to this parliament\".\n\nSenate President Stephen Parry said this came within the purview of parliament's presiding officers, not the attorney-general.\n\n\"The Speaker and I have made arrangements that anyone who enters these premises with their face covered by whatever means is clearly identified prior to entering the building.\" He said he had ascertained when she entered who she was.\n\nShadow Attorney-General Mark Dreyfus tweeted praise for Brandis:\n\nLater Hanson moved a motion calling on \"the government to ban full face coverings in public places on the grounds of social cohesion, the need to identify people seeking community support and for public safety\". It was defeated on the voices.\n\n\"Muslims determine the electoral outcomes in up to 15 lower house seats,\" she told the Senate in her speech on the motion.\n\n\"The Muslim vote will continue to increase in importance because of the high birth rates in Australian Muslim communities. The number of Muslims in Australia doubled in the decade from 2006 to 2016 through immigration and high numbers of children born to Muslim families.\n\n\"If we do not draw a line in the sand against immigration from Islamic countries the influence of Muslims in this country will continue to grow and Australia will continue down the path of Islamisation.\"\n\nShe told 2GB that just outside the Senate chamber she had passed Greens senator Peter Whish-Wilson. \"He actually put out his hand to shake my hand. Now I shook it. He has never done that to me as Pauline Hanson. He did it to shake hands with a person completely covered up. It was a tokenism that he was shaking the hand of Islam.\"\n\nCrossbencher Jacqui Lambie said Hanson had diminished the chamber and was dividing the nation.\n\nAnne Aly, a member of the House of Representatives, said Hanson had made a mockery of the parliament and her behaviour needed to be called out.\n\nCrossbench senator Nick Xenophon said her action was offensive, \"demeaning to people of other faiths\".\n\n\"I wouldn't even call this a stunt, this was just toxic,\" Xenophon said.\n\nAustralian Conservatives' Cory Bernard, who supports a ban on the burqa, said it had been \"a shock when Pauline Hanson walked past me in the flag of fundamentalism\".\n\n\"She made a particularly blunt point, but I'm not sure it is a point that should be made in the Senate chamber. I'm just as concerned about the dignity of our parliamentary system as I am about preserving our culture, and I don't like stunts of this nature to take place in our Parliament,\" Bernardi said.", {"timeCrawl": "10:41:00", "uri": "710826756", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T03:21:00Z", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "source": {"title": "Huffington Post Australia", "uri": "huffingtonpost.com.au", "id": "3857"}, "url": "http://www.huffingtonpost.com.au/2017/08/17/pauline-hanson-wears-a-burqa-into-the-senate_a_23080008/", "eventUri": "eng-3368046", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368046", "body": "CANBERRA -- Attorney-General George Brandis has been applauded after delivering a stinging, fiery response to an appalling stunt by One Nation senator Pauline Hanson, who mockingly wore an Islamic burqa into the Senate.\n\nFederal Parliament further descended into high farce on Thursday as Hanson entered the chamber wearing a black burqa covering her face and head. In a stunt to draw attention to her push to ban the face covering, Hanson entered the Senate wearing the shroud, leaving her Senate colleagues shocked and open-mouthed during Question Time.\n\nEmployment minister Michaelia Cash had risen to her feet to answer a question but re-took her seat seemingly in shock as other members of the chamber turned to watch Hanson take her seat.\n\n\"What on earth?\" one senator was heard to say, as gasps and groans rang around the room.\n\nhere's video of Hanson entering the Senate, in a full black face covering - \"what on earth?\" says one senator pic.twitter.com/HyBSITxYrU -- Josh Butler (@JoshButler)\n\nAugust 17, 2017\n\nHanson sat quietly, wearing the burqa, but eventually removed it. She then rose to ask Brandis a question about Muslim face coverings and security, and was met by a quietly seething response.\n\n\"I'm not going to pretend to ignore the stunt you tried to pull today,\" Brandis said.\n\n\"We all know you are not an adherent to the Islamic faith. I caution and counsel you, with respect, to be very careful of the offence you may do to the religious sensibilities of other Australians.\"\n\n\"We have about half a million Australians in this country of the Islamic faith, and the vast majority are good, law-abiding Australians,\" Brandis said.\n\n\"To ridicule that community, to drive it into a corner, to mock its religious garments is an appalling thing to do. And I would ask you to reflect what you have done.\"\n\nUpon Hanson's arrival, Senate president Stephen Parry told the chamber that a clerk had verified Hanson's identity before she entered. Senator Derryn Hinch asked whether it was appropriate for the One Nation leader to appear in such attire.\n\n\"I'd like to know, if Senator Hanson can stay here unchallenged, she's not a Muslim or of Islamic faith, can I appear here in fancy dress unchallenged?\" Hinch asked.\n\n\"My rulings have always been that I'm not going to dictate the standard of dress for senators in this chamber,\" Parry replied.\n\n\"I'm going to reflect on the situation we have before us. I don't want to make a decision or a rash statement about that at the moment.\"\n\nHanson had earlier given notice that she wanted to debate a burqa ban in the Senate on Thursday afternoon.\n\nFollowing the end of Question Time, conservative senator Cory Bernardi said while he agreed with One Nation's stance on banning head coverings, he didn't agree with Hanson's \"blunt\" stunt.\n\n\"I happen to agree the burqa has no place in Australia... so I accept the point but I really do think it diminished the status of the parliament,\" Bernardi told 2GB radio.\n\n\"I don't agree with stunts by politicians. I actually care about the standards of the parliament.\"", "id": "9665809", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-17", "title": "Pauline Hanson Wears A Burqa Into The Senate", "image": "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368046", "body": "CANBERRA - Australian senator and leader of the right-wing One Nation party, Pauline Hanson, wore a burqa to the Senate chamber on Thursday in a bid to push for the burqa ban, on the grounds that wearing a burqa concealed the wearer's identity and was therefore a security risk.\n\nThe incident provoked the ire of the lawmakers with the Attorney General formally issuing a warning that the action may be offensive to the \"religious sensibilities of other Australians\".\n\n\"Senator Hanson, I'm not going to pretend to ignore the stunt that you have tried to pull today by arriving in the chamber dressed in a burqa when we all know you are not an adherent of the Islamic faith,\" said Brandis in a video\n\nThe AG asked the legislator to reflect on her behavior as mocking religious garment was an \"appalling\" thing.\n\n\"We have about half a million Australians in this country of the Islamic faith, and the vast majority of them are law abiding, good Australians, and Senator Hanson, it [burqa] is absolutely consistent with being a good law abiding Australian and a strict, adherent, Muslim,\" Brandis was quoted as saying.\n\nFor his remarks, Mr Brandis received a standing applause from opposition parties as well.\n\nEarlier, during the questioning time, Hanson asked the attorney general if the government would work to ban the burqa \"in light of [the country's] national security\".\n\nShe pointed out that there have been 13 foiled terror attacks in Australia and three in which lives have been lost.\n\n\"Terrorism is a true threat to our country,\" added Hanson, saying that she was speaking on \"behalf of the Australian people\".\n\nHowever, Brandis made it clear that Australia would not ban the burqa but Hanson's motion to ban the garment will be debated in the Senate later today.\n\nHanson and her party are traditionally known for their Islamophobic tilt of politics.\n\nLast year, amid deteriorating race relations and an escalating fear of violence, Hanson's One Nation party called for a ban on Muslim immigration.\n\nIn 2015, she defended the 'Reclaim Australia' rallies which called for a ban on the burqa and were criticized by rival protesters as anti-Muslim.\n\nAccording to latest census figures, the Muslim population in Australia has soared to 604,000 people. 'don't want to stand up to the facts' and shut her down instead\n\nPauline Hanson says her critics are ignoring the Australian people's wishes by refusing to ban the burqa.\n\nThe One Nation leader was slammed on Thursday for wearing the Islamic garment on the Senate floor, claiming it had 'no place' in Australian society.\n\nAttorney-General George Brandis tore into the stunt in an impassioned speech that received a rare standing ovation from Labor and Greens colleagues.\n\nBut the right-wing firebrand hit back the next morning, accusing her many critics of being out of touch with voters concerned about Islam in Australia.\n\nPauline Hanson says her critics are ignoring the Australian people's wishes by refusing to ban the burqa\n\nThe One Nation leader was widely condemned on Thursday for wearing the Islamic garment on the Senate floor, claiming it had 'no place' in Australian society\n\n'For George Brandis and everyone in that Parliament to shut me down is not answering the Australian people,' she said on the Today show on Friday.\n\n'They've been ignored, people like George Brandis and the Labor Party and Derryn Hinch that stood up and applauded his comments are not really understanding how the Australian people feel and think.'\n\nSenator Hanson said her critics were trying to 'shut down' people with her views because they 'don't want to stand up to the facts'.\n\n'The people will have their say at the ballot box,' she said, after a poll of Today viewers showed 59 per cent of respondents agreed with her stunt.\n\nThe 63-year-old said wearing a burqa was not a religious requirement and claimed many Muslim wore it to impose their ideology on Australians.\n\nVoice quavering, the Attorney-General said it was 'appalling' for Senator Hanson to 'drive (Muslims) into a corner'\n\nSurprise ovation: Senators from the Greens and Labor joined a standing ovation for George Brandis's spontaneous speech\n\n'I think a lot of these people wear it just for the fact of saying we are going to do what we want to do in your country, we are going to use your country, we are going to use your laws to further our political agenda, our ideology,' she said.\n\n'Let's look at what is right for this country. Where do we want to go? Is it national security? Do we want social cohesion? Let the people have their say.'\n\nThe anti-immigration campaigner said she did not oppose the Islamic religion, just the 'political ideology' that came along with it.\n\n'I have no problems with religion, I have a problem with the political ideology that is incompatible with our culture and way of life and are shutting down a lot of things that we are dear to our hearts as Australians,' she said.\n\nSenator Hanson said Parliament House was getting a $16 million upgrade because 'we're in fear of a threat', but voters did not get the same protection.\n\n'It's alright for us parliamentarians are protected in many ways for having security guards. What about the people on our streets, what about the terrorist attacks that are happening,' she said.\n\nSenator Hanson rips off the burqa (left and right) after labelling it a threat to national security\n\nHer comments followed a stinging rebuke from Senator Brandis immediately following her demand for the chamber to support a burqa ban.\n\n'I am not going to pretend to ignore the stunt that you have tried to pull today by arriving in the Chamber dressed in a burqa,' the Liberal Senate leader said.\n\n'We all know that you are not an adherent of the Islamic faith.'\n\nThe minister continued: 'We have about 500,000 Australians in this country of the Islamic faith. Can I appear tomorrow in fancy dress unchallenged?' he asked the Senate president.\n\nSenator Hanson sat in the chamber with the burqa for some time before dramatically ripping it off to as her colleague if they would support banning it.\n\n'There have been 13 foiled national threats against us with terrorism, three that have been successful and Australians have lost their lives,' she said.\n\n'Terrorism is a true threat to our country. {"timeCrawl": "14:51:00", "uri": "710945173", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T14:51:00Z", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "source": {"title": "Tribune", "uri": "tribuneonlineng.com", "id": "19298"}, "url": "http://www.tribuneonlineng.com/far-right-australian-senator-slammed-burqa-stunt/", "eventUri": "eng-3368046", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368046", "body": "AN Australian senator known for her strong stance against Muslim immigration has been widely condemned for wearing a burqa to Parliament House.\n\nIn video of the parliamentary session, One Nation leader Pauline Hanson can be seen taking her seat in the floor-length Islamic garment. A voice on the recording can be heard saying, \"What on Earth?\"\n\nHanson has long called for the burqa to be banned in public, saying the central issue is the \"right of others to see a face.\"\n\nAmid unrest from her fellow senators, Hanson dramatically took off the veil, saying \"I'm quite happy to remove this because it's not what should belong in this parliament.\"\n\nHanson then asked Attorney General George Brandis, if \"in light of what is happening with national security... will you work to ban the burqa?\"\n\nBrandis, a member of the governing Liberal National coalition, received a standing ovation when, close to tears, he tore into Hanson for mocking the Muslim dress.\n\n\"Senator Hanson, no, we will not be banning the burqa.\"\n\n\"Senator Hanson, I'm not going to pretend to ignore the stunt that you have tried to pull today by arriving in the chamber dressed in a burqa, when we all know you are not an adherent of the Islamic faith.\"\n\nHe told Hanson to be \"very, very careful\" of offending the \"religious sensibilities of other Australians.\"\n\n\"To ridicule that community, to drive it into a corner, to mock its religious garments is an appalling thing to do,\" he said.\n\nIn a speech to Parliament, Hanson referred to terror threats as one reason for her proposed ban.\n\nAustralia's terrorism threat level is currently listed as \"probable,\" on a four level scale between \"possible\" and \"expected.\"\n\nLast month, Australian authorities thwarted alleged twin terror plots described as the \"most sophisticated\" ever planned on Australian soil. They included plans to release a toxic gas in public.\n\nSince Australia's national terrorism threat level was last raised in September 2014, there have been five attacks and 13 \"major counter terrorism disruptions,\" according to a representative for the Australian Security Intelligence Organization.\n\nIn her speech, Hanson cited an attack on the Iranian parliament building in June, by men believed to be dressed in burqas, as being one example of the security threat.\n\n\"This is not the first case of this kind and it will not be the last,\" she said.", "id": "9714060", "details": {"timeCrawl": "15:22:00", "uri": "710960061", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T15:22:00Z", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "source": {"title": "alaraby", "uri": "alaraby.co.uk", "id": "6819"}, "url": "https://www.alaraby.co.uk/english/news/2017/8/17/anti-immigration-australian-senator-paulinehanson-wears-full-burqa-in-parliament", "eventUri": "eng-3368046", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368046", "body": "The far-right One Nation leader wore a burqa into the Australian Senate chamber on Thursday to call for its ban, earning blistering rebuke for the \"appalling\" stunt. Australian anti-immigration politician Pauline Hanson caused a furore on Thursday when she entered the Senate wearing a full burqa, earning a blistering rebuke from the country's top lawyer for the \"appalling\" stunt.\n\nHanson wore the Islamic garment in the chamber to highlight what she said were the security issues it posed, linking it to terrorism as fellow senators heckled her.\n\n\"Will you work to ban the burqa in Australia in light of what is happening with national security?\" she said after whipping off the garment to question Attorney-General George Brandis.\n\nShe added: \"Terrorism is a true threat to our country, many Australians are in fear of it.\"\n\nBrandis said his conservative government had no such plans, warning Hanson she risked offending the Muslim community by wearing a burqa when she was not a follower of Islam.\n\n\"To ridicule that community, to drive it into a corner, to mock its religious garments is an appalling thing to do, and I would ask you to reflect on what you have done,\" he said.\n\nBrandis, his voice cracking with emotion, also said that being a strict adherent Muslim, such as those who wear the burka, was \"absolutely consistent\" with being a law-abiding citizen.\n\n\"We have about half a million Australians in this country of the Islamic faith and the vast majority of them are law-abiding, good Australians,\" he said.\n\nBrandis' remarks prompted a standing ovation from his political opponents in the Labour and Green parties.\n\nHanson wore the Islamic garment in the chamber to highlight what she said were the security issues it posed [AAP]\n\nIndependent senator Derryn Hinch labelled Hanson's conduct \"disgusting\".\n\n\"Pauline Hanson mocked the religion of some Australians... she made a mockery of an honourable place (the Senate),\" he told Sky News.\n\nLabour senator Sam Dastyari accused Hanson of stoking extremism in a poorly timed bid for \"a cheap headline\".\n\n\"In the same week that we saw white nationalism rear its ugly head in the country of our closest ally - in that week a stunt like this gets pulled in the Australian Senate,\" he said.\n\n\"It is hurtful, it is offensive, it is wrong.\"\n\nHanson first gained prominence in the 1990s, when she warned Australia was in danger of being \"swamped by Asians\".\n\nAfter a 12-year hiatus from politics she returned in 2014, this time targeting Muslims and was elected to the Senate two years later as leader of the right-wing One Nation party.\n\nIn her first speech after returning to parliament, she said Islam was \"a culture and ideology that is incompatible with our own\".\n\nHanson was unrepentant after her latest stunt, telling commercial radio: \"Is it extreme? Yes. Is it getting my message across? It really happened\n\nWhen Senator Hanson whipped off the garment with a dramatic flourish, exclaiming how glad she was to be free of it, and asked Senator Brandis if the government would join her in banning the burqa, he did not hold back.\n\n\"Senator Hanson, no, we will not be banning the burqa,\" he said, visibly angry, and looking at one point like he was close to tears.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"I am not going to pretend to ignore the stunt that you have tried to pull today by arriving in the chamber dressed in a burqa when we all know that you are not an adherent of the Islamic faith.\n\nYou will now receive updates from Breaking News Alert Breaking News Alert\n\nGet the latest news and updates emailed straight to your inbox.\n\nBy submitting your email you are agreeing to Fairfax Media's terms and conditions and privacy policy .\n\n\"I would caution and counsel you with respect to be very, very careful of the offence you may do to the religious sensibilities of other Australians.\"\n\n\"We have about 500,000 Australians in this country of the Islamic faith and the vast majority of them are law-abiding good Australians.\n\n\"Senator Hanson, for the last four years, I have had responsibility pre-eminently among the ministers subject to the Prime Minister for national security policy.\n\n\"And I can tell you, Senator Hanson, that it has been the advice of each director-general of security with whom I have worked and each commissioner of the Australian Federal Police with whom I have worked that it is vital for their intelligence and law enforcement work that they work co-operatively with the Muslim community, and to ridicule that community, to drive it into a corner, to mock its religious garments is an appalling thing to do.\n\n\"I would ask you to reflect on that.\"\n\nIn extraordinary scenes, Labor and Greens senators burst into spontaneous applause, before getting to their feet in enthusiastic praise, while his Coalition colleagues remained seated.\n\nSenator Hanson and Senator Burston left the chamber shortly after, to calls of \"good on you, George\" from the opposing side.\n\nBut she had made her point, reigniting a debate that flamed in 2014 when then-prime minister Tony Abbott was forced to reverse a decision by Speaker Bronwyn Bishop and Senator Parry to isolate women wearing a burqa or niqab in glass enclosures away from the public galleries.\n\nASIO head Duncan Lewis rebuked Senator Hanson earlier this year after she asked whether a terrorist threat was \"being brought in\" with Middle Eastern refugees.\n\n\"We've made it plain on a number of occasions, senator, that we have no security reason to be concerned about the wearing of a burqa other than the requirement for individuals to identify themselves to authorities, and there are regulations in place for that,\" Mr Lewis said in May.\n\nHe stood by his assessment despite criticism from One Nation and conservative members of the Coalition in the following days.\n\nBut while politicians from across the political divide united in their praise of Senator Brandis for his swift and unwavering condemnation of her actions, Senator Hanson - whose party was recently named by the Trump administration as a threat to religious freedoms - was relishing having \"started the debate\". \"...It was a horrible feeling, I felt just cut off from the rest of the world,\" she told Radio 2GB.\n\n\"Here I am, no one can see my facial features, no one can see if I have given them a smile, or look at my eyes, or my reaction to them - isn't that a part of our society, that we have to interact with people?\n\n\"...It is foreign to us. This is not our way of life. And so many in the suburbs of Sydney, if you are honest about it, if you are not a Muslim, you really don't want to go to these places because you don't feel welcome there.\"\n\nIslamic Friendship Association of Australia spokesman Keysar Trad predicted some \"women who wear the burqa will feel hurt and will feel that they are under siege again\" by the Senator's actions.\n\n\"Why isn't Pauline Hanson supporting their right to dress as they choose?\"\n\nIslamic Council of Victoria vice-president Adel Salman said the stunt was offensive, and \"doesn't really help the debate\".\n\n\"The current discourse is really negative. It's about time [Senator Hanson] is ridiculed and her platform is ridiculed,\" he said.\n\nBoth Mr Trad and Mr Salman praised Senator Brandis' strong response.\n\nLabor, Greens and other crossbench senators, including Derryn Hinch and Nick Xenophon, called for Senator Hanson's stunt to be ignored.\n\nUndeterred, Senator Hanson took to the Senate floor later that same day to deliver a speech calling for the burqa ban and claiming Islam was \"threatening our way of life\", speaking to an almost empty room.\n\nFollow us on Facebook", "id": "9640931", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-17",
