{"timeCrawl": "08:17:00", "uri": "710761570", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T03:26:00Z", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "source": {"title": "The West Australian", "uri": "thewest.com.au", "id": "18866"}, "url": "https://thewest.com.au/politics/federal-politics/pauline-hanson-wears-a-burqa-into-the-senate-ng-b88571343z", "eventUri": "eng-3368046", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368046", "body": "Pauline Hanson has sat through Senate Question Time wearing a burqa.\n\nIn an \"appalling\" stunt ahead of moving a motion about violent extremism she will put to the Senate about 4.30pm, the One Nation Leader asked Attorney-General George Brandis if the Government would ban full face coverings in public.\n\n\"In light of the national security of this nation, will you work to ban the burqa in Australia,\" she asked.\n\nSenator Brandis replied: \"No\".\n\nAfter using a supplementary question to argue the burqa poses a national security risk, Senator Hanson left with the religious garment in her hand.\n\nMr Brandis received a rare standing ovation from Labor and the Greens after he condemned Senator Hanson's \"ridiculing\" of the Muslim community.\n\n\"To ridicule that community to drive them into a corner, and to mock its religious garments, is an appalling thing to do and I would ask you to reflect on what you've done,\" Senator Brandis told the Senate.\n\n\"I caution you and council you, Senator Hanson, with respect, to be very, very careful of the offence you may cause to the religious sensibilities of other Australians of the Islamic faith.\n\n\"And the vast majority of them are good, law-abiding Australians.\"\n\nSenate President Stephen Parry said Senator Hanson's identity had been confirmed before she entered the chamber.\n\nSenator Derryn Hinch asked Senator Parry whether he could come into the chamber wearing fancy dress, given Senator Hanson is not a Muslim.\n\n\"I understand that she is not a Muslim, not of Islamic faith. Can I appear tomorrow in fancy dress unchallenged,\" he asked the president.\n\nSenator Parry said he was not going to dictate the standard of dress for senators.\n\nOpposition Leader in the Senate Penny Wong described the act as a \"stunt\".\n\n\"It is one thing to wear religious dress as a sincere act of faith, it is another to wear it as a stunt here in the Senate chamber,\" Senator Wong said.\n\nIndependent senator Cory Bernardi also weighed in on the stunt.\n\n\"I did warn you that proroguing the Parliament was in national interest. Things are getting seriously weirder by the day,\" he posted to Twitter.\n\nA statement released by One Nation said Senator Hanson wore the garment \"because she believed the need to ban full-face coverings in public was an important issue facing modern Australia that needed to be discussed\".\n\nThe statement said Senator Hanson believed full-face coverings were not only security threats at Parliament House but also in the wider community and Australia could hide from a difficult conversation out of fear of causing offence.\n\nSenator Hanson will move a motion in Parliament later today calling on the Federal Government to ban the burqa.\n\nIt came just hours after Senator Hanson has met with prominent Australian businessman Dick Smith to discuss immigration policy.\n\nShe tweeted a film clip of her meeting with Mr Smith, who recently launched a \"grim reaper\" anti-immigration ad campaign to argue Australia's annual intake should be capped at 70,000.\n\n\"Every Australian family doesn't have 20 kids. They have the number of kids they can give a good life too. {"timeCrawl": "07:31:00", "uri": "710742289", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T07:31:00Z", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "source": {"title": "The Business Times", "uri": "businesstimes.com.sg", "id": "10474"}, "url": "http://www.businesstimes.com.sg/government-economy/australias-hanson-wears-burqa-to-parliament-in-bid-to-ban-them", "eventUri": "eng-3368046", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368046", "body": "[CANBERRA] Australian far-right senator Pauline Hanson wore a burqa to parliament on Thursday as part of her campaign to ban the all-enveloping garment worn by some Muslim women, drawing a quick rebuke from the government and Muslims.\n\nMs Hanson sat in her seat in the assembly for about 20 minutes covered by the black burqa before removing it to call for them to be banned in public for national security reasons.\n\n\"I'm quite happy to remove this because this is not what should belong in this parliament,\" Ms Hanson, who leads the far-right One Nation party, told the Senate.\n\n\"If a person who wears a balaclava or a helmet in to a bank or any other building, or even on the floor of the court, they must be removed. Why is it not the same case for someone who is covering up their face and cannot be identified?\"\n\nMs Hanson, who first rose to prominence in the 1990s because of her strident opposition to immigration from Asia and to asylum seekers, has in recent years campaigned against Islamic clothing and the building of mosques.\n\nHer party has four senators, which gives it influence in parliament when closely contested legislation is being voted on.\n\nAttorney-General George Brandis rebuked Ms Hanson.\n\n\"I am not going to pretend to ignore the stunt that you have tried to pull today by arriving in the chamber dressed in a burqa,\" he said, drawing applause from members of the Senate.\n\n\"We all know that you are not adherent of the Islamic faith. I would caution and counsel you with respect to be very, very careful of the offence you may do to the religious sensibilities of other Australians.\"\n\nAdel Salman, vice president of the Islamic Council of Victoria state, said Hanson's action was \"a mockery of her position\".\n\n\"It is very disappointing, but not surprising as she has sought to mock the Islamic faith time and time {"timeCrawl": "10:38:00", "uri": "710825079", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T10:38:00Z", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "source": {"title": "Clearfield Gant Daily", "uri": "gantdaily.com", "id": "537"}, "url": "http://gantdaily.com/2017/08/17/far-right-australian-senator-slammed-for-burqa-stunt/", "eventUri": "eng-3368046", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368046", "body": "An Australian senator known for her strong stance against Muslim immigration has been widely condemned for wearing a burqa to Parliament House.\n\nIn video of the parliamentary session, One Nation leader Pauline Hanson can be seen taking her seat in the floor-length Islamic garment. A voice on the recording can be heard saying, \"What on Earth?\"\n\nHanson has long called for the burqa to be banned in public, saying the central issue is the \"right of others to see a face.\"\n\nAmid unrest from her fellow senators, Hanson dramatically took off the veil, saying \"I'm quite happy to remove this because it's not what should belong in this parliament.\"\n\nHanson then asked Attorney General George Brandis, if \"in light of what is happening with national security... will you work to ban the burqa?\"\n\nBrandis, a member of the governing Liberal National coalition, received a standing ovation when, close to tears, he tore into Hanson for mocking the Muslim dress.\n\n\"Senator Hanson, no, we will not be banning the burqa.\"\n\n\"Senator Hanson, I'm not going to pretend to ignore the stunt that you have tried to pull today by arriving in the chamber dressed in a burqa, when we all know you are not an adherent of the Islamic faith.\"\n\nHe told Hanson to be \"very, very careful\" of offending the \"religious sensibilities of other Australians.\"\n\n\"To ridicule that community, to drive it into a corner, to mock its religious garments is an appalling thing to do,\" he said.\n\nTerror threat\n\nIn a speech to Parliament, Hanson referred to terror threats as one reason for her proposed ban.\n\nAustralia's terrorism threat level is currently listed as \"probable,\" on a four level scale between \"possible\" and \"expected.\"\n\nLast month, Australian authorities thwarted alleged twin terror plots described as the \"most sophisticated\" ever planned on Australian soil. They included plans to release a toxic gas in public.\n\nSince Australia's national terrorism threat level was last raised in September 2014, there have been five attacks and 13 \"major counter terrorism disruptions,\" according to a representative for the Australian Security Intelligence Organization.\n\nIn her speech, Hanson cited an attack on the Iranian parliament building in June, by men believed to be dressed in burqas, as being one example of the security threat.\n\n\"This is not the first case of this kind and it will not be the last,\" she said.\n\nGrowing Muslim population\n\nThe issue of burqa bans flared across the West last year amid calls to ban the full-length garment. They're already banned in France, Belgium, Austria and Switzerland. Earlier this year, the German parliament voted in favor of a partial ban, backed by Prime Minister Angela Merkel.\n\nIn a Facebook post, Hanson said: \"I have long believed that full face coverings, such as the burqa, were oppressive, presented barriers to assimilation, disadvantaged women from finding employment, were causing issues inside our justice system, presented a clear security threat and has no place in modern Western society.\"\n\nAccording to a Pew Research Center poll released in February, around half of Australian surveyed said that sharing the customs and traditions of the country is very important to anyone to be considered \"truly\" Australian.\n\nThere are around 600,000 Muslims in Australia -- about 2.6% of the population -- according to 2016 Census data.\n\nThe Australian far right has long attempted to ban face-covering Muslim clothing, however, Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull has insisted that it won't happen.\n\nDivisive figure\n\nThis is not the first time Pauline Hanson has captured the political spotlight in Australia.\n\nThe far-right politician became a national figure in Australia in 1996 when during her first speech to Parliament, after being elected as an independent MP, she said the country was at risk of being \"swamped by Asians.\"\n\nAmong the policies of Hanson's One Nation party are surveillance cameras in mosques, stopping Muslim immigration to Australia and holding a national inquiry into Islam.\n\nShe was found guilty of fraudulently obtaining $500,000 in election funding in 2003 and spent 11 weeks in jail before successfully appealing.\n\nHanson has run in numerous elections, including the 2007 and 2013 general votes, but has failed to win a seat until now. She also appeared on several reality TV shows, including Australia's Celebrity Apprentice in 2011.\n\nWhile the populist has been compared by some in the Australian media to US President Donald Trump -- and Hanson herself boasted of being invited to his inauguration -- his administration recently listed her political party a threat to religious freedom.\n\nThe annual International Religious Freedom Report highlights the campaign platform of Hanson's One Nation Party, which included \"cessation of Muslim immigration and limits on some Islamic practices,\" among an executive summary of the status of religious freedom in Australia.\n\nOnline criticism\n\nThe politician was widely criticized online for her recent stunt, by the public and fellow politicians.\n\nOne Twitter user, apparently a Melbourne-based, hijab-wearing Muslim woman, condemned Hanson's act.\n\n\"Our choice of clothing and religious expression is not your political football,\" she wrote.\n\nSome, however, applauded her move.\n\n\"Pauline Hanson made a very powerful statement in the Australian Senate by wearing a burqa,\" one commenter wrote. \"And Australian senators couldn't stomach it!\"\n\nOpposition leader Bill Shorten said the politician's \"stunt\" was \"beneath contempt.\"", "id": "9665295", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-17", "title": "Far-right Australian senator slammed for burqa 'stunt'", "image": "storyUri": "eng-3368046", "body": "The leader of Australia's \"One Nation\" party, Pauline Hanson, has caused controversy by wearing a burka to question time in the Upper House of Parliament.\n\nAn Australian anti-Muslim Senator might have just taken the cake for weird political stunts when she walked in to the Senate chamber wearing a burqa.\n\nParry said he would not interfere with what Senators wore.\n\n\"And I would caution you and counsel you Senator Hanson, with respect, to be very, very careful of the offence you may do to the religious sensibilities of other Australians\".\n\nThe vast majority of Muslims in Australia were law-abiding, he said.\n\nMs Hanson said she wore the garment to highlight the fact she believes \"it does not belong\" in parliament.\n\nThe fiery One Nation senator had urged the government to ban the burqa for \"national security reasons\" but Mr Brandis was having none of it.\n\nSenator George Brandis, who is Australia's Attorney General from the ruling, conservative Liberal Party, drew a standing ovation from all sides of the chamber for his condemnation of Hanson's \"stunt\". \"It is absolutely consistent being a good, law abiding Australian, and being a strict, adherent Muslim\".\n\nAn angry Senator Brandis said the government would not consider such a ban.\n\n\"I've been informed by the attendant that the identity of Senator Hanson was established before she entered the chamber\", Parry says in the video.\n\nHanson, who is vocally anti-Muslim and anti-immigration, warned in her inaugural speech for her second stint in the Senate in 2016 that \"We are now in danger of being swamped by Muslims whose culture is incompatible with our own\". "eng-3368046", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368046", "body": "Attorney-General George Brandis launched a withering and emotional condemnation of Pauline Hanson's decision to wear a burqa to Question Time.\n\nWith his voice cracking, Senator Brandis described Ms Hanson's move to wear the Muslim garment to the Senate and then remove it as \"appalling\".\n\n\"Senator Hanson, no, we will not be banning the burqa,\" a clearly emotional Senator Brandis said.\n\n\"I am not going to pretend to ignore the stunt that you have tried to pull today by arriving in the Chamber dressed in a burqa when we all know that you are not an adherent of the Islamic faith.\n\n\"I would caution and counsel you with respect to be very, very careful of the offence you may do to the religious sensibilities of other Australians.\"\n\n\"We have about 500,000 Australians in this country of the Islamic faith and the vast majority of them are law abiding good Australians.\n\n\"Senator Hanson, for the last four years, I have had responsibility pre-eminently among the ministers subject to the Prime Minister for national security policy.\n\n\"And I can tell you, Senator Hanson, that it has been the advice of each Director-General of security with whom I have worked and each Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police with whom I have worked that it is vital for their intelligence and law enforcement work that they work cooperatively with the Muslim community and to ridicule that community, to drive it into a corner, to mock its religious garments is an appalling thing to do and I would ask you to reflect on that.\"\n\nThe speech received a standing ovation from opposition members of the parliament.\n\nNick Xenophon praised Senator Brandis's stance describing what Ms Hanson did as \"toxic behaviour\".\n\n\"George Brandis spoke like a true statesman,\" he said.\n\n\"He displayed the leadership and clarity of purpose the country needs on an issue like this. So good on you George.\n\n\"He has shown what it means to be a statesman when many other politicians would have shied away, he did the right thing.\"\n\nGreens Leader Richard Di Natale also labelled Ms Hanson's actions \"disgraceful\" and argument for a multicultural code of conduct for the parliament to prevent future stunts.\n\nOf the stunt, Senator Hanson told radio station 2GB her One Nation colleague Brian Burston identified her to the senate security guards but said none of the guards checked to confirm her identity before she walked in.\n\n\"I put it on in my office, the media were taking photos, I walked straight down the hallway, down the stairs. I met two security guards and I walked straight up the chamber,\" she said.\n\n\"No one, no security guard at any point of time asked to see my face.\n\n\"When I walked into the chamber one of the attendants ... he just gasped.\n\n\"Doesn't the Australian people have the right to know that whoever sits in the chamber, that is actually the person they voted for,\" she said.\n\n\"How do I know, that if you have someone ... in a burqa in that chamber it is that person who walks in that chamber every time?\n\n\"These are questions that need to be asked.\n\n\"To blatantly come out, as Senator Brandis did with a definite no, 'we're not going to ban the burqa, we're not going to have equality as far as anyone wearing full faced coverings into a bank or into the chamber, a blatant 'No' straight off without saying 'Let's discuss this' ... it was just a definite 'No'.\n\nSenator Hanson hit back at the suggestions she was mocking the Islamic faith.\n\n\"That's absolute rubbish -- I'm not mocking anyone,\" she said.\n\n\"People have a right to their own faith and what they believe in, I've got no problems with that. But when that faith stops at a religion and then becomes a political ideology, that's what I have problems with.\n\n\"The burqa is not a religious requirement. "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368046", "body": "Senator Hanson took her seat while wearing the full-face black garment.\n\nSenate President Stephen Parry said Senator Hanson's identity had been confirmed before she entered the chamber.\n\nSenators continued on with Question Time in the Upper House as normal while Senator Hanson sat in the full black covering.\n\nHer provocative move comes ahead of her call to ban the garment in Australia.\n\nThe One Nation leader is expected to make a speech to the Parliament later today about the ban, which she has called for in the past.\n\nLabor senators called \"shame\" and \"you're a disgrace\" as Senator Hanson rose to ask if the Government would work towards implementing the ban.\n\nAttorney-General George Brandis received a standing ovation from the Labor senators when he called Hanson's stunt \"appalling\".\n\n\"Senator Hanson, no, we will not be banning the burqa,\" Brandis said.\n\n\"I am not going to pretend to ignore the stunt that you have tried to pull today by arriving in the Chamber dressed in a burka when we all know that you are not an adherent of the Islamic faith.\n\n\" I would caution and counsel "body": "One Nation leader Pauline Hanson has entered the Senate wearing a burqa.\n\nAttorney-General George Brandis has savaged an \"appalling\" stunt by Pauline Hanson after the One Nation leader entered the Senate dressed in a burqa.\n\nThe One Nation leader pulled the stunt during question time on Thursday before a debate on banning full-face coverings in public.\n\nSenator Hanson removed the face covering to ask Attorney-General George Brandis a question about banning the burqa.\n\nAn angry Senator Brandis said the government would not consider such a ban.\n\n\"I would caution and counsel you with respect to be very, very careful of the offence you may do to the religious sensibilities of other Australians,\" he said.\n\nThe vast majority of Muslims in Australia were law-abiding, and Australia's senior security officials say it's vital for their intelligence and law enforcement work that they work cooperatively with the Muslim community, Senator Brandis said.\n\n\"To ridicule that community, to drive it into a corner, to mock its religious garments is an appalling thing to do,\" Senator Brandis said, almost moved to tears.\n\nHis emotional slap-down received applause from all sides of politics, except One Nation senators.\n\nSenator Hanson then left the chamber with her full-face covering in hand.\n\nLabor senator Penny Wong, a fierce and long-time rival of Senator Brandis, rose to congratulate him.\n\nSo too did another of his regular sparring partners, Greens leader Richard Di Natale.\n\nOpposition frontbencher Sam Dastyari, a non-practising Muslim, struck out at the \"desperate\" stunt.\n\n\"Today was embarrassing, it was insulting, it was hurtful and it was wrong,\" he told senators.\n\n\"When you pull those types stunts - when people try and trivialise other people's faith and other people's religion for the sole purpose of a cheap headline - national security is damaged, not helped.\"\n\nThe stunt came just one day public.\n\n\"Doesn't the Australian people have a right to know that whoever sits in their chamber that is actually the person that they voted for,\" she told Sydney's 2GB radio afterwards.\n\nSenator And senator Hanson it is absolutely consistent with being a good, law-abiding Australian and a strict, adherent Muslim.\n\nNow senator Hanson, for the last four years, I have had responsibility, pre-eminently, among the ministers, subject to the Prime Minister, for national security policy.\n\nAnd I can tell you, senator Hanson, that it has been the advice of each Director-General of security with whom I have worked, and each Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police with whom I have worked, that it is vital for their intelligence and law enforcement work that they work cooperatively Why is it not the same case for someone who is covering up their face and cannot be identified?\"\n\nMs Hanson, who first rose to prominence in the 1990s because of her strident opposition to immigration from Asia and to asylum seekers, has in recent years campaigned against Islamic clothing and the building of mosques.\n\nHer party has four senators, which gives it influence in Parliament when closely contested legislation is being voted on.\n\nAttorney-General George Brandis rebuked Ms Hanson for her action.\n\n\"I am not going to pretend to ignore the stunt that you have tried to pull today by arriving in the chamber dressed in a burqa,\" he said, drawing applause from members of the Senate.\n\n\"We all know that you are not an adherent of the Islamic faith. I would caution and counsel you with respect to be very, very careful of the offence you may do to the religious sensibilities of other Australians.\"\n\nOpposition Senate leader Penny Wong told Ms Hanson: \"It is one thing to wear religious dress as a sincere act of faith; it is another to wear it as a stunt here in the Senate.\"\n\nMr Sam Dastyari, an opposition Senator and an Iranian-born Muslim, said: \"We have seen the stunt of all stunts in this chamber by Senator Hanson.\n\n\"The close to 500,000 Muslim Australians do not deserve to be targeted, do not deserve to be marginalised, do not deserve to be ridiculed, do not deserve to have their faith made some political point by the desperate leader of a desperate political party,\" added Mr Dastyari.\n\nSenate President Stephen Parry said Ms Hanson's identity had been confirmed before she entered the chamber. He also said he would not dictate the standards of dress for the chamber. "1151"}, "url": "https://www.rte.ie/news/2017/0817/898013-australia-pauline-hanson/", "eventUri": "eng-3368046", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368046", "body": "An Australian anti-immigration politician caused a furore this morning when she entered the Senate wearing a full burqa, earning a stern rebuke from the country's top lawyer for the \"appalling\" stunt.\n\nPauline Hanson wore the Islamic garment in the chamber to highlight what she said were the security issues it posed, linking it to terrorism as fellow senators heckled her.\n\n\"Will you work to ban the burqa in Australia in light of what is happening with national security?\" she said after whipping off the garment to question Attorney General George Brandis.\n\nShe added: \"Terrorism is a true threat to our country, many Australians are in fear of it.\"\n\nMr Brandis said his conservative government had no such plans, warning Ms Hanson she risked offending the Muslim community by wearing a burqa when she was not a follower of Islam.\n\n\"To ridicule that community, to drive it into a corner, to mock its religious garments is an appalling thing to do, and I would ask you to reflect on what you have done,\" he said.\n\nMr Brandis, his voice cracking with emotion, also said that being a strict adherent Muslim, such as those who wear the burqa, was \"absolutely consistent\" with being a law-abiding citizen.\n\n\"We have about half a million Australians in this country of the Islamic faith and the vast majority of them are law-abiding, good Australians,\" he said.\n\nMr Brandis' remarks prompted a standing ovation from his political opponents in the Labor and Greens parties.\n\nIndependent senator Derryn Hinch labelled Hanson's conduct \"disgusting\".\n\n\"Pauline Hanson mocked the religion of some Australians... she made a mockery of an honourable place [the Senate],\" he told Sky News.\n\nLabor senator Sam Dastyari accused Ms Hanson of stoking extremism in a poorly timed bid for \"a cheap headline\".\n\n\"In the same week that we saw white nationalism rear its ugly head in the country of our closest ally, in that week a stunt like this gets pulled in the Australian Senate,\" he said.\n\n\"It is hurtful, it is offensive, it is wrong,\"\n\nMs Hanson first gained prominence in the 1990s, when she warned Australia was in danger of being \"swamped by Asians\".\n\nAfter a 12-year hiatus from politics she returned in 2014, this time targeting Muslims, and was elected to the Senate two years later as leader of the right-wing One Nation party.\n\nIn her first speech after returning to parliament, she said Islam was \"a culture and ideology that is incompatible with our own\".\n\nMs Hanson was unrepentant after her latest stunt, telling commercial radio: \"Is it Hanson.\n\n\"To ridicule that community, to drive it into a corner, to mock its religious garments is an appalling thing to do and I would ask you to reflect on what you have done,\" Brandis said.\n\nOpposition Senate leader Penny Wong told Hanson: \"It is one thing to wear religious dress as a sincere act of faith; it is another to wear it as a stunt here in the Senate.\"\n\nSam Dastyari, an opposition senator and an Iranian-born Muslim, said: \"We have seen the stunt of all stunts in this chamber by Sen. Hanson.\"\n\n\"The close to 500,000 Muslim Australians do not deserve to be targeted, do not deserve to be marginalized, do not deserve to be ridiculed, do not deserve to have their faith made some political point by the desperate leader of a desperate political party,\" Dastyari said.\n\nSenate President Stephen Parry said Hanson's identity had been confirmed before she entered the chamber. Image: AP/PA Images\n\nAUSTRALIAN ANTI-IMMIGRANT politician Pauline Hanson caused a furore when she entered the Senate wearing a full burqa, earning a blistering rebuke from the country's top lawyer for the \"appalling\" stunt.\n\nHanson wore the Islamic garment in the chamber to highlight what she said were the security issues it posed, linking it to terrorism as fellow senators heckled her.\n\n\"Will you work to ban the burqa in Australia in light of what is happening with national security?\" she said after whipping off the garment to question Attorney-General George Brandis.\n\nShe added: \"Terrorism is a true threat to our country, many Australians are in fear of it.\"\n\nBrandis said his conservative government had no such plans, warning Hanson she risked offending the Muslim community by wearing a burka when she was not a follower of Islam.\n\n\"To ridicule that community, to drive it into a corner, to mock its religious garments is an appalling thing to do, and I would ask you to reflect on what you have done,\" he said.\n\nBrandis, his voice cracking with emotion, also said that being a strict adherent Muslim, such as those who wear the burka, was \"absolutely consistent\" with being a law-abiding citizen.\n\n\"We have about half a million Australians in this country of the Islamic faith and the vast majority of them are law-abiding, good Australians,\" he said.\n\nBrandis' remarks prompted a standing ovation from his political opponents in the Labour and Greens parties.\n\nAustralia's far-right one nation party leader Pauline its ugly head in the country of our closest ally, in that week a stunt like this gets pulled in the Australian Senate,\" he said.\n\n\"It is hurtful, it is offensive, it is wrong.\"\n\nHanson first gained prominence in the 1990s, when she warned Australia was in danger of being \"swamped by Asians\".\n\nAfter a 12-year hiatus from politics she returned in 2014, this time targeting Muslims and incompatible with our own\".\n\nHanson was unrepentant after her latest stunt, telling commercial radio: \"Is it extreme? Pauline Hanson, who has sponsored legislation to ban burqas in Australia, entered the chamber with the black veil worn by some Muslim women, then removed it when asked a question by a colleague.\n\n\"I'm quite happy to remove this because this is not what should belong in this Parliament,\" Hanson said, calling on lawmakers to support her legislation.\n\nThe display was met with an emotional rebuke by Australian Attorney General George Brandis, who received a rare standing ovation from several of his colleagues in the Senate after admonishing Hanson.\n\n\"Senator Hanson, I'm not going to pretend to ignore the stunt that you have tried to pull today by arriving in the chamber dressed in burqa when we all know you are not an adherent to the Islamic faith. I caution you and counsel you Senator Hanson, with respect, to be very, very careful of the offense you may give to the religious sensibilities of other Australians,\" Brandis said.\n\nHis voice {"timeCrawl": "08:35:00", "uri": "710770827", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T08:35:00Z", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "source": {"title": "Queensland Times", "uri": "qt.com.au", "id": "4736"}, "url": "https://www.qt.com.au/news/hansons-speech-ban-burqa/3213675/", "eventUri": "eng-3368046", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368046", "body": "ONE Nation Senator Pauline Hanson has delivered a speech calling for a burqa ban and accusing Labor of \"pandering to the Muslim vote\".\n\nIt follows LNP Senator and Attorney-General George Brandis warning her to be respectful of religious sensibilities and saying ridiculing the Muslim community was \"appalling\".\n\nSenator Hanson said she wanted the government to ban \"full face coverings\" in public places.\n\n\"No one should be permitted behind a veil of secrecy while there is a security concern,\" she said.\n\n\"Our laws are outdated and we need new ones like a ban on full face coverings.\n\n\"While it is an offence in most states in Australia to be disguised with unlawful intent, it is self-evident that the two years jail is not a deterrent for a suicide bomber.\"\n\nShe said the ban was needed to prevent terrorism.\n\n\"We need laws to stop terrorism before it happens and the ability of others to see a face is an important part of assessing that risk,\" Senator Hanson said.\n\n\"Full face coverings, like a niqab or burqa, take away a valuable source of information from counter-terrorism experts and ordinary Australians.\n\n\"How can you justify the ban on wearing a helmet or a balaclava into banks but let someone wear a niqab or burqa?\"\n\nShe claimed that \"the Muslim vote\" determined the electoral outcomes in up to 15 lower house seats, before accusing Labor of \"pandering to the Muslim vote\".\n\n\"My message to those who want to live under Sharia Law is to migrate to an Islamic country but don't come here to Australia,\" she said.\n\n\"The meaning of the Islamic veil, niqab or burqa has varied over time but what has never changed is the way the wearer is separated from everyone else.\n\n\"This separation is a barrier to the formation of relationships so necessary to integrate into the Australian way of life.\n\n\"I want to say that everyone has the right to their own religious beliefs but it is only Islam that threatens our way of life.\"\n\nSenator Hanson delivered her speech to an almost empty Senate Chamber, with just two Coalition Senators, two ALP Senators, Senator Jacqui Lambie and her three One Nation colleagues present.\n\nSenator Brandis had earlier pulled her up for pulling a \"stunt\" by wearing a burqa into Senate Question Time.\n\n\"I'm not going to pretend to ignore the stunt that you have tried to pull today by arriving in the chamber dressed in burqa when we all know you are not an adherent to the Islamic faith,\" he said.\n\n\"I caution you and counsel you, Senator Hanson, with respect to be very, very careful of the offence you may give to the religious sensibilities of other Australians.\n\n\"We have about half a million Australians in this country of the Islamic faith and the vast majority of them are law abiding good Australians.\n\n\"To ridicule that community, to drive it into a corner, to mock its religious garments is an appalling thing to do.\"\n\nHe warned her attacking the Muslim community was a risk to national security.\n\n\"I can tell you, Senator Hanson, that it has been the advice of each director-general of security with whom I have worked, and each division of the Australian Federal Police with whom I have worked, that it is vital for their intelligence and law enforcement work that they work cooperatively with the Muslim community,\" Senator Brandis said.\n\nLeader of the Opposition in the Senate Penny Wong commended the Attorney-General for his response to Senator Hanson.\n\n\"The sort of bigotry and divisiveness we saw displayed by Senator Hanson today has no place in our society. It certainly has no place in our parliament,\" Senator Wong said.\n\n\"It is one thing to wear religious dress as an act of faith. It is another to wear it as a stunt. That can only give offence and divide.\n\n\"Nobody needs to defend Senator Hanson's right to speak. The people that need defending are the people she attacks.\n\n\"Leaders have an obligation to stand up for the people in Australia who do not have a voice and today the Parliament did so.\"", "id": {"timeCrawl": "10:38:00", "uri": "710824834", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T10:38:00Z", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "source": {"title": "CNN International", "uri": "edition.cnn.com", "id": "1256"}, "url": "http://www.cnn.com/2017/08/17/asia/australia-pauline-hanson-burqa/index.html", "eventUri": "eng-3368046", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368046", "body": "Chat with us in Facebook Messenger. Find out what's happening in the world as it unfolds.\n\nStory highlightsAnti-Muslim politician wears burqa in Australian senate session Politicians decry action as a \"stunt\"\n\n(CNN)An Australian senator known for her strong stance against Muslim immigration has been widely condemned for wearing a burqa to Parliament House.\n\nIn video of the parliamentary session, One Nation leader Pauline Hanson can be seen taking her seat in the floor-length Islamic garment. A voice on the recording can be heard saying, \"What on Earth?\"Hanson has long called for the burqa to be banned in public, saying the central issue is the \"right of others to see a face.\" Amid unrest from her fellow senators, Hanson dramatically took off the veil, saying \"I'm quite happy to remove this because it's not what should belong in this parliament.\" Hanson then asked Attorney General George Brandis, if \"in light of what is happening with national security... will you work to ban the burqa?\"Read MoreBrandis, a member of the governing Liberal National coalition, received a standing ovation when, close to tears, he tore into Hanson for mocking the Muslim dress.\"Senator Hanson, no, we will not be banning the burqa.\"\"Senator Hanson, I'm not going to pretend to ignore the stunt that you have tried to pull today by arriving in the chamber dressed in a burqa, when we all know you are not an adherent of the Islamic faith.\"He told Hanson to be \"very, very careful\" of offending the \"religious sensibilities of other Australians.\"\"To ridicule that community, to drive it into a corner, to mock its religious garments is an appalling thing to do,\" he said.\n\nGeorge Brandis on the verge of tears as he tells Pauline Hanson her behaviour is \"appalling\". Standing ovation from ALP/Greens. #auspol #QT pic.twitter.com/KQpc6q5RVN -- Michael Koziol (@michaelkoziol)\n\nAugust 17, 2017\n\nTerror threatIn a speech to Parliament, Hanson referred to terror threats as one reason for her proposed ban.Australia's terrorism threat level is currently listed as \"probable,\" on a four level scale between \"possible\" and \"expected.\"Last month, Australian authorities thwarted alleged twin terror plots described as the \"most sophisticated\" ever planned on Australian soil. They included plans to release a toxic gas in public.Since Australia's national terrorism threat level was last raised in September 2014, there have been five attacks and 13 \"major counter terrorism disruptions,\" according to a representative for the Australian Security Intelligence Organization.In her speech, Hanson cited an attack on the Iranian parliament building in June, by men believed to be dressed in burqas, as being one example of the security threat.\"This is not the first case of this kind and it will not be the last,\" she said.Growing Muslim population The issue of burqa bans flared across the West last year amid calls to ban the full-length garment. They're already banned in France, Belgium, Austria and Switzerland. Earlier this year, the German parliament voted in favor of a partial ban, backed by Prime Minister Angela Merkel. North region, Cameroon Xinjiang, China Lombardy, Italy Diffa, Niger Stavropol, Russia Reus, Spain Ticino, Switzerland Belgium Chad France Gabon Republic of Congo Azerbaijan Banned in schools Kosovo Banned in schools Malasyia Banned for public servants Syria Banned for university students Egypt Netherlands Tunisia Germany In a Facebook post, Hanson said: \"I have long believed that full face coverings, such as the burqa, were oppressive, presented barriers to assimilation, disadvantaged women from finding employment, were causing issues inside our justice system, presented a clear security threat and has no place in modern Western society.\" According to a Pew Research Center poll released in February, around half of Australian surveyed said that sharing the customs and traditions of the country is very important to anyone to be considered \"truly\" Australian.There are around 600,000 Muslims in Australia -- about 2.6% of the population -- according to 2016 Census data. The Australian far right has long attempted to ban face-covering Muslim clothing, however, Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull has insisted that it won't happen.Divisive figureThis is not the first time Pauline Hanson has captured the political spotlight in Australia.The far-right politician became a national figure in Australia in 1996 when during her first speech to Parliament, after being elected as an independent MP, she said the country was at risk of being \"swamped by Asians.\"Among the policies of Hanson's One Nation party are surveillance cameras in mosques, stopping Muslim immigration to Australia and holding a national inquiry into Islam.She was found guilty of fraudulently obtaining $500,000 in election funding in 2003 and spent 11 weeks in jail before successfully appealing.Hanson has run in numerous elections, including the 2007 and 2013 general votes, but has failed to win a seat until now. She also appeared on several reality TV shows, including Australia's Celebrity Apprentice in 2011.While the populist has been compared by some in the Australian media to US President Donald Trump -- and Hanson herself boasted of being invited to his inauguration -- his administration recently listed her political party a threat to religious freedom.The International Religious Freedom Report, published annually by the US government, highlights the campaign platform of Hanson's One Nation Party, which included \"cessation of Muslim immigration and limits on some Islamic practices,\" among an executive summary of the current status of religious freedom in Australia. Online criticism The politician was widely criticized online for her recent stunt, by the public and fellow politicians.One Twitter user, apparently a Melbourne-based, hijab-wearing Muslim woman, condemned Hanson's act. \"Our choice of clothing and religious expression is not your political football,\" she wrote.\n\nOur choice of clothing and religious expression is not your political Football. \u1f621\u1f621\u1f621 #PaulineHanson @PaulineHansonOz -- Rana Hussain (@ranahuss)\n\nAugust 17, 2017\n\nSome, however, applauded her move. \"Pauline Hanson made a very powerful statement in the Australian Senate by wearing a burqa,\" one commenter wrote. \"And Australian senators couldn't stomach it!\"\n\nPauline Hanson made a very powerful statement in the Australian Senate by wearing a burqa. And Australian senators couldn't stomach it! -- Mervyn Sullivan (@PMS280153)\n\nAugust 17, 2017\n\nOpposition leader Bill Shorten said the politician's \"stunt\" was \"beneath contempt.\"\n\nHanson's stunt beneath contempt. Response from Brandis is spot on. Standing ovation from ALP/Greens. #auspol #QT pic.twitter.com/KQpc6q5RVN -- Michael Koziol (@michaelkoziol)\n\nAugust 17, 2017\u200b\n\nIn 2016 a poll suggested almost half of all Australians wanted to ban Muslim immigrants. Ms. Hanson, who heads the One Nation Party, has been campaigning to get the burqa banned in Australia, which is home to around 500,000 Muslims.\n\nOne of Australia's most notorious burqa-wearers was Fatima Elomar, whose husband was killed fighting for Daesh in Syria in 2015.\n\n\"No, Senator Hanson, we will not ban the burqa,\" said Mr. Brandis.\n\n\"To ridicule that community, to drive it into a corner, to mock its religious garments, is an appalling thing to do and I would ask you reflect on what you have done,\" said Mr. Brandis, who was applauded by opposition senators from the Labor Party and the Greens.\n\n\"It is one thing to wear religious dress as a sincere act of faith, there is another to wear it as a stunt here in the chamber,\" said Labor Senator Penny Wong.\n\nSam Dastyari, an Iranian-born senator, stood up for Muslim Australians.\n\n\"Muslim Australians do not deserve to be targeted, do not deserve to be marginalized, do not deserve to be ridiculed, do not deserve to have {"timeCrawl": "12:03:00", "uri": "710863240", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T12:03:00Z", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "source": {"title": "SBS", "uri": "sbs.com.au", "id": "793"}, "url": "http://www.sbs.com.au/news/article/2017/08/17/pauline-hansons-call-ban-burqas-oppressive-says-muslim-leader", "eventUri": "eng-3368046", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368046", "body": "Ms Hanson's extraordinary stunt - wearing a full-length burqa in the Senate chamber - to show she opposes people wearing face veils in Australia is \"very unfortunate\", Silma Ihram told SBS World News.\n\n\"I think it is terrible timing, especially considering what's been playing out in the US at the moment.\n\n\"I don't believe the burqa is a security threat in Australia. It's not universally popular amongst the Muslim community, but there are many more pressing issues in terms of security than the burqa,\" she said.\n\nShe said women have the right to choose how they dress, particularly in Australia.\n\n\"It's a terrific thing about Australia - that it doesn't force people to assimilate, but it recognises their cultural diversity.\n\n\"What is sad is that Pauline Hanson has refused to meet with the Muslim community, and continues - like some people, only a few in the Australian community - to hold very incorrect perceptions about what Islam means to Muslims and how we live our lives.\"\n\nOne Nation leader Pauline Hanson shocked her fellow senators after entering the chamber during Question Time on Thursday afternoon wearing a full length burqa.\n\nThere were audible groans in the Senate as she walked in and one person was heard saying \"What on earth?\"\n\nSenator Hanson removed the burqa a few minutes later as she attempted to ask the Attorney-General a question on banning the garment altogether.\n\n\"Will the Attorney-General ban this burqa?\" she said in the Senate.\n\nenator Brandis' passionate impromptu response to the One Nation senator's stunt earned a standing ovation from Labor and Greens senators.\n\n\"You are not an adherent of the Islamic faith,\" Senator Brandis said in a passionate response.\n\n\"I would caution you and counsel you. Be very, very careful of the offence you may give.\"\n\n\"We have about 500,000 Australians in this country of the Islamic faith. And the vast majority of them are law abiding good Australians.\"\n\nMr Brandis said that it was vital to work with the Muslim community to combat the threat of radicalisation.\n\n\"It is vital for their intelligence and law enforcement work that they work cooperatively with the Muslim community, and to ridicule that community, to drive it into a corner, to mock its religious garments is an appalling thing to do and I would ask you to reflect on what you have done.\"\n\nIndependent Derryn Hinch asked Senator Parry whether he could come into the chamber wearing fancy dress, given Senator Hanson is not a Muslim.\n\nSenator Parry said he would not interfere with what Senators wore.\n\n\"It may have been something that I did that was radical, yes it was, coming into this chamber with a burqa on but it was a case in point saying that I do not believe that at any point in time ever in the future that any full face coverings should ever be worn in this place,\" Senator Hanson later said in the chamber.\n\nShe has since moved a motion in parliament calling on the federal government to ban the burqa but it was defeated within an hour.\n\n\"The fact is wearing a burqa is not a religious requirement. Non Islamic countries like Switzerland, Norway, Germany, France, Belgium, the Netherlands, Spain, China and Russia have also banned full face coverings. Again, lawmakers believe a ban improves public safety and enables social cohesion.\n\n\"How can you justify the banning of a helmet or balaclavas but not a burqa when entering a bank?\"\n\nShe has also renewed her push for a temporary ban on Muslim immigration for at least five years.\n\n\"If we do not draw a line in the sand against immigration from Islamic countries, the influence of Muslims in this country will continue to grow and Australia will continue down the path of Islamisation.\"\n\nLabor Senator Doug Cameron spoke straight after to oppose the motion and condemn Ms Hanson's earlier stunt.\n\n\"A contribution underpinned by racism, a contribution underpinned by religious intolerance and a contribution from my point of view underpinned by just plain stupidity,\" Senator Cameron said.\n\nSenator Nick Xenophon has applauded the Attorney General's response to Pauline Hanson's burqa stunt and says it was offensive and demeaning to people of the Islamic faith.\n\n\"I know a thing or two about stunts but I wouldn't even call this a stunt, this was just toxic,\" Senator Xenophon told reporters in Canberra.\n\nOpposition leader Bill Shorten described it as a 'political circus stunt'.\n\n\"I do not believe, no matter what anyone thinks, that pulling those sorts of antics in parliament does anything other than trivialise parliament and democracy,\" Mr Shorten told reporters in Canberra.\n\nNSW Muslim MP Jihad Dib said the incident was \"calculated and divisive\".\n\nIndependent senator Cory Bernardi also weighed in on the stunt.\n\n\"I did warn you that proroguing the parliament was in national interest. community.\n\nPerth-based Australian Federation of Islamic Councils president Rateb Jneid condemned Senator Hanson's actions, but questioned whether anyone in the Muslim community listened to former Australian politician Pauline Hanson (L) caused a furore when she entered the Senate wearing a full burqa\n\nAustralian anti-immigration politician Pauline Hanson caused a furore Thursday when she entered the Senate wearing a full burqa, earning a blistering rebuke from the country's top lawyer for the \"appalling' stunt.\n\nHanson wore the Islamic garment in the chamber to highlight what she said were the security issues it posed, linking it to terrorism as fellow senators heckled her.\n\n\"Will you work to ban the burqa in Australia in light of what is happening with national security?\" she said after whipping off the garment to question Attorney-General George Brandis.\n\nShe added: \"Terrorism is a true threat to our country, many Australians are in fear of it.\"\n\nBrandis said his conservative government had no such plans, warning Hanson she risked offending the Muslim community by wearing a burka when she was not a follower of Islam.\n\n\"To ridicule that community, to drive it into a corner, to mock its religious garments is an appalling thing to do, and I would ask you to reflect on what you have done,\" he said.\n\nBrandis, his voice cracking with emotion, also said that being a strict adherent Muslim, such as those who wear the burka, was \"absolutely consistent\" with being a law-abiding citizen.\n\n\"We have about half a million Australians in this country of the Islamic faith and the vast majority of them are law-abiding, good Australians,\" he said.\n\nBrandis' remarks prompted a standing ovation from his political opponents in the Labor and Greens parties.\n\nIndependent senator Derryn Hinch labelled Hanson's conduct \"disgusting\".\n\n\"Pauline Hanson mocked the religion of some Australians... she made a Why is it not the same case for someone who is covering up their face and cannot be identified?\"\n\nGet The Straits Times\n\nnewsletters in your inboxSign Up\n\nMs Hanson, who first rose to prominence in the 1990s because of her strident opposition to immigration from Asia and to asylum seekers, has in recent years campaigned against Islamic clothing and the building of mosques. Her party has four senators, which gives it influence in Parliament when closely contested legislation is being voted on.\n\nAttorney-General George Brandis rebuked Ms Hanson. \"I am not going to pretend to ignore the stunt that you have tried to pull today by arriving in the Chamber dressed in a burqa,\" he said, drawing applause from members of the Senate.\n\n\"We all know that you are not an adherent of the Islamic faith. I would caution and counsel you, with respect, to be very, very careful of the offence you may do to the religious sensibilities of other Australians.\"\n\nMr Adel Salman, vice-president of the Islamic Council of Victoria state, said Ms Hanson's action was \"a mockery of her position\".\n\n\"It is very disappointing, but not surprising as she has sought to mock the Islamic faith time and AP\n\nHanson sat in her seat in the assembly for about 20 minutes covered by the black burqa before removing it to call for them to be banned in public for national security reasons.\n\n\"I'm quite happy to remove this because this is not what should belong in this parliament\", Hanson, who leads the far-right One Nation party, told the Senate.\n\n\"If a person who wears a balaclava or a helmet in to a bank or any other building, or even on the floor of the court, they must be removed. Why is it not the same case for someone who is covering up their face and cannot be identified?\".\n\nHanson, who first rose to prominence in the 1990s because of her strident opposition to immigration from Asia and to asylum seekers, has in recent years campaigned against Islamic clothing and the building of mosques.\n\nHer party has four senators, which gives it influence in parliament when closely contested legislation is being voted on.\n\nAttorney-General George Brandis rebuked Hanson.\n\n\"I am not going to pretend to ignore the stunt that you have tried to pull today by arriving in the chamber dressed in a burqa\", he said, drawing applause from members of the Senate.\n\n\"We all know that you are not adherent of the Islamic faith. I would caution and counsel you with respect to be very, very careful of the offense you may do to the religious sensibilities of other Australians.\"\n\nAdel Salman, vice president of the Islamic Why is it not the same case for someone who is covering up their face and cannot be identified?\"\n\nHanson, who first rose to prominence in the 1990s because of her strident opposition to immigration from Asia and to asylum seekers, has in recent years campaigned against Islamic clothing and the building of mosques.\n\nHer party has four senators, which gives it influence in Parliament when closely contested legislation is being voted on.\n\nAttorney-General George Brandis rebuked Hanson.\n\n\"I am not going to pretend to ignore the stunt that you have tried to pull today by arriving in the chamber dressed in a burqa,\" he said, drawing applause from members of the Senate.\n\n\"We all know that you are not adherent of the Islamic faith. Pauline Hanson takes off a burqa she wore into the Senate chamber at Parliament House in Canberra, Australia, Thursday, Aug. 17, 2017. Hanson, leader of the anti-Muslim, anti-immigration One Nation minor party, sat wearing the black head-to-ankle garment for more than 10 minutes before taking it off as she rose to explain that she wanted such outfits banned on national security grounds. (Lukas Coch/AAP Image via AP)\n\nAttorney-General George Brandis drew applause when he said his government would not ban the burqa, and chastised Hanson for what he described as a \"stunt\" that offended Australia's Muslim minority.\n\n\"To ridicule that community, to drive it into a corner, to mock its religious garments is an appalling thing to do and I would ask you to reflect on what you have done,\" Brandis said.\n\nOpposition Senate leader Penny Wong told Hanson: \"It is one thing to wear religious dress as a sincere act of faith; it is another to wear it as a stunt here in the Senate.\"\n\nSam Dastyari, an opposition senator and an Iranian-born Muslim, said: \"We have seen the stunt of all stunts in this chamber by Sen. Hanson.\"\n\n\"The close to 500,000 Muslim Australians do not deserve to be targeted, do not deserve to be marginalized, do not deserve to be ridiculed, do not deserve to have their faith made some political point by the desperate leader of a desperate political party,\" Dastyari said.\n\nSenate President Stephen Parry said Hanson's identity had been confirmed before she entered the chamber. He also said he would not dictate the standards of dress for the chamber.\n\nSen. {"timeCrawl": "08:32:00", "uri": "710770154", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T08:32:00Z", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "source": {"title": "digitaljournal.com", "uri": "digitaljournal.com", "id": "556"}, "url": "http://www.digitaljournal.com/news/world/muslim-baiter-hanson-wears-burka-in-australia-s-senate/article/500233", "eventUri": "eng-3368046", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368046", "body": "Australian anti-immigration politician Pauline Hanson caused a furore Thursday when she entered the Senate wearing a full burqa, earning a blistering rebuke from the country's top lawyer for the \"appalling\" stunt.\n\nHanson wore the Islamic garment in the chamber to highlight what she said were the security issues it posed, linking it to terrorism as fellow senators heckled her.\n\n\"Will you work to ban the burqa in Australia in light of what is happening with national security?\" she said after whipping off the garment to question Attorney-General George Brandis.\n\nShe added: \"Terrorism is a true threat to our country, many Australians are in fear of it.\"\n\nBrandis said his conservative government had no such plans, warning Hanson she risked offending the Muslim community by wearing a burka when she was not a follower of Islam.\n\n\"To ridicule that community, to drive it into a corner, to mock its religious garments is an appalling thing to do, and I would ask you to reflect on what you have done,\" he said.\n\nBrandis, his voice cracking with emotion, also said that being a strict adherent Muslim, such as those who wear the burka, was \"absolutely consistent\" with being a law-abiding citizen.\n\n\"We have about half a million Australians in this country of the Islamic faith and the vast majority of them are law-abiding, good Australians,\" he said.\n\nBrandis' remarks prompted a standing ovation from his political opponents in the Labor and Greens parties.\n\nIndependent senator Derryn Hinch labelled Hanson's conduct \"disgusting\".\n\n\"Pauline Hanson mocked the religion of some Australians... she made a mockery of an honourable place (the Senate),\" he told Sky News.\n\nLabor senator Sam Dastyari accused Hanson of stoking extremism in a poorly timed bid for \"a cheap headline\".\n\n\"In the same week that we saw white nationalism rear its ugly head in the country of our closest ally -- in that week a stunt like this gets pulled in the Australian Senate,\" he said.\n\n\"It is hurtful, it is offensive, it is wrong,\"\n\nHanson first gained prominence in the 1990s, when she warned Australia was in danger of being \"swamped by Asians\".\n\nAfter a 12-year hiatus from politics she returned in 2014, this time targeting Muslims and was elected to the Senate two years later as leader of the right-wing One Nation party.\n\nIn her first speech after returning to parliament, she said Islam was \"a culture and ideology that is incompatible with our own\".\n\nHanson was unrepentant after her latest stunt, telling commercial radio: \"Is it extreme? Yes. Is it getting my message across? {"timeCrawl": "08:00:00", "uri": "710754072", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T08:00:00Z", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "source": {"title": "The Australian", "uri": "theaustralian.com.au", "id": "292"}, "url": "http://at.theaustralian.com.au/link/cd29b0ac7e07bab761004381e3a42882?domain=theaustralian.com.au", "eventUri": "eng-3368046", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368046", "body": "Attorney-General George Brandis has slammed the One Nation leader for what he described as an \"appalling stunt\" of dressing in the Islamic dress that has a face covering.\n\nSenator Hanson told radio 2GB this afternoon that she had put the burka on in her office and that she had not been stopped by security, saying the parliamentary attendant had been told in advance.\n\nShe had had the idea for \"months\" and told 2GB that Senator Brandis's admonishment of her proved politicians aren't taking the issue of rising Islam seriously.\n\n\"What I have done today is open up debate, and what Senator Brandis did today was just shut it down.\"\n\nSenator Hanson described wearing the burka as \"really horrible, it really is\" and \"more than just uncomfortable... it's really hard to describe\".\n\nIn question time, Senate President Stephen Parry allowed Senator Hanson to sit in the chamber dressed in the clothing, after senator Derryn Hinch challenged her.\n\n\"I'd like to know if Senator Hanson can stay here, unchallenged. I understand that she is not a Muslim, not of Islamic faith. Can I appear tomorrow in fancy dress unchallenged?\" Senator Hinch said.\n\nSenator Parry replied: \"I've been advised by the clerk via the attendant that the identity of Senator Hanson was established before she entered the chamber.\n\n\"My rulings have always been, Senator Hinch, that I'm not going to dictate the standard of dress for senators in this chamber. I believe senators should be making their own decisions about the standard of dress.\"\n\nParliamentarians are often get told off for bringing props to question time. Someone in the chamber was heard saying \"Oh what on earth?\" as she walked in.\n\nThe senator dressed in the outfit, on which her Senate pin was visible, before she was expected to move a motion about violent extremism at 4.30pm.\n\n\"In light of the national security of this nation will you work to ban the burka in Australia,\" Senator Hanson asked the Attorney-General.\n\nSenator Brandis said: \"No\".\n\nSenator Hanson took the burka off during in question time and then left with the garment in her hand.\n\nBrandis slams Hanson 'stunt'\n\nAn emotional Senator Brandis then attacked Senator Hanson for her \"stunt\" and said what she had done was \"appalling\".\n\n\"I can tell you it has been the advice of each director-general of security with whom I have worked and each commission of the Australian Federal Police that it is vital for their intelligence and law enforcement work that they work cooperatively with Muslim community,\" Senator Brandis said.\n\n\"And to ridicule that community to drive it into a corner, to mock its religious garments is an appalling thing to do and I would ask you to reflect on what you've done.\"\n\nSenator Brandis said he wanted to \"counsel\" Senator Hanson.\n\n\"I am not going to pretend to ignore the stunt that you have tried to pull today by arriving in the Chamber dressed in a burka when we all know that you are not an adherent of the Islamic faith. I would caution and counsel you with respect to be very, very careful of the offence you may do to the religious sensibilities of other Australians,\" he said.\n\nSenator Brandis then received a standing ovation from Labor and the Greens. Greens leader senator Richard Di Natale then stood to thank Senator Brandis for \"showing leadership\".\n\nOne Nation posted a release on its Facebook page, saying Senator Hanson \"has attended question time dressed modestly in a full burka and will later be delivering a speech in parliament calling for the government to ban full face coverings in public\".\n\nLeader of the Opposition in the Senate Penny Wong said the One Nation leader's decision to wear the burqa was \"a stunt\".\n\nXenophon praises response to 'toxic' stunt\n\nSouth Australian senator Nick Xenophon, who leads a crucial bloc of three upper house MPs, backed Senator Brandis and declared Senator Hanson's actions were \"toxic\", \"offensive\" and \"demeaning to people of the Islamic faith\".\n\n\"I believe you should respect people of other faiths. It was completely disrespectful. I know a thing or two about stunts but I wouldn't even call this a stunt, this was just toxic,\" Senator Xenophon said.\n\n\"I understand that the standing orders of the Senate as they currently exist were not breached but that's something I'm sure that those responsible for standing orders will be having another look at. \"Senator Hanson's actions were unhelpful in so many ways on so many issues.\"\n\n\"Senator Brandis spoke like a true statesman. He displayed the leadership and clarity of purpose that this country needs on issues such as this. So good on you George.\"\n\nOne Nation leader Pauline Hanson: In light of the national security of our nation, will you work to ban the burqa in Australia? (calls for order) In light of what is happening with national security, there has been 13 foiled national threats against us with terrorism, three that have been successful and Australians have lost their lives. Terrorism is a true threat to our country, many Australians are in fear of it. What I would like to ask on behalf of the Australian people considering a large majority of Australians wish to see the banning of the burka.\n\nAttorney-General George Brandis: Senator Hanson no, we will not be banning the burka. Now Senator Hanson, I'm not going to pretend to ignore the stunt that you have tried to pull today by arriving in the chamber dressed in a burka when we all know you are not an adherent of the Islamic faith. And I would caution and counsel you Senator Hanson with respect, to be very very careful of the offence you may do to the religious sensibilities you may do to other Australians. We have about half a million Australians in this country of the Islamic faith. And the vast majority of them are law abiding, good Australians and Senator Hanson is is absolutely consistent with being a good law abiding Australian and being a strict adherent Muslim.\n\nNow, Senator Hanson, for the last four years I have had responsibility preeminently among the ministers subject to the Prime Minister, for national security policy. And I can tell you Senator Hanson, it has been the advice of each director-general of security with whom I have worked and each commissioner of the Australian Federal Police with whom I have worked that it is vital for their intelligence and their law enforcement work that they work cooperatively with the Muslim community. And to ridicule that community, to drive it into a corner, to mock its religious garments is an appalling thing to do, and I would ask you to reflect on what you have done. (applause)\n\nOne Nation media release:\n\nSenator Pauline Hanson has attended question time dressed modestly in a full burqa and will later be delivering a speech in Parliament calling for the Government to ban full face coverings in public.\n\nSenator Hanson said she made the decision to attend question time in a full face covering because she believed the need to ban full face coverings in public was an important issue facing modern Australia that needed to be discussed.\n\nSenator Hanson said she wished to raise the issue of full face covering presenting a security threat not only to Parliament House, but also to the greater Australian public.\n\nSenator Hanson said that she believed that full face covering, such as the burqa, were oppressive, presented barriers to assimilation, disadvantaged women from finding employment, were causing issues inside our justice system, presented a clear security threat and had no place in modern Western society.\n\nSenator Hanson said that this was a debate that was happening across the world and Australia could not hide from a difficult conversation out of fear of causing offence.\n\nSenator Hanson is scheduled to Why is it not the same case for someone who is covering up their face and cannot be identified?\"\n\nSen Hanson, who first rose to prominence in the 1990s because of her strident opposition to immigration from Asia and to asylum seekers, has in recent years campaigned against Islamic clothing and the building of mosques.\n\nHer party has four senators, which gives it influence in parliament when closely contested legislation is being voted on.\n\nAttorney-General George Brandis rebuked Sen Hanson.\n\n\"I am not going to pretend to ignore the stunt that you have tried to pull today by arriving in the chamber dressed in a burqa,\" he said, drawing applause from members of the Senate.\n\n\"We all know that you are not adherent of the Islamic faith. {"timeCrawl": "09:03:00", "uri": "710782123", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T09:03:00Z", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "source": {"title": "Free Malaysia Today", "uri": "freemalaysiatoday.com", "id": "10786"}, "url": "http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/category/world/2017/08/17/muslim-baiter-hanson-wears-burka-in-australias-senate/", "eventUri": "eng-3368046", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368046", "body": "Hanson was unrepentant after her latest stunt, telling commercial radio: \"Is it extreme? Yes. Is it getting my message across? I hope so.\"\n\nSYDNEY: Australian anti-immigration politician Pauline Hanson caused a furore Thursday when she entered the Senate wearing a full burqa, earning a blistering rebuke from the country's top lawyer for the \"appalling\" stunt.\n\nHanson wore the Islamic garment in the chamber to highlight what she said were the security issues it posed, linking it to terrorism as fellow senators heckled her.\n\n\"Will you work to ban the burqa in Australia in light of what is happening with national security?\" she said after whipping off the garment to question Attorney-General George Brandis.\n\nShe added: \"Terrorism is a true threat to our country, many Australians are in fear of it.\"\n\nBrandis said his conservative government had no such plans, warning Hanson she risked offending the Muslim community by wearing a burka when she was not a follower of Islam.\n\n\"To ridicule that community, to drive it into a corner, to mock its religious garments is an appalling thing to do, and I would ask you to reflect on what you have done,\" he said.\n\nBrandis, his voice cracking with emotion, also said that being a strict adherent Muslim, such as those who wear the burka, was \"absolutely consistent\" with being a law-abiding citizen.\n\n\"We have about half a million Australians in this country of the Islamic faith and the vast majority of them are law-abiding, good Australians,\" he said.\n\nBrandis' remarks prompted a standing ovation from his political opponents in the Labor and Greens parties.\n\nIndependent senator Derryn Hinch labelled Hanson's conduct \"disgusting\".\n\n\"Pauline Hanson mocked the religion of some Australians... she made a mockery of an honourable place (the Senate),\" he told Sky News.\n\nLabor senator Sam Dastyari accused Hanson of stoking extremism in a poorly timed bid for \"a cheap headline\".\n\n\"In the same week that we saw white nationalism rear its ugly head in the country of our closest ally -- in that week a stunt like this gets pulled in the Australian Senate,\" he said.\n\n\"It is hurtful, it is offensive, it is wrong,\"\n\nHanson first gained prominence in the 1990s, when she warned Australia was in danger of being \"swamped by Asians\".\n\nAfter a 12-year hiatus from politics she returned in 2014, this time targeting Muslims and was elected to the Senate two years later as leader of the right-wing One Nation party.\n\nIn her first speech after returning to parliament, she said Islam was \"a culture and ideology that is incompatible with our own\".\n\nHanson was unrepentant after her latest stunt, {"timeCrawl": "17:06:00", "uri": "711012571", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T09:11:00Z", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "source": {"title": "Arab News", "uri": "arabnews.com", "id": "4355"}, "url": "http://www.arabnews.com/node/1146131/offbeat", "eventUri": "eng-3368046", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368046", "body": "DUBAI: A far-right politician attended Australia's Parliament dressed in a burqa as part of a protest against the garment, but instead was berated by fellow senators who said she was mocking a whole section of the country's population.\n\nMembers of the Parliament could be heard voicing their surprise when the leader of the right wing One Nation party, Pauline Hanson, arrived wearing the black burqa and proceeded to sit down.\n\nShe eventually removed the garment after approximately 10 minutes and said she wanted it banned on security grounds.\n\nBut Attorney-General George Brandis denounced her actions and was quick to respond to her call, stating that the Coalition Government would not be banning the burqa - a statement that was received by cheers of approval from other politicians.\n\n\"Senator Hanson, I'm not going to pretend to ignore the stunt that you have tried to pull today by arriving in the chamber dressed in a burqa when we all know you are not an adherent of the Islamic faith,\" Brandis said.\n\n\"I would caution you and counsel you, Senator Hanson, with respect, to be very very careful of the offense you may do to the religious sensibilities of other Australians... To ridicule that community, to drive it into a corner, to mock its religious garments, is an appalling thing to do and I would ask you to reflect on your behavior.\"\n\nBrandis went on to add that the intelligence agencies had already said it was more beneficial to build ties with the Muslim community rather than create divisions.\n\nBut Hanson seemed unfazed by the response to her stunt, repeating her previous claim that the burqa was a threat to security, as well as being oppressive and she said the government's refusal to ban the burqa showed it was not listening to the people.", "id": Fuming Brandis attacks Hanson over burqa stunt\n\nAttorney-General George Brandis defends Australia's half-million Muslims in a response to Senator Pauline Hanson's burqa stunt.\n\nUp Next The Keenan citizenship saga The Keenan citizenship saga The Keenan citizenship saga\n\nAfter blasting Fairfax Media for publishing a story questioning his citizenship, the Liberal MP took to social media to reveal just what his status is.\n\nMore videos Pauline Hanson's stunt\n\nThe One Nation leader has gone to great lengths to make her point, turning up to question time in a burqa.\n\nThe Queensland senator, accompanied by colleague Brian Burston, entered the Senate dressed in a black Islamic dress shortly after question time began on Thursday afternoon - her senator pin still on display.\n\nAs senators could be heard groaning and gasping at her entrance, Senate President Stephen Parry confirmed it was Senator Hanson beneath the face covering, while seeming unsure of how to officially respond to the performance.\n\nRelated Articles George Brandis pulls off his finest speech by calling out a dangerous fool Brandis cheered by Greens and Labor senators? It really happened\n\nAttorney-General George Brandis showed no hesitation.\n\nWhen Senator Hanson whipped off the garment with a dramatic flourish, exclaiming how glad she was to be free of it, and asked Senator Brandis if the government would join her in banning the burqa, he did not hold back.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"Senator Hanson, no, we will not be banning the burqa,\" he said, visibly angry, and looking at one point like he was close to tears.\n\nYou will now receive updates from Breaking News Alert Breaking News Alert\n\nGet the latest news and updates emailed straight to your inbox.\n\nBy submitting your email you are agreeing to Fairfax Media's terms and conditions and privacy policy .\n\n\"I am not going to pretend to ignore the stunt that you have tried to pull today by arriving in the chamber dressed in a burqa when we all know that you are not an adherent of the Islamic faith.\n\n\"I would caution and counsel you with respect to be very, very careful of the offence you may do to the religious sensibilities of other Australians.\"\n\n\"We have about 500,000 Australians in this country of the Islamic faith and the vast majority of them are law-abiding good Australians.\n\n\"Senator Hanson, for the last four years, I have had responsibility pre-eminently among the ministers subject to the Prime Minister for national security policy.\n\n\"And I can tell you, Senator Hanson, that it has been the advice of each director-general of security with whom I have worked and each commissioner of the Australian Federal Police with whom I have worked that it is vital for their intelligence and law enforcement work that they work co-operatively with the Muslim community, and to ridicule that community, to drive it into a corner, to mock its religious garments is an appalling thing to do.\n\n\"I would ask you to reflect on that.\"\n\nIn extraordinary scenes, Labor and Greens senators burst into spontaneous applause, before getting to their feet in enthusiastic praise, while his Coalition colleagues remained seated.\n\nSenator Hanson and Senator Burston left the chamber shortly after, to calls of \"good on you, George\" from the opposing side.\n\nBut she had made her point, reigniting a debate that flamed in 2014 when then-prime minister Tony Abbott was forced to reverse a decision by Speaker Bronwyn Bishop and Senator Parry to isolate women wearing a burqa or niqab in glass enclosures away from the public galleries.\n\nASIO head Duncan Lewis rebuked Senator Hanson earlier this year after she asked whether a terrorist threat was \"being brought in\" with Middle Eastern refugees.\n\n\"We've made it plain on a number of occasions, senator, that we have no security reason to be concerned about the wearing of a burqa other than the requirement for individuals to identify themselves to authorities, and there are regulations in place for that,\" Mr Lewis said in May.\n\nHe stood by his assessment despite criticism from One Nation and conservative members of the Coalition in the following days.\n\nIn 2014, Fairfax Media revealed ASIO had examined the issue and concluded the consequences of banning the burqa would be \"predominantly, if not wholly, negative\".\n\nThe previously secret 2011 report found a ban would increase tension and distrust between communities and provide \"further fuel for extremist propaganda, recruitment, and radicalisation efforts\".\n\nBut while politicians from across the political divide united in their praise of Senator Brandis for his swift and unwavering condemnation of her actions, Senator Hanson - whose party was recently named by the Trump administration as a threat to religious freedoms - was relishing having \"started the debate\". \"...It was a horrible feeling, I felt just cut off from the rest of the world,\" she told Radio 2GB.\n\n\"Here I am, no one can see my facial features, no one can see if I have given them a smile, or look at my eyes, or my reaction to them - isn't that a part of our society, that we have to interact with people?\n\n\"...It is foreign to us. This is not our way of life. And so many in the suburbs of Sydney, if you are honest about it, if you are not a Muslim, you really don't want to go to these places because you don't feel welcome there.\"\n\nIslamic Friendship Association of Australia spokesman Keysar Trad predicted some \"women who wear the burqa will feel hurt and will feel that they are under siege again\" by the Senator's actions.\n\n\"Why isn't Pauline Hanson supporting their right to dress as they choose?\"\n\nIslamic Council of Victoria vice-president Adel Salman said the stunt was offensive, and \"doesn't really help the debate\".\n\n\"The current discourse is really negative. It's about time [Senator Hanson] is ridiculed and her platform is ridiculed,\" he said.\n\nBoth Mr Trad and Mr Salman praised Senator Brandis' strong response.\n\nLabor, Greens and other crossbench senators, including Derryn Hinch and Nick Xenophon, called for Senator Hanson's stunt to be ignored.\n\nUndeterred, Senator Hanson took to the Senate floor later that same day to deliver a speech calling for the burqa ban and claiming Islam was \"threatening our way of life\", speaking to an almost empty room.\n\nFollow us on Facebook", "id": "9749061", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-17",
