"isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368046", "body": "It follows LNP Senator and Attorney-General George Brandis warning her to be respectful of religious sensibilities and saying ridiculing the Muslim community was \"appalling\".\n\nSenator Hanson said she wanted the government to ban \"full face coverings\" in public places.\n\n\"No one should be permitted behind a veil of secrecy while there is a security concern,\" she said.\n\n\"Our laws are outdated and we need new ones like a ban on full face coverings.\n\n\"While it is an offence in most states in Australia to be disguised with unlawful intent, it is self-evident that the two years jail is not a deterrent for a suicide bomber.\"\n\nShe said the ban was needed to prevent terrorism.\n\n\"We need laws to stop terrorism before it happens and the ability of others to see a face is an important part of assessing that risk,\" Senator Hanson said.\n\n\"Full face coverings, like a niqab or burqa, take away a valuable source of information from counter-terrorism experts and ordinary Australians.\n\n\"How can you justify the ban on wearing a helmet or a balaclava into banks but let someone wear a niqab or burqa?\"\n\nShe claimed that \"the Muslim vote\" determined the electoral outcomes in up to 15 lower house seats, before accusing Labor of \"pandering to the Muslim vote\".\n\n\"My message to those who want to live under Sharia Law is to migrate to an Islamic country but don't come here to Australia,\" she said.\n\n\"The meaning of the Islamic veil, niqab or burqa has varied over time but what has never changed is the way the wearer is separated from everyone else.\n\n\"This separation is a barrier to the formation of relationships so necessary to integrate into the Australian way of life.\n\n\"I want to say that everyone has the right to their own religious beliefs but it is only Islam that threatens our way of life.\"\n\nSenator Hanson delivered her speech to an almost empty Senate Chamber, with just two Coalition Senators, two ALP Senators, Senator Jacqui Lambie and her three One Nation colleagues present.\n\nSenator Brandis had earlier pulled her up for pulling a \"stunt\" by wearing a burqa into Senate Question Time.\n\n\"I'm not going to pretend to ignore the stunt that you have tried to pull today by arriving in the chamber dressed in burqa when we all know you are not an adherent to the Islamic faith,\" he said.\n\n\"I caution you and counsel you, Senator Hanson, with respect to be very, very careful of the offence you may give to the religious sensibilities of other Australians.\n\n\"We have about half a million Australians in this country of the Islamic faith and the vast majority of them are law abiding good Australians.\n\n\"To ridicule that community, to drive it into a corner, to mock its religious garments is an appalling thing to do.\"\n\nHe warned her attacking the Muslim community was a risk to national security.\n\n\"I can tell you, Senator Hanson, that it has been the advice of each director-general of security with whom I have worked, and each division of the Australian Federal Police with whom I have worked, that it is vital for their intelligence and law enforcement work that they work cooperatively with the Muslim community,\" Senator Brandis said.\n\nLeader of the Opposition in the Senate Penny Wong commended the Attorney-General for his response to Senator Hanson.\n\n\"The sort of bigotry and divisiveness we saw displayed by Senator Hanson today has no place in our society. It certainly has no place in our parliament,\" Senator Wong said.\n\n\"It is one thing to wear religious dress as an act of faith. It is another to wear it as a stunt. That can only give offence and divide.\n\n\"Nobody needs to defend Senator Hanson's right to speak. The people that need defending are the people she attacks.\n\n\"Leaders have an obligation to stand up for the people in Australia who do not have a voice and today the Parliament did so.\"", "id": {"timeCrawl": "10:41:00", "uri": "710826620", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T07:21:00Z", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "source": {"title": "Business Insider", "uri": "businessinsider.com", "id": "711"}, "url": "http://www.businessinsider.com/anti-immigrant-australian-senator-wears-burqa-to-parliament-2017-8", "eventUri": "eng-3368046", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368046", "body": "One Nation leader Pauline Hanson appeared in the Australian senate today wearing the full black covering of a burqa.\n\nShe wore it for several minutes until leaping to her feet when the Senate President gave her the call to ask a question asking to ban the burqa in Australia \"in light of national security.\"\n\nHanson's call is part of a long-running campaign by the controversial Queensland senator, who, when she returned to parliament last year, claimed that the country was going to be over-run with Muslims - a variation on her claim 20 years earlier that Australia was being \"swamped by Asians.\"\n\nShe claimed there was a \"large majority of Australians\" who wished to ban the burqa.\n\nIn response attorney-general George Brandis with an emphatic \"no\" and then chastised Hanson for her behavior.\n\n\"I'm not going to pretend to ignore the stunt that you have tried to pull today by arriving in the chamber dressed in a burqa when we all know that you are not an adherent of the Islamic faith,\" he said.\n\n\"I would caution you and counsel you senator Hanson, with respect, to be very, very careful of the offense you may do to the religious sensibilities of other Australians.\n\n\"We have about half a million Australians in this country of the Islamic faith and the vast majority of them are law-abiding, good Australians... It is absolutely consistent with being a good, law-abiding Australian and a strict, adherent Muslim.\"\n\nSenator Brandis said he'd had responsibility for the national security for four years and intelligence and law enforcement officials worked closely with the Muslim community.\n\nHis voice quivered with emotion as he concluded his response, saying \"To ridicule that community, to drive it into a corner, to mock its religious garments is an appalling thing to do and I would ask you to reflect on what you do.\"\n\nThe senate erupted with applause as he concluded his reply and Labor senators and many on the crossbench stood to applaud.\n\nSenate President Stephen Parry said that when Hanson entered the chamber, he confirmed her identity, and declined to comment on her attire.\n\nShe also had her red senator's pin, which identifies her as a member of the chamber, pinned to the outside of her garment.\n\nIn subsequent debate, Labor's Penny Wong said Hanson's actions were \"disgraceful\" and \"disrespectful.\"\n\n\"I make this point on behalf of all of us on this side of the chamber, it is one thing to wear religious dress as a sincere act of faith, there is another to wear it as a stunt here in the chamber,\" Wong said.\n\nAnd the attorney-general's response won praise from Labor senator Sam Dastyari, who is Muslim.\n\nWhen question time in the senate {"timeCrawl": "14:47:00", "uri": "710943430", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T14:47:00Z", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "source": {"title": "yahoo.com", "uri": "yahoo.com", "id": "228"}, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/anti-muslim-australian-senator-wears-burqa-parliament-063230341.html", "eventUri": "eng-3368046", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368046", "body": "1 / 8In this combination of photos Sen. Pauline Hanson takes off a burqa she wore into the Senate chamber at Parliament House in Canberra, Australia, Thursday, Aug. 17, 2017. Hanson, leader of the anti-Muslim, anti-immigration One Nation minor party, sat wearing the black head-to-ankle garment for more than 10 minutes before taking it off as she rose to explain that she wanted such outfits banned on national security grounds. (Lukas Coch/AAP Image via AP)\n\nCANBERRA, Australia (AP) -- An Australian senator provoked an angry backlash from lawmakers by wearing a burqa in Parliament on Thursday as part of her campaign for a national ban on Islamic face covers.\n\nPauline Hanson, leader of the anti-Muslim, anti-immigration One Nation minor party, sat wearing the black head-to-ankle garment for more than 10 minutes before taking it off as she rose to explain that she wanted such outfits banned on national security grounds.\n\n\"There has been a large majority of Australians (who) wish to see the banning of the burqa,\" said Hanson, an outspoken fan of President Donald Trump, as senators objected.\n\nAttorney-General George Brandis drew applause when he said his government would not ban the burqa, and chastised Hanson for what he described as a \"stunt\" that offended Australia's Muslim minority.\n\n\"To ridicule that community, to drive it into a corner, to mock its religious garments is an appalling thing to do and I would ask you to reflect on what you have done,\" Brandis said.\n\nOpposition Senate leader Penny Wong told Hanson: \"It is one thing to wear religious dress as a sincere act of faith; it is another to wear it as a stunt here in the Senate.\"\n\nSam Dastyari, an opposition senator and an Iranian-born Muslim, said: \"We have seen the stunt of all stunts in this chamber by Sen. Hanson.\"\n\n\"The close to 500,000 Muslim Australians do not deserve to be targeted, do not deserve to be marginalized, do not deserve to be ridiculed, do not deserve to have their faith made some political point by the desperate leader of a desperate political party,\" Dastyari said.\n\nSenate President Stephen Parry said Hanson's identity had been confirmed before she entered the chamber. He also said he would not dictate the standards of dress for the chamber.\n\nParliament House briefly segregated women wearing burqas and niqabs in 2014. The department that runs Parliament House said that \"persons with facial coverings\" would no longer be allowed in the building's open public galleries. Instead, they were to be directed to galleries usually reserved for noisy schoolchildren, where they could sit behind soundproof glass.\n\nThe policy was branded a \"burqa ban\" and was widely condemned as a segregation of Muslim women, as well as a potential breach of anti-discrimination laws.\n\nOfficials relented, allowing people wearing face coverings in all public areas of Parliament House after the coverings were removed temporarily at the building's front door so that staff can check the visitor's identity.\n\nThe reason behind the segregation was never explained, but it seems to have been triggered by a rumor on Sydney talk radio that men dressed in burqas were planning an anti-Muslim demonstration in Parliament House.", "id": "9713282", "details": {}, "date": {"timeCrawl": "09:54:00", "uri": "710804484", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T05:41:00Z", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "source": {"title": "Business Insider", "uri": "businessinsider.com", "id": "711"}, "url": "http://www.businessinsider.com/disgraceful-pauline-hanson-senate-burqa-2017-8", "eventUri": "eng-3368046", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368046", "body": "One Nation leader Pauline Hanson appeared in the Australian senate today wearing the full black covering of a burqa.\n\nShe wore it for several minutes until leaping to her feet when the Senate President gave her the call to ask a question asking to ban the burqa in Australia \"in light of national security.\"\n\nHanson's call is part of a long-running campaign by the controversial Queensland senator, who, when she returned to parliament last year, claimed that the country was going to be over-run with Muslims - a variation on her claim 20 years earlier that Australia was being \"swamped by Asians.\"\n\nShe claimed there was a \"large majority of Australians\" who wished to ban the burqa.\n\nIn response attorney-general George Brandis with an emphatic \"no\" and then chastised Hanson for her behavior.\n\n\"I'm not going to pretend to ignore the stunt that you have tried to pull today by arriving in the chamber dressed in a burqa when we all know that you are not an adherent of the Islamic faith,\" he said.\n\n\"I would caution you and counsel you senator Hanson, with respect, to be very, very careful of the offense you may do to the religious sensibilities of other Australians.\n\n\"We have about half a million Australians in this country of the Islamic faith and the vast majority of them are law-abiding, good Australians... It is absolutely consistent with being a good, law-abiding Australian and a strict, adherent Muslim.\"\n\nSenator Brandis said he'd had responsibility for the national security for four years and intelligence and law enforcement officials worked closely with the Muslim community.\n\nHis voice quivered with emotion as he concluded his response, saying \"To ridicule that community, to drive it into a corner, to mock its religious garments is an appalling thing to do and I would ask you to reflect on what you do.\"\n\nThe senate erupted with applause as he concluded his reply and Labor senators and many on the crossbench stood to applaud.\n\nSenate President Stephen Parry said that when Hanson entered the chamber, he confirmed her identity, and declined to comment on her attire.\n\nShe also had her red senator's pin, which identifies her as a member of the chamber, pinned to the outside of her garment.\n\nIn subsequent debate, Labor's Penny Wong said Hanson's actions were \"disgraceful\" and \"disrespectful.\"\n\n\"I make this point on behalf of all of us on this side of the chamber, it is one thing to wear religious dress as a sincere act of faith, there is another to wear it as a stunt here in the chamber,\" Wong said.\n\nAnd the attorney-general's response won praise from Labor senator Sam Dastyari, who is Muslim.\n\nWhen question time in the senate ended at 3pm Greens senators crossed the chamber and shook hands with senator Brandis.\n\nShe subsequently issued the following media release on Facebook:", "id": "9657276", "details": {}, "date": {"timeCrawl": "16:15:00", "uri": "710987976", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T16:15:00Z", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "source": {"title": "aljazeera.com", "uri": "aljazeera.com", "id": "3408"}, "url": "http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/08/anti-muslim-australian-politician-attempts-burqa-stunt-170817132659882.html", "eventUri": "eng-3368046", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368046", "body": "Far-right politician Pauline Henson wore face veil in parliament as part of campaign to ban the Islamic face veil.\n\nAn Australian senator provoked an angry backlash from politicians by wearing a burqa in parliament on Thursday as part of her campaign for a national ban on the Islamic face veil.\n\nPauline Hanson, leader of the anti-Muslim, anti-immigration One Nation party, sat wearing the black head-to-ankle garment for more than 10 minutes before taking it off as she rose to explain that she wanted such outfits banned on national security grounds.\n\n\"There has been a large majority of Australians [who] wish to see the banning of the burka,\" said Hanson, an outspoken fan of President Donald Trump, as senators objected.\n\nAttorney-General George Brandis drew applause when he said his government would not ban the burqa, and chastised Hanson for what he described as a \"stunt\" that offended Australia's Muslim minority.\n\nREAD MORE: Australia's grand mufti wins case against newspaper\n\n\"To ridicule that community, to drive it into a corner, to mock its religious garments is an appalling thing to do and I would ask you to reflect on what you have done,\" Brandis said.\n\nOpposition Senate leader Penny Wong told Hanson: \"It is one thing to wear religious dress as a sincere act of faith; it is another to wear it as a stunt here in the Senate.\"\n\nSam Dastyari, an opposition senator and an Iranian-born Muslim, said: \"We have seen the stunt of all stunts in this chamber by Senator Hanson.\n\n\"The close to 500,000 Muslim Australians do not deserve to be targeted, do not deserve to be marginalised, do not deserve to be ridiculed, do not deserve to have their faith made some political point by the desperate leader of a desperate political party.\"\n\nSenate President Stephen Parry said Hanson's identity had been confirmed before she entered the chamber. He also said he would not dictate the standards of dress for the chamber.\n\nGreg Barton, a professor of global Islamic politics at Deakin University, said Hanson's calls to ban the burqa enjoyed little public support.\n\n\"Pauline Henson has a long track record of demonising Asians, immigrants and indigenous Australians and this is just a cheap shot. Fortunately she doesn't speak for the majority of Australians,\" Barton told Al Jazeera.\n\n\"But she does have three fellow senators in the upper house and that is significant and cannot be ignored,\" he added.\n\nPauline Hanson's divisive stunt has no place in our parliament. Thank you George Brandis for your fine words today. #SenateQT pic.twitter.com/V2ebMwwBzF -- Senator Penny Wong (@SenatorWong)\n\nAugust 17, 2017\n\nParliament House briefly segregated women wearing burqas and niqabs in 2014.\n\nThe department that runs Parliament House said that \"persons with facial coverings\" would no longer be allowed in the building's open public galleries.\n\nInstead, they were to be directed to galleries usually reserved for noisy schoolchildren, where they could sit behind soundproof glass.\n\nThe policy was branded a \"burqa ban\" and was widely condemned as segregating Muslim women, as well as a potential breach of anti-discrimination laws.\n\nOfficials relented, allowing people wearing face coverings in all public areas of Parliament House after the coverings were removed temporarily at the building's front door so that staff can check the visitor's identity.\n\nThe reason behind the segregation was never explained, but it seems to have been triggered by a rumor on Sydney talk radio that men dressed in burqas were planning an anti-Muslim demonstration in Parliament House.", "id": "9730721", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-17", "title": {"timeCrawl": "07:23:00", "uri": "710739107", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T06:49:00Z", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "source": {"title": "Associated Press", "uri": "hosted2.ap.org", "id": "566"}, "url": "http://hosted2.ap.org/CARIE/0260ea4c3e85456b80715585ba3c7b5b/Article_2017-08-17-AS--Australia-Burqa%20Stunt/id-501b0b21e7d94ccf86b9b51715cdd82f", "eventUri": "eng-3368046", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368046", "body": "CANBERRA, Australia (AP) -- An Australian senator provoked an angry backlash from lawmakers by wearing a burqa in Parliament on Thursday as part of her campaign for a national ban on Islamic face covers.\n\nPauline Hanson, leader of the anti-Muslim, anti-immigration One Nation minor party, sat wearing the black head-to-ankle garment for more than 10 minutes before taking it off as she rose to explain that she wanted such outfits banned on national security grounds.\n\n\"There has been a large majority of Australians (who) wish to see the banning of the burka,\" said Hanson, an outspoken fan of President Donald Trump, as senators objected.\n\nAttorney-General George Brandis drew applause when he said his government would not ban the burqa, and chastised Hanson for what he described as a \"stunt\" that offended Australia's Muslim minority.\n\n\"To ridicule that community, to drive it into a corner, to mock its religious garments is an appalling thing to do and I would ask you to reflect on what you have done,\" Brandis said.\n\nOpposition Senate leader Penny Wong told Hanson: \"It is one thing to wear religious dress as a sincere act of faith; it is another to wear it as a stunt here in the Senate.\"\n\nSam Dastyari, an opposition senator and an Iranian-born Muslim, said: \"We have seen the stunt of all stunts in this chamber by Sen. Hanson.\"\n\n\"The close to 500,000 Muslim Australians do not deserve to be targeted, do not deserve to be marginalized, do not deserve to be ridiculed, do not deserve to have their faith made some political point by the desperate leader of a desperate political party,\" Dastyari said.\n\nSenate President Stephen Parry said Hanson's identity had been confirmed before she entered the chamber. {"timeCrawl": "10:41:00", "uri": "710826665", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T07:21:00Z", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "source": {"title": "The Courier Mail", "uri": "couriermail.com.au", "id": "2778"}, "url": "http://www.couriermail.com.au/news/queensland/queensland-government/pauline-hansons-burqa-speech-in-the-senate/news-story/c56122eb5545e37fad0c4a45b8af98b8", "eventUri": "eng-3368046", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368046", "body": "SENATORS across the political divide, including Labor, Coalition, Greens, Nick Xenophon and Jacqui Lambie, have called out Senator Pauline Hanson's burqa ban speech.\n\nSenator Lambie, who supports an inquiry into halal certification, said Senator Hanson was an embarrassment.\n\n\"If Senator Hanson wanted to prove it is possible for dangerous extremists to get into the Senate chambers, she proved it all right,\" she said.\n\n\"She proved Australians have something to fear - and it is her.\n\n\"Senator Hanson's stunt was to prove the need for a ban on full-face coverings. She could have made the same point by wearing a balaclava.\n\n\"What we saw today was an effort to divide all of us.\n\n\"What she has done has diminished this place and dimished us all.\n\n\"She is an absolute embarrassment.\"\n\nSenator Xenophon, who wore a onsies to parliament a few months ago, also called out Senator Hanson.\n\n\"I know a thing or two about stunts but I wouldn't consider this a stunt. This was just toxic,\" he said.\n\nLabor senator and Scottish migrant Doug Cameron said he left west Scotland to get away from religious intolerance.\n\nHe spoke of being brought up Presbyterian and marrying a Catholic at a time this was looked down on.\n\n\"I came here because I wanted to get away from religious intolerance,\" Senator Cameron said.\n\n\"I want to say to anyone who sees this: 'That is not Australia'.\n\n\"We are a secular nation, with religious freedom and tolerance.\n\n\"Senator Hanson is in here pushing this agenda for purely political reasons.\"\n\nHe said her speech was underpinned by \"racism, religious intolerance and just plain stupidity\".\n\nSenator Hanson's speech followed a stunt in which she wore a burqa into the Senate chamber, bringing condemnation from Attorney-General George Brandis.\n\nIn the speech -- delivered to an almost empty chamber with just two Coalition senators, two Labor senators, Senator Lambie and Senator Hanson's three One Nation colleagues --\n\nthe firebrand said she wanted the government to ban full-face coverings in public places.\n\n\"No one should be permitted behind a veil of secrecy while there is a security concern,\" she said.\n\n\"Our laws are outdated and we need new ones like a ban on full face coverings.\n\n\"While it is an offence in most states in Australia to be disguised with unlawful intent, it is self-evident that the two years jail is not a deterrent for a suicide bomber.\"\n\nShe said the ban was needed to prevent terrorism.\n\n\"We need laws to stop terrorism before it happens and the ability of others to see a face is an important part of assessing that risk,\" Senator Hanson said.\n\n\"Full face coverings, like a niqab or burqa, take away a valuable source of information from counter-terrorism experts and ordinary Australians.\n\n\"How can you justify the ban on wearing a helmet or a balaclava into banks but let someone wear a niqab or burqa?\"\n\nShe claimed that \"the Muslim vote\" determined the electoral outcomes in up to 15 lower house seats, before accusing Labor of \"pandering to the Muslim vote\".\n\n\"My message to those who want to live under Sharia Law is to migrate to an Islamic country but don't come here to Australia,\" she said.\n\n\"The meaning of the Islamic veil, niqab or burqa has varied over time but what has never changed is the way the wearer is separated from everyone else.\n\n\"This separation is a barrier to the formation of relationships so necessary to integrate into the Australian way of life.\n\n\"I want to say that everyone has the right to their own religious beliefs but it is only Islam that threatens our way of life.\"\n\nSenator Brandis had earlier pulled her up for pulling a \"stunt\" by wearing a burqa into Senate Question Time.\n\n\"I'm not going to pretend to ignore the stunt that you have tried to pull today by arriving in the chamber dressed in burqa when we all know you are not an adherent to the Islamic faith,\" he said.\n\n\"I caution you and counsel you, Senator Hanson, with respect to be very, very careful of the offence you may give to the religious sensibilities of other Australians.\n\n\"We have about half a million Australians in this country of the Islamic faith and the vast majority of them are law abiding good Australians.\n\n\"To ridicule that community, to drive it into a corner, to mock its religious garments is an appalling thing to do.\"\n\nHe warned her attacking the Muslim community was a risk to national security.\n\n\"I can tell you, Senator Hanson, that it has been the advice of each director-general of security with whom I have worked, and each division of the Australian Federal Police with whom I have worked, that it is vital for their intelligence and law enforcement work that they work cooperatively with the Muslim community,\" Senator Brandis said.\n\nLeader of the Opposition in the Senate Penny Wong commended the Attorney-General for his response to Senator Hanson.\n\n\"The sort of bigotry and divisiveness we saw displayed by Senator Hanson today has no place in our society. It certainly has no place in our parliament,\" Senator Wong said.\n\n\"It is one thing to wear religious dress as an act of faith. It is another to wear it as a stunt. That can only give offence and divide.\n\n\"Nobody needs to defend Senator Hanson's right to speak. The people that need defending are the people she attacks.\n\n\"Leaders have an obligation to stand up for the people in Australia who do not have a voice and today the Parliament did so.\"", "id": {"timeCrawl": "16:36:00", "uri": "710998789", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T16:36:00Z", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "source": {"title": "From the Trenches World Report", "uri": "fromthetrenchesworldreport.com", "id": "17200"}, "url": "http://fromthetrenchesworldreport.com/anti-muslim-australian-senator-wears-burqa-parliament/205414", "eventUri": "eng-3368046", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368046", "body": "CANBERRA, Australia (AP) -- An Australian senator provoked an angry backlash from lawmakers by wearing a burqa in Parliament on Thursday as part of her campaign for a national ban on Islamic face covers.\n\nPauline Hanson, leader of the anti-Muslim, anti-immigration One Nation minor party, sat wearing the black head-to-ankle garment for more than 10 minutes before taking it off as she rose to explain that she wanted such outfits banned on national security grounds.\n\n\"There has been a large majority of Australians (who) wish to see the banning of the burqa,\" said Hanson, an outspoken fan of President Donald Trump, as senators objected. Attorney-General George Brandis drew applause when he said his government would not ban the burqa, and chastised Hanson for what he described as a \"stunt\" that offended Australia's Muslim minority.\n\n\"To ridicule that community, to drive it into a corner, to mock its religious garments is an appalling thing to do and I would ask you to reflect on what you have done,\" Brandis said. Opposition Senate leader Penny Wong told Hanson: \"It is one thing to wear religious dress as a sincere act of faith; it is another to wear it as a stunt here in the Senate.\"\n\nSam Dastyari, an opposition senator and an Iranian-born Muslim, said: \"We have seen the stunt of all stunts in this chamber by Sen. Hanson.\" \"The close to 500,000 Muslim Australians do not deserve to be targeted, do not deserve to be marginalized, do not deserve to be ridiculed, do not deserve to have their faith made some political point by the desperate leader of a desperate political party,\" Dastyari said.\n\nSenate President Stephen Parry said Hanson's identity had been confirmed before she entered the chamber. He also said he would not dictate the standards of dress for the chamber. Parliament House briefly segregated women wearing burqas and niqabs in 2014. The department that runs Parliament House said that \"persons with facial coverings\" would no longer be allowed in the building's open public galleries. Instead, they were to be directed to galleries usually reserved for noisy schoolchildren, where they could sit behind soundproof glass.\n\nThe policy was branded a \"burqa ban\" and was widely condemned as a segregation of Muslim women, as well as a potential breach of anti-discrimination laws. Officials relented, allowing people wearing face coverings in all public areas of Parliament House after the coverings were removed temporarily at the building's front door so that staff can check the visitor's identity.\n\nThe reason behind the segregation was never explained, but it seems to have been triggered by a rumor on Sydney talk radio that men dressed in burqas were planning an anti-Muslim demonstration in Parliament House.", "id": "9734675", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-17", "title": "Anti-Muslim Australian senator wears burqa in Parliament | From the Trenches World {"timeCrawl": "13:27:00", "uri": "710903218", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T12:21:00Z", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "source": {"title": "Newsweek", "uri": "newsweek.com", "id": "14218"}, "url": "http://www.newsweek.com/pauline-hanson-far-right-australian-leader-shocks-wearing-burqa-senate-demands-651820", "eventUri": "eng-3368046", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368046", "body": "Pauline Hanson, the leader of Australia's right-wing One Nation party, provoked gasps in the Australian national Senate Wednesday after she entered the chamber wearing a full-length burqa to demand the item of Muslim clothing be banned.\n\nHanson, who has in the past caused controversy by saying students with disabilities should be removed from mainstream schooling, wore the full Islamic dress while waiting quietly to be called for questions. She removed the burqa, which had a conservative face mesh, with a flourish and launched into an attack on the item, which the Australian Senate will debate banning later on Thursday.\n\nRead more: Australia terrorism suspects wanted to use meat grinder to conceal explosives\n\nDaily Emails and Alerts - Get the best of Newsweek delivered to your inbox\n\nThe actions by the senator for Queensland, in northeastern Australia, have been widely dismissed as a stunt, the Australian Broadcasting Corp. reported. As Hanson removed the garment, one of her colleagues could be heard to say: \"Oh, what on earth?\"\n\nAustralia's attorney general, George Brandis, offered a stinging rebuke to Hanson's decision to wear the burqa in the chamber, coming close to tears as he accused her of undermining relations with the country's Muslim community.\n\nAustralian One Nation party leader Senator Pauline Hanson pulls off a burqa in the Senate chamber at Parliament House in Canberra, Australia, on August 17. AAP/Mick Tsikas/via REUTERS\n\n\"To ridicule that community, to drive it into a corner, to mock its religious garments is an appalling thing to do. I would ask you to reflect on that,\" he said. Brandis added that Australia would not be banning the burqa to applause from across the Senate.\n\nIn her own speech, Hanson, whose One Nation party built upon a foundation of anti-immigration populism in Australia, cited security concerns as one of her reasons for wanting to ban the burqa.\n\nSpeaking to radio 2GB, she said she had been able to enter the Senate building by having a colleague vouch for her, rather than identifying herself. She went on to claim that she feared all Australian women might one day be forced to wear burqas.\n\n\"With the amount of kids that these Muslims are having and breeding here in Australia....possibly, one day, maybe not in the next five years but further down the track, it might be [that] my daughter or grandchildren will be told, 'You must cover up,' as is the case in many countries,\" she said.\n\nHanson has repeatedly taken an anti-Muslim stance since her election in 1996. She then rose to explain why it's necessary to ban the covering on national security grounds, according to Sky News Australia.\n\nShe said the garment \"does not belong\" in Parliament, and she was \"quite happy to remove\" it.\n\n\"There has been a large majority of Australians [who] wish to see the banning of the burqa,\" she continued.\n\nBut Australian Attorney General George Brandis slammed Hanson, saying that it was a \"stunt\" that offended the country's Muslim community. \"To ridicule that community, to drive it into a corner, to mock its religious garments is an appalling thing to do and I would ask you to reflect on what you have done,\" Brandis said, Fox News reported.\n\nHanson fired back, saying she wasn't trying to mock Muslims.\n\n\"I am actually proving a point here. There was no security checks. {"timeCrawl": "10:41:00", "uri": "710826689", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T07:21:00Z", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "source": {"title": "SBS", "uri": "sbs.com.au", "id": "793"}, "url": "http://www.sbs.com.au/news/article/2017/08/17/pauline-hanson-burqa-stunt-condemned-and-slammed-toxic", "eventUri": "eng-3368046", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368046", "body": "One Nation leader Pauline Hanson shocked her fellow senators after entering the chamber during Question Time on Thursday afternoon wearing a full length burqa.\n\nThere were audible groans in the Senate as she walked in and one person was heard saying \"What on earth?\"\n\nSenator Hanson removed the burqa a few minutes later as she attempted to ask the Attorney-General a question on banning the garment altogether.\n\n\"Will the Attorney-General ban this burqa?\" she said in the Senate.\n\nSenator Brandis' passionate impromptu response to the One Nation senator's stunt earned a standing ovation from Labor and Greens senators.\n\n\"You are not an adherent of the Islamic faith,\" Senator Brandis said in a passionate response.\n\n\"I would caution you and counsel you. Be very, very careful of the offence you may give.\"\n\n\"We have about 500,000 Australians in this country of the Islamic faith. And the vast majority of them are law abiding good Australians.\"\n\nMr Brandis said that it was vital to work with the Muslim community to combat the threat of radicalisation.\n\n\"It is vital for their intelligence and law enforcement work that they work cooperatively with the Muslim community, and to ridicule that community, to drive it into a corner, to mock its religious garments is an appalling thing to do and I would ask you to reflect on what you have done.\"\n\nIndependent Derryn Hinch asked Senator Parry whether he could come into the chamber wearing fancy dress, given Senator Hanson is not a Muslim.\n\nSenator Parry said he would not interfere with what Senators wore.\n\n\"It may have been something that I did that was radical, yes it was, coming into this chamber with a burqa on but it was a case in point saying that I do not believe that at any point in time ever in the future that any full face coverings should ever be worn in this place,\" Senator Hanson later said in the chamber.\n\nShe has since moved a motion in parliament calling on the federal government to ban the burqa but it was defeated within an hour.\n\n\"The fact is wearing a burqa is not a religious requirement. Non Islamic countries like Switzerland, Norway, Germany, France, Belgium, the Netherlands, Spain, China and Russia have also banned full face coverings. Again, lawmakers believe a ban improves public safety and enables social cohesion.\n\n\"How can you justify the banning of a helmet or balaclavas but not a burqa when entering a bank?\"\n\nShe has also renewed her push for a temporary ban on Muslim immigration for at least five years.\n\n\"If we do not draw a line in the sand against immigration from Islamic countries, the influence of Muslims in this country will continue to grow and Australia will continue down the path of Islamisation.\"\n\nLabor Senator Doug Cameron spoke straight after to oppose the motion and condemn Ms Hanson's earlier stunt.\n\n\"A contribution underpinned by racism, a contribution underpinned by religious intolerance and a contribution from my point of view underpinned by just plain stupidity,\" Senator Cameron said.\n\nSenator Nick Xenophon has applauded the Attorney General's response to Pauline Hanson's burqa stunt and says it was offensive and demeaning to people of the Islamic faith.\n\n\"I know a thing or two about stunts but I wouldn't even call this a stunt, this was just toxic,\" Senator Xenophon told reporters in Canberra.\n\nOpposition leader Bill Shorten described it as a 'political circus stunt'.\n\n\"I do not believe, no matter what anyone thinks, that pulling those sorts of antics in parliament does anything other than trivialise parliament and democracy,\" Mr Shorten told reporters in Canberra.\n\nNSW Muslim MP Jihad Dib said the incident was \"calculated and divisive\".\n\nFormer health minister Sussan Ley also weighed in on Twitter.\n\nIndependent senator Cory Bernardi also weighed in on the stunt.\n\n\"I did warn you that proroguing the parliament was in national interest. {"timeCrawl": "13:26:00", "uri": "710902708", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T13:26:00Z", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "source": {"title": "Belfast Telegraph", "uri": "belfasttelegraph.co.uk", "id": "226"}, "url": "http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/Viral/an-australian-senator-wore-a-burka-into-the-chamber-as-she-argued-for-it-to-be-banned-36041511.html", "eventUri": "eng-3368046", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368046", "body": "http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/Viral/article36041505.ece/1c2d6/AUTOCROP/h342/bpanews_76ca6278-8ce7-40b0-b707-42a62fbcaab3_1\n\nThe leader of Australia's right-wing One Nation party has been strongly rebuked by her senate colleagues after she wore a burka into the chamber.\n\nPauline Hanson is not a Muslim. In fact, her party has been described in the media as anti-Muslim and anti-immigration.\n\nAs Hanson entered the chamber mid-debate, Liberal senator Jonathan Duniam could be heard saying: \"What on earth?\"\n\nWhen the time for her question came, Hanson removed the black clothing, saying: \"I'm quite happy to remove this, because this is not what should belong in this parliament,\" before calling on Malcolm Turnbull's government to ban the full face covering.\n\nLiberal Attorney-General George Brandis, representing the government in the senate, sharply rebuked her \"stunt\" saying: \"Senator Hanson, no, we will not be banning the burka.\n\n\"Now, Senator Hanson, I am not going to pretend to ignore the stunt that you have tried to pull today by arriving in the chamber dressed in a burka when we all know that you are not an adherent of the Islamic faith.\n\n\"I would caution you and counsel you, Senator Hanson, with respect, to be very, very careful of the offence you may do to the religious sensibilities of other Australians. We have about half a million Australians in this country of the Islamic faith, and the vast majority of them are law-abiding, good Australians.\"\n\nHis words received applause from most senators in the chamber, with many rising to their feet in support of his statement.\n\nSam Dastyari, an opposition senator and an Iranian-born Muslim, said: \"We have seen the stunt of all stunts in this chamber by Senator Hanson.\n\nWhen questioned on whether this type of dress, particularly when the wearer is not an adherent to the religion concerned, was acceptable, Senate president Stephen Parry said he would not dictate dress standards in the chamber, but did say Hanson's identity had been verified before she entered.\n\nAfter the incident, senators took to Twitter to share their dismay at Hanson's actions.\n\nPauline Hanson's divisive stunt has no place in our parliament. {"timeCrawl": "14:50:00", "uri": "710944372", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T14:50:00Z", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "source": {"title": "Washington Post", "uri": "washingtonpost.com", "id": "104"}, "url": "https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/worldviews/wp/2017/08/17/an-australian-senator-wore-a-burqa-in-parliament-then-called-for-a-ban-on-muslim-immigrants/", "eventUri": "eng-3368046", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368046", "body": "Australian One Nation party leader, Sen. Pauline Hanson pulls off a burqa in the Senate chamber at Parliament House on Thursday. (AAP/Mick Tsikas/via Reuters)\n\nFaceless in a long, black burqa, the woman took a front-row seat in the Australian Senate chambers Thursday and sat like that for several minutes: silent, well aware she'd caused a scene.\n\nThen she rose with a dramatic flair, whipped the veil off her bright red hair and cast the burqa to the floor, her identity revealed.\n\nThe senators behind her did not look remotely surprised. The woman was Sen. Pauline Hanson, one of Australia's most acerbic politicians, and she was about to make yet another long speech about Islam.\n\n\"I'm quite happy to remove this because it is not what should belong in this Parliament,\" Hanson said, flipping her hair back in place as she began. \"The central issue in this motion before the Senate is the right of others to see a face.\"\n\nHanson accused security guards of failing to identify her as she walked anonymously into the chambers (the Senate president denied this, according to the Associated Press). And she chastised a senator who shook her hand on the way, when he had never done so before.\n\n\"It was the burqa that drew him\" Hanson said.\n\nOver the next 20 minutes, she would warn of hypothetical burqa-clad bank robbers, of \"migrants who want to come here and change the foundation stones of our way of life,\" of a Muslim war on Christmas -- and she'd eventually demand a ban on burqas and Islamic immigration alike.\n\nShe had done this type of thing before -- if not always in costume.\n\nThe proprietor of a fish-and-chips shop at the time, Hanson first won a Parliament seat in the 1990s. She used it to accuse aboriginals of milking government benefits, and Asians of flooding Australia.\n\nBut Australia is \"one of the world's most peaceful and socially harmonious immigrant-driven countries,\" as The Washington Post once noted. Hanson lost her seat and spent long years out of power. She was jailed on charges of electoral fraud in the 2000s, though the conviction was later overturned, the Australian Broadcasting Corporation reported.\n\n[An anti-Muslim political party in Australia is rebounding]\n\nShe stunned many politicians last year, when she led her One Nation party to win four seats in the Senate by courting voters' fears of immigrants.\n\nHer first speech to the Senate, in September, ran for half an hour. Australia now \"swamped by Muslims\" Hanson told the Senate, and declared that \"Islam cannot have a significant presence in Australia if we are to live in an open, secular and cohesive society.\"\n\nAround the same time, Hanson later told an Australian radio host, she found out the Senate had no dress code and began putting together her burqa plan.\n\n\"Is it extreme? Yes,\" she said on 2GB 873 AM after Thursday's stunt. \"Is it getting my message across, I hope so.\"\n\n[An anti-immigrant group mistook empty bus seats for women wearing burqas]\n\nWhile a tiny fraction of Australians practice Islam -- let alone wear burqa -- the full-body coverings have become a target of anti-immigrant groups and politicians around the world, regardless of whether many people actually wear them. In one notable example of hysteria, a group of Norwegians became alarmed by a photo of what turned out to be empty bus seats.\n\nHanson told the radio host she found the garb \"horrible\" when she tried it on this week.\n\n\"More than just uncomfortable,\" she added. \"It's really hard to describe. I'm hiding behind something. I feel for these women that are forced to wear it.\"\n\nHanson chose to wear one, of course.\n\n\"It is clear that Muslims particularly those with extremist views have chosen to live separately from other Australians,\" she said near the end of her speech, after calling for a five-year ban on Islamic immigration.\n\n\"Islam threatens our way of life,\" she said.\n\nWhen she was done, Attorney-General George Brandis rose to reply, his voice sometimes catching as he defended his country's Muslim population.\n\n\"Senator Hanson, no, we will not be banning the burqa,\" he said. \"To ridicule that community, to drive it into a corner, to mock its religious garments, is an appalling thing to do, and I would ask you to reflect on what you have done.\"\n\nApplause then filled the chamber, despite calls for order. Hanson stood again too, as if to say something, but the clapping continued, and she remained as silent as when she'd come in, covered up.\n\nMore reading:\n\nGermany's potential burqa ban has a problem: Where are the burqas?\n\nAustria's president suggested that every woman should wear a headscarf to fight Islamophobia\n\nE.U. court says employers can ban Muslim headscarf in workplace\n\nHindu students protest burqa-wearing Muslims on campus in southern India", "id": "9713748", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-17", "title": "An Australian senator wore a burqa in Parliament {"timeCrawl": "16:02:00", "uri": "710981473", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T16:02:00Z", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "source": {"title": "lethbridgeherald.com", "uri": "lethbridgeherald.com", "id": "6076"}, "url": "http://lethbridgeherald.com/news/world-news/2017/08/17/antimuslim-australian-senator-wears-burqa-in-parliament/", "eventUri": "eng-3368046", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368046", "body": "CANBERRA, Australia - An Australian senator provoked an angry backlash from lawmakers by wearing a burqa in Parliament on Thursday as part of her campaign for a national ban on Islamic face covers.\n\nPauline Hanson, leader of the anti-Muslim, anti-immigration One Nation minor party, sat wearing the black head-to-ankle garment for more than 10 minutes before taking it off as she rose to explain that she wanted such outfits banned on national security grounds.\n\n\"There has been a large majority of Australians (who) wish to see the banning of the burqa,\" said Hanson, an outspoken fan of President Donald Trump, as senators objected.\n\nAttorney-General George Brandis drew applause when he said his government would not ban the burqa, and chastised Hanson for what he described as a \"stunt\" that offended Australia's Muslim minority.\n\n\"To ridicule that community, to drive it into a corner, to mock its religious garments is an appalling thing to do and I would ask you to reflect on what you have done,\" Brandis said.\n\nOpposition Senate leader Penny Wong told Hanson: \"It is one thing to wear religious dress as a sincere act of faith; it is another to wear it as a stunt here in the Senate.\"\n\nSam Dastyari, an opposition senator and an Iranian-born Muslim, said: \"We have seen the stunt of all stunts in this chamber by Sen. Hanson.\"\n\n\"The close to 500,000 Muslim Australians do not deserve to be targeted, do not deserve to be marginalized, do not deserve to be ridiculed, do not deserve to have their faith made some political point by the desperate leader of a desperate political party,\" Dastyari said.\n\nSenate President Stephen Parry said Hanson's identity had been confirmed before she entered the chamber. He also said he would not dictate the standards of dress for the chamber.\n\nParliament House briefly segregated women wearing burqas and niqabs in 2014. The department that runs Parliament House said that \"persons with facial coverings\" would no longer be allowed in the building's open public galleries. Instead, they were to be directed to galleries usually reserved for noisy schoolchildren, where they could sit behind soundproof glass.\n\nThe policy was branded a \"burqa ban\" and was widely condemned as a segregation of Muslim women, as well as a potential breach of anti-discrimination laws.\n\nOfficials relented, allowing people wearing face coverings in all public areas of Parliament House after the coverings were removed temporarily at the building's front door so that staff can check the visitor's identity.\n\nThe reason behind the segregation was never explained, but it seems to have been triggered by a rumour on Sydney talk radio that men dressed in burqas were planning an anti-Muslim demonstration in Parliament House.", "id": "9728030", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-17", "title": "Anti-Muslim Australian senator wears burqa in Parliament - The Lethbridge Herald - News and Sports from around Lethbridge", "image": Why is it not the same case for someone who is covering up their face and cannot be identified?\"\n\nHanson, who first rose to prominence in the 1990s because of her strident opposition to immigration from Asia and to asylum seekers, has in recent years campaigned against Islamic clothing and the building of mosques.\n\nHer party has four senators, which gives it influence in parliament when closely contested legislation is being voted on.\n\nAttorney-General George Brandis rebuked Hanson.\n\n\"I am not going to pretend to ignore the stunt that you have tried to pull today by arriving in the chamber dressed in a burqa,\" he said, drawing applause from members of the Senate.\n\n\"We all know that you are not adherent of the Islamic faith. {"timeCrawl": "16:46:00", "uri": "711002207", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T12:14:00Z", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "source": {"title": "The Irish Times", "uri": "irishtimes.com", "id": "1154"}, "url": "https://www.irishtimes.com/news/world/asia-pacific/australian-senator-rebuked-for-wearing-burka-to-parliament-1.3189373", "eventUri": "eng-3368046", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368046", "body": "The leader of Australia's rightwing One Nation party has been rebuked by the Turnbull government for entering the Senate chamber wearing a burka.\n\nPauline Hanson caused a commotion by arriving in the senate chamber for the daily question time session dressed in a black burka, which was designed to underscore a call she intended to make to ban the religious garment, citing national security concerns.\n\nBut Ms Hanson was rebuked sharply for her behaviour. The leader of the government in the senate, attorney general George Brandis, told the One Nation leader the ruling coalition had no intention of banning the burka.\n\nIn remarks that secured him a standing ovation from the opposition Labor Party, and the Greens as well as other crossbench senators, Mr Brandis warned Ms Hanson against indulging in behaviour that Muslim Australians would find offensive.\n\n\"Senator Hanson, no, we will not be banning the burka,\" Mr Brandis told the senate on Thursday. \"Senator Hanson, I'm not going to pretend to ignore the stunt that you have tried to pull today by arriving in the chamber dressed in a burka when we all know you are not an adherent of the Islamic faith.\n\n\"I would caution you and counsel you, Senator Hanson, with respect, to be very very careful of the offence you may do to the religious sensibilities of other Australians.\"\n\n\"We have about half a million Australians in this country of the Islamic faith, and the vast majority of them are law abiding, good Australians, and Senator Hanson, it is absolutely consistent with being a good law abiding Australian and a strict, adherent, Muslim.\"\n\nMr Brandis reminded Ms Hanson that as attorney general he held preeminent portfolio responsibility for national security, and the advice from intelligence agencies was clear - countering the risks of extremism required close co-operation with the Islamic community.\n\nHe rebuked Ms Hanson for causing offence to a faith community. \"To ridicule that community, to drive it into a corner, to mock its religious garments, is an appalling thing to do, and I would ask you to reflect on your behaviour.\"\n\nMs Hanson smiled throughout Mr Brandis's comments , and visibly delighted with the commotion caused by her intervention, left the senate chamber shortly after her designated question.\n\nMr Brandis's rebuke prompted Labor, Greens and some crossbenchers to stand and applaud. Some but not all government MPs also applauded but kept their seats.\n\nThe leader of the opposition in the senate, the Labor senator Penny Wong, said if the standing orders permitted, she would have issued a vote of thanks to Mr Brandis for his remarks.\n\nMs Wong, also clearly infuriated, told Ms Hanson: \"It is one thing to wear religious dress as a sincere act of faith and another to wear it here as a stunt in the Senate chamber.\"\n\nMs Hanson's call for the banning of the burka prompted disorderly interjections from across the chamber.\n\nThe One Nation leader's question was posed to Mr Brandis along the following lines: \"In light of our national security of this nation, will [the government] work with me to actually ban the burka in Australia considering there have been 13 foiled national threats against us with terrorism, three that have been successful that Australians have lost their lives?\n\n\"Terrorism is a true threat to our country. Many Australians are in fear of it. What I would like to ask on behalf of the Australian people, considering there has been a large majority of Australians wish to see the banning of the burka.\"\n\nThe Labor senator Sam Dastyari, who is of Iranian heritage, and a non-practising Muslim, shouted that Ms Hanson was a threat to national security, and a \"disgrace\".\n\nAnother Labor senator interjected that Ms Hanson would next enter the chamber wearing a white hood - a reference to white supremacist groups.\n\nMs Hanson later took to Facebook to double down on her behaviour in the parliament.\n\nHer One Nation party proposes anti-Islamic policies including a ban on Muslim immigration, and a royal commission into Islam. {"timeCrawl": "16:37:00", "uri": "711000172", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T16:37:00Z", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "source": {"title": "The Blaze", "uri": "theblaze.com", "id": "957"}, "url": "http://www.theblaze.com/news/2017/08/17/australian-senator-causes-uproar-by-wearing-islamic-veil-to-parliament/", "eventUri": "eng-3368046", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368046", "body": "Australian Sen. Pauline Hanson sent Parliament into a frenzy Thursday by entering the Senate chambers wearing a burqa, making a statement as part of her campaign to ban the traditional Islamic garb.\n\nHanson is the founder and leader of the right-wing nationalist One Nation Party, which was founded in 1997. She turned heads by entering the chamber late so her entrance would draw the maximum amount of attention.\n\nAfter sitting quietly for a short time, Hanson confronted Liberal Senate leader George Brandis, imploring him to support her efforts to ban the burqa in Australia.\n\n\"I'm quite happy to remove this, because this is not what should belong in this Parliament,\" Hanson said, according to Yahoo. \"Senator Brandis, in light of the national security of this nation, will you work with me to ban the burqa in Australia. There has been 13 foiled national threats against us with terrorism, three that have been successful, and Australians have lost their lives.\n\n\"What I would like to ask on behalf of the Australian people, considering there has been a large majority of Australians wish to see the banning of the burqa,\" Hanson said.\n\nHanson faced severe backlash and chastisement from her fellow senators for what Brandis called a \"stunt.\" Australia has a sizable Muslim population, which other senators said would be offended by the insincere use of their religious dress.\n\n\"I would caution and counsel you with respect to be very, very careful of the offense you may do to the religious sensibilities of other Australians,\" Brandis said. \"We have about 500,000 Australians in this country of the Islamic faith and the vast majority of them are law-abiding good Australians. Senator Hanson, it is absolutely consistent with being a good, law-abiding Australian and being a strict adherent Muslim.\"\n\nThe subject of Islamic terrorism has been of growing concern in Australia, with several attacks taking place that the Islamic State has claimed responsibility for. Two men were killed and three police officers shot in a hostage situation in Melbourne in June.\n\nIn 2014, an Islamic gunman took 18 people hostage in a Sydney cafe, and two people were killed before the gunman was killed by authorities. These events have increased the dialogue surrounding burqas and their implications for national security.\n\nCountries in Europe, Asia, and Africa have instituted full or partial bans of full-face veils in recent years. France and Belgium, for example, have national bans on full-face veils in public. explain that she wanted to ban such outfits on the grounds of national security.\n\nAttorney-General George Brandis drew applause when he said his government would not ban the burqa, and chastised Hanson for what he described as a \"stunt\" that offended Australia's Muslim minority.\n\n\"We have about half a million Australians in this country of the Islamic faith, and the vast majority of them are law abiding, good Australians,\" Brandis said, adding that being a good law abiding Australian was \"absolutely\" consistent with being a strict, adherent, Muslim.\n\nThe Australian officials.\n\n\"To ridicule that community, to drive it into a corner, to mock its religious garments, is an appalling thing to do, and I would ask you to reflect on your behavior,\" Brandis added.\n\nFollowing Brandis' speech, most of the Australian lawmakers gave him a standing ovation.\n\nMany Australians and media outlets also criticized Hanson's stunt as \"offensive\" and \"appalling.\"\n\nSenate President Stephen Parry said Hanson's identity had been confirmed before she entered the chamber, undermining her argument that a ban on burqas was necessary for security.", "Attorney-General George Brandis has savaged an \"appalling\" stunt by Pauline Hanson after the One Nation leader entered the Senate dressed in a burqa.\n\nThe One Nation leader pulled the stunt during question time on Thursday before a debate on banning full-face coverings in public.\n\nSenator Hanson removed the face covering to ask Attorney-General George Brandis a question about banning the burqa.\n\nAn angry Senator Brandis said the government would not consider such a ban.\n\n\"I would caution and counsel you with respect to be very, very careful of the offence you may do to the religious sensibilities of other Australians,\" he said.\n\nThe vast majority of Muslims in Australia were law-abiding, and Australia's senior security officials say it's vital for their intelligence and law enforcement work that they work cooperatively with the Muslim community, Senator Brandis said.\n\n\"To ridicule that community, to drive it into a corner, to mock its religious garments is an appalling thing to do,\" Senator Brandis said, almost moved to tears.\n\nHis emotional slap-down received applause from all sides of politics, except One Nation senators.\n\nSenator Hanson then left the chamber with her full-face covering in hand.\n\nLabor senator Penny Wong, a fierce and long-time rival of Senator Brandis, rose to congratulate him.\n\nSo too did another of his regular sparring partners, Greens leader Richard Di Natale.\n\nOpposition frontbencher Sam Dastyari, a non-practising Muslim, struck out at the \"desperate\" stunt.\n\n\"Today was embarrassing, it was insulting, it was hurtful and it was wrong,\" he told senators.\n\n\"When you pull those types stunts - when people try and trivialise other people's faith and other people's religion for the sole purpose of a cheap headline - national security is damaged, not helped.\"\n\nThe stunt came just one day after the Trump administration listed One Nation as a threat to religious freedom.\n\nSenator Hanson said full-face coverings presented a security threat to Parliament House and the Australian public.\n\n\"Doesn't the Australian people have a right to know that whoever sits in their chamber that is {"timeCrawl": "06:35:00", "uri": "710716019", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T06:35:00Z", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "source": {"title": "Mail Online", "uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "id": "214"}, "url": "http://www.dailymail.co.uk/~/article-4798228/index.html", "eventUri": "eng-3368046", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368046", "body": "CANBERRA, Aug 17 (Reuters) - Australian far-right senator Pauline Hanson wore a burqa to parliament on Thursday as part of her campaign to ban the all-enveloping garment worn by some Muslim women, drawing a quick rebuke from the government and Muslims.\n\nHanson sat in her seat in the assembly for about 20 minutes covered by the black burqa before removing it to call for them to be banned in public for national security reasons.\n\n\"I'm quite happy to remove this because this is not what should belong in this parliament,\" Hanson, who leads the far-right One Nation party, told the Senate.\n\n\"If a person who wears a balaclava or a helmet in to a bank or any other building, or even on the floor of the court, they must be removed. Why is it not the same case for someone who is covering up their face and cannot be identified?\"\n\nHanson, who first rose to prominence in the 1990s because of her strident opposition to immigration from Asia and to asylum seekers, has in recent years campaigned against Islamic clothing and the building of mosques.\n\nHer party has four senators, which gives it influence in parliament when closely contested legislation is being voted on.\n\nAttorney-General George Brandis rebuked Hanson.\n\n\"I am not going to pretend to ignore the stunt that you have tried to pull today by arriving in the chamber dressed in a burqa,\" he said, drawing applause from members of the Senate.\n\n\"We all know that you are not adherent of the Islamic faith. I would caution and counsel you with respect to be very, very careful of the offence you may do to the religious sensibilities of other Australians.\"\n\nAdel Salman, vice president of the Islamic Council of Victoria state, said Hanson's action was \"a mockery of her position\".\n\n\"It is very disappointing, but not surprising as she has sought to mock the Islamic faith time and time again.\" {"timeCrawl": "14:06:00", "uri": "710922747", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T10:14:00Z", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "source": {"title": "The Irish News", "uri": "irishnews.com", "id": "7055"}, "url": "http://www.irishnews.com/magazine/daily/2017/08/17/news/an-australian-senator-wore-a-burka-into-the-chamber-as-she-argued-for-it-to-be-banned-1113467/", "eventUri": "eng-3368046", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368046", "body": "The leader of Australia's right-wing One Nation party has been strongly rebuked by her senate colleagues after she wore a burka into the chamber.\n\nPauline Hanson is not a Muslim. {"timeCrawl": "16:03:00", "uri": "710982267", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T16:03:00Z", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "source": {"title": "Spokesman.com", "uri": "spokesman.com", "id": "2267"}, "url": "http://www.spokesman.com/stories/2017/aug/17/australian-senator-wore-a-burqa-in-parliament-then/", "eventUri": "eng-3368046", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368046", "body": "Faceless in a long black burqa, the woman took a front-row seat in the Australian Senate chambers Thursday and sat like that for several minutes: silent, well aware she'd caused a scene.\n\nThen she rose with a dramatic flair, whipped the veil off her bright red hair and cast the burqa to the floor, her identity revealed.\n\nThe senators behind her did not look remotely surprised. The woman was Sen. Pauline Hanson, one of Australia's most acerbic politicians, and she was about to make yet another long speech about Islam.\n\n\"I'm quite happy to remove this because it is not what should belong in this Parliament,\" Hanson said, flipping her hair back in place as she began. \"The central issue in this motion before the Senate is the right of others to see a face.\"\n\nHanson said no security guards had tried to identify her as she walked anonymously into the chambers (the Senate president denied this, according to the Associated Press). And she chastised a senator who shook her hand on the way, when he had never done so before.\n\n\"It was the burqa that drew him\" Hanson said.\n\nOver the next 20 minutes, she would warn of hypothetical burqa-clad bank robbers, of \"migrants who want to come here and change the foundation stones of our way of life,\" of a Muslim war on Christmas - and she'd eventually demand a ban on burqas and Islamic immigration alike.\n\nShe had done this type of thing before, if not always in costume.\n\nThe proprietor of a fish-and-chips shop at the time, Hanson first won a Parliament seat in the 1990s. She used it to accuse aboriginals of milking government benefits, and Asians of flooding Australia.\n\nBut Australia is \"one of the world's most peaceful and socially harmonious immigrant-driven countries,\" as The Washington Post once noted. Hanson lost her seat and spent long years out of power. She was jailed on charges of electoral fraud in the 2000s, though the conviction was later overturned, the Australian Broadcasting Corporation reported.\n\nShe stunned many politicians last year, when she led her One Nation party to win four seats in the Senate by courting voters' fears of immigrants.\n\nHer first speech to the Senate, in September, ran for half an hour. Australia is now \"swamped by Muslims\" Hanson told the Senate, and declared that \"Islam cannot have a significant presence in Australia if we are to live in an open, secular and cohesive society.\"\n\nAround the same time, Hanson later told an Australian radio host, she found out the Senate had no dress code and began putting together her burqa plan.\n\n\"Is it extreme? Yes,\" she said on 2GB 873 AM after Thursday's stunt. \"Is it getting my message across? I hope so.\"\n\nWhile a tiny fraction of Australians practice Islam, let alone wear burqas, the full-body coverings have become a target of anti-immigrant groups and politicians around the world, regardless of whether many people actually wear them. In one notable example of hysteria, a group of Norwegians became alarmed by a photo of what turned out to be empty bus seats.\n\nHanson told the radio host she found the garb \"horrible\" when she tried it on this week.\n\n\"More than just uncomfortable,\" she said. \"It's really hard to describe. I'm hiding behind something. I feel for these women that are forced to wear it.\"\n\nHanson chose to, of course.\n\n\"It is clear that Muslims particularly those with extremist views have chosen to live separately from other Australians,\" she said near the end of her speech, after calling for a five-year ban on Islamic immigration.\n\n\"Islam threatens our way of life,\" she said.\n\nWhen she was done, Attorney-General George Brandis rose to reply, his voice sometimes catching as he defended his country's Muslim population.\n\n\"Senator Hanson, no, we will not be banning the burqa,\" he said. \"To ridicule that community, to drive it into a corner, to mock its religious garments, is an appalling thing to do, and I would ask you to reflect on what you have done.\"\n\nApplause then filled the chamber, despite calls for order. Hanson stood again too, as if to say something, but the clapping continued, and she remained as silent as when she'd come in, covered up.", "id": "9728295", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-17", {"timeCrawl": "13:57:00", "uri": "710918169", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T13:57:00Z", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "source": {"title": "Edmonton Sun", "uri": "edmontonsun.com", "id": "1063"}, "url": "http://www.edmontonsun.com/2017/08/17/australian-senator-pauline-hanson-criticized-for-burka-stunt-we-have-seen-the-stunt-of-all-stunts?utm_source=facebook&utm_medium=recommend-button&utm_campaign=Australian senator Pauline Hanson criticized for burka stunt: 'We have seen the stunt of all stunts'", "eventUri": "eng-3368046", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368046", "body": "CANBERRA, Australia -- An Australian senator provoked an angry backlash from lawmakers by wearing a burqa in Parliament on Thursday as part of her campaign for a national ban on Islamic face covers.\n\nPauline Hanson, leader of the anti-Muslim, anti-immigration One Nation minor party, sat wearing the black head-to-ankle garment for more than 10 minutes before taking it off as she rose to explain that she wanted such outfits banned on national security grounds.\n\n\"There has been a large majority of Australians (who) wish to see the banning of the burka,\" said Hanson, an outspoken fan of President Donald Trump, as senators objected.\n\nAttorney-General George Brandis drew applause when he said his government would not ban the burqa, and chastised Hanson for what he described as a \"stunt\" that offended Australia's Muslim minority.\n\n\"To ridicule that community, to drive it into a corner, to mock its religious garments is an appalling thing to do and I would ask you to reflect on what you have done,\" Brandis said.\n\nOpposition Senate leader Penny Wong told Hanson: \"It is one thing to wear religious dress as a sincere act of faith; it is another to wear it as a stunt here in the Senate.\"\n\nSam Dastyari, an opposition senator and an Iranian-born Muslim, said: \"We have seen the stunt of all stunts in this chamber by Sen. Hanson.\"\n\nFULL INTERVIEW @PM_Live @PaulineHansonOZ with @PMOnAir\n\nFULL SPEECH https://t.co/kVyYEVQbS3 #PaulineHanson #auspolhttps://t.co/gKZBgja9Mj -- Pauline Hanson (@PaulineHansonOz)\n\nAugust 17, 2017\n\n\"The close to 500,000 Muslim Australians do not deserve to be targeted, do not deserve to be marginalized, do not deserve to be ridiculed, do not deserve to have their faith made some political point by the desperate leader of a desperate political party,\" Dastyari said.\n\nSenate President Stephen Parry said Hanson's identity had been confirmed before she entered the chamber. He also said he would not dictate the standards of dress for the chamber.\n\nParliament House briefly segregated women wearing burqas and niqabs in 2014. The department that runs Parliament House said that \"persons with facial coverings\" would no longer be allowed in the building's open public galleries. Instead, they were to be directed to galleries usually reserved for noisy schoolchildren, where they could sit behind soundproof glass.\n\nThe policy was branded a \"burqa ban\" and was widely condemned as a segregation of Muslim women, as well as a potential breach of anti-discrimination laws.\n\nOfficials relented, allowing people wearing face coverings in all public areas of Parliament House after the coverings were removed temporarily at the building's front door so that staff can check the visitor's identity.\n\nThe reason behind the segregation was never explained, but it seems to have been triggered by a rumour on Sydney talk radio that men dressed in burqas were planning an anti-Muslim demonstration in Parliament House.", "id": "9703143", "details": {}, "date": {"timeCrawl": "21:22:00", "uri": "711120287", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T21:22:00Z", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "source": {"title": "The Straits Times", "uri": "straitstimes.com", "id": "611"}, "url": "http://www.straitstimes.com/asia/australianz/aussie-senator-dons-burqa-in-parliament-in-push-for-its-ban", "eventUri": "eng-3368046", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368046", "body": "SYDNEY * Australian anti-immigration politician Pauline Hanson caused a furore yesterday when she entered the Senate wearing a full burqa, earning a blistering rebuke from the country's top lawyer for the \"appalling\" stunt.\n\nMs Hanson wore the all-enveloping garment worn by some Muslim women for 20 minutes before removing it in the Chamber to highlight what she said were the security issues it posed, linking it to terrorism as fellow senators heckled her.\n\n\"Will you work to ban the burqa in Australia in light of what is happening with national security?\" she said after whipping off the garment to question Attorney-General George Brandis, adding: \"Terrorism is a true threat to our country. Many Australians are in fear of it.\"\n\nMr Brandis said his conservative government had no such plans, warning Ms Hanson that she risked offending the Muslim community by wearing a burqa as a non-Muslim.\n\nGet The Straits Times\n\nnewsletters in your inboxSign Up\n\n\"To ridicule that community, to drive it into a corner, to mock its religious garments is an appalling thing to do and I would ask you to reflect on what you have done,\" he said.\n\nMr Brandis, his voice cracking with emotion, also said that being a strict adherent Muslim was \"absolutely consistent\" with being a law-abiding citizen.\n\n\"We have about half a million Australians in this country of the Islamic faith and the vast majority of them are law-abiding, good Australians,\" he said, prompting a standing ovation from his political opponents in the Labor and Greens parties.\n\nPOORLY TIMED\n\nIn the same week that we saw white nationalism rear its ugly head in the country of our closest ally - in that week a stunt like this gets pulled in the Australian Senate... It is hurtful, it is offensive, it is wrong.\n\nMR SAM DASTYARI, Labor senator, on Ms Hanson's move in the context of US events.\n\nCAUSING A STIR\n\nPauline Hanson mocked the religion of some Australians... She made a mockery of an honourable place (the Senate).\n\nMR DERRYN HINCH, independent senator, who called her conduct \"disgusting\".\n\nIndependent senator Derryn Hinch labelled Ms Hanson's conduct as \"disgusting\".\n\n\"Pauline Hanson mocked the religion of some Australians... She made a mockery of an honourable place (the Senate),\" he told Sky News.\n\nLabor senator Sam Dastyari accused Ms Hanson of stoking extremism for \"a cheap headline\".\n\n\"In the same week we saw white nationalism rear its ugly head in the country of our closest ally - in that week a stunt like this gets pulled in the Australian Senate,\" he said. \"It is hurtful, it is offensive, it is wrong.\"\n\nMs Hanson first gained prominence in the 1990s, when she warned Australia was in danger of being \"swamped by Asians\". After a 12-year hiatus from politics she returned in 2014, this time targeting Muslims, and was elected to the Senate two years later as leader of the right-wing One Nation party.\n\nIn her first speech after returning to Parliament, she said Islam was \"a culture and ideology that is incompatible with our own\".\n\nMs Hanson was unrepentant after her latest stunt, telling commercial radio: \"Is it extreme? Yes. Is it getting my message across? I hope so.\"\n\nHer party has four senators, which gives it influence when closely contested legislation is being voted on.\n\nAGENCE FRANCE-PRESSE, REUTERS", "id": "9779293", "details": {}, "date": Credit - Australian Parliament House via Storyful6:38\n\nOne Nation's Pauline Hanson has come under fire from her for wearing a burqa in the Australian Senate on Thursday. When Hanson entered the Senate chambers on August 17, audible gasps could be heard from other Senators. Hanson, in a press release, said she attended Question Time \"dressed modestly in a full burqa\" to call for the government to ban full face coverings in public, arguing burqas were a national security risk. When it was her turn to present a question to Attorney-General George Brandis, she stood up and removed the burka, and asked the AG if the government planned to ban the garment which is worn by some Muslim women. Brandis said the government had no plans to ban the wearing of burqas. He then said Hanson's attire was a \"stunt\", adding it was \"appalling\" and offensive towards the Muslim community, whom he said co-operated with law enforcement and security agencies in Australia. \"To ridicule that community, to drive it into a corner, to mock its religious attire is an appalling thing to do,\" Brandis said, before the left side of the chamber erupted in applause. Hanson's stunt has put her One Nation party back in the spotlight after a US State Department report published on August 16 warned her policy of banning Muslim immigration was a threat to religious freedom in Australia. Hanson.\"\n\n\"The close to 500,000 Muslim Australians do not deserve to be targeted, do not deserve to be marginalized, do not deserve to be ridiculed, do not deserve to have their faith made some political point by the desperate leader of a desperate political party,\" Dastyari said.\n\nSenate President Stephen Parry said Hanson's identity had been confirmed before she entered the chamber. He also said he would not dictate the standards of dress for the chamber.\n\nParliament House briefly segregated women wearing burqas and niqabs in 2014. The department that runs Parliament House said that \"persons with facial coverings\" would no longer be allowed in the building's open public galleries. Australia.\n\nGeorge Brandis, Australia's attorney-general, hit back at Hanson, who leads the far-right One Nation party.\n\nHe claimed the government had no plans to ban the burqa and it was offensive to the Muslim community, whose co-operation was needed by police and security agencies.\n\n\"To ridicule that community, to drive it into a corner, to mock its religious attire is an
