Some politicians have gained reputations -- good and bad -- for pushing the boundaries of acceptable behaviour by elected representatives and Pauline Hanson is one of them. She is the leader of the rightwing One Nation party and caused a ruckus when she entered the Senate chamber wearing a black burqa. She has called for a ban on the wearing of the burqa on the grounds of national security, and quickly drew the ire and the admonishments of a basket of other parties representatives.\n\nThe leader of the government in the Senate told Hanson that the ruling coalition had no intention of banning the burqa and that her actions were likely to be found offensive by Australian Muslims. There are around half a million Australian Muslims and they already face a rise in discrimination against them. The Speaker pointed out that countering the risks relative to extremism required the cooperation of the Muslim community. Banning the burqa was unlikely to do much to further that goal.\n\nAlthough Hanson's behaviour was offensive, ill judged and bizarre it is far from unique among politicians worldwide that are increasingly confident in advancing an anti-Muslim agenda. There may even be Senate members that were quietly supportive of her as not all members applauded the put-downs that came her way. There is a troubling and global swing to the political right, and events in Charlottesville less than a week ago and the equivocal initial response of President Trump tell us that extremism can and does reach the top. {"timeCrawl": "04:51:00", "uri": "711252654", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T00:36:00Z", "sim": 0.5333333611488342, "source": {"title": "ABC News", "uri": "abc.net.au", "id": "19269"}, "url": "http://www.abc.net.au/news/2017-08-18/pauline-hanson-burqa-stunt-disproved-her-point/8819162", "eventUri": "eng-3368046", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368046", "body": "When Pauline Hanson shrugged off her burka costume, revealing her smug face revelling in the attention, it barely caused a ripple in the lives of Australian Muslim women.\n\nIt was if amnesia had taken hold. Forgetting that Muslim women had long ago been boiled down to a reduction, a caricature of oppression. That Muslim women had been fought over through the narratives of liberation, in the wars of culture, the lightning rod in the clash of civilisation debates.\n\nMany Australian Muslim women have repeatedly raised concerns with the same parliamentarians who rebuked Ms Hanson, over the political rhetoric used by them when they have discussed issues such as terrorism, free speech and refugees.\n\nWe have grown to expect false consultations, reports on Australian values and citizenship, insincere platitudes and empty reassurances.\n\nThere is no power to fight the burden that falls on Muslim women to engage with racists, as if their racism was one big misunderstanding.\n\nI'm expected to listen patiently to racists that lecture me on my religion, to debate neo-nazis, to participate in campaigns such as to \"hug a Muslim\" or \"date a Muslim\". Indeed, even large Muslim organisations and Muslim leaders advocate that narrative. To jump through hoops, with a pretty smile on my face, so that a common humanity is recognised.\n\nWhen a terrorist incident occurs overseas, Australian Muslim women modify their behaviour in public and restrict their participation in public spaces.\n\nAt all times, we remain acutely aware of our safety and the safety of our children in public.\n\nThe food we eat, where we live, our relationship: they are all heavily politicised, lest of all our bodies and our dress.\n\nThis is our normal. This is our reality. As is the acceptance that we are politically disposable. We are entirely aware that we are a form of political currency, the value of which is dictated by the context.\n\nFor Hanson, it was the star attraction in a stunt more closely resembling a year 12 muck-up day prank.\n\nSenator George Brandis has been congratulated for (finally) calling out Ms Hanson's hate speech; but he is not an anti-racism hero.\n\nEven in his condemnation of Ms Hanson, he stressed that every single head of intelligence and Australian Federal Police commissioner has stressed how vital Australian Muslims are to Australia's national security. Time and time again, Muslims are viewed purely though a prism of security, where we are policed, our belonging questioned and our loyalties demanded.\n\nThe default position is to suspect us unless we have demonstrated our loyalty against an ever shifting line in the sand.\n\nMany prominent Muslim advocates and \"leaders\" contribute to this binary to further their own agendas.\n\nThey should take heed of the comments made by Brandis: \"that it is consistent with being a good law abiding citizen and a strict adherent Muslim\".\n\nI was not surprised to watch Ms Hanson play dress-up, nor her dressing down by Brandis. Using our Parliament as an act of political theatre was not invented by Ms Hanson; nor will she be the last actor on its stage.\n\nIt is surprising that Brandis and Co are that shocked over Hanson's stunt. How could they expect anything less?\n\nThe political leadership in this country has allowed the cultivation and festering of the conditions that gave birth to Ms Hanson and her supporters.\n\nIt is far easier condemning dangerous right-wing ideology when it comes from outside your own political party.\n\nThe risk is that when the Senate resumes, the underlying racism that is fuelling this fire will still be burning. It is a fire that threatens to disintegrate the bonds that bind us as Australians.\n\nIronically, Ms Hanson demonstrated that the very security reforms she is erroneously pushing are effective and adaptable.\n\nMs Hanson was processed through the security checkpoints inside Parliament House and had her identification confirmed before entering Parliament.\n\nIn a strange and glorious twist of fate, Hanson demonstrated that a woman's choice of dress does not impede their ability to participate in our Parliament and contribute to the process of democratic decision-making.\n\nMs Hanson gave hope to little Hijabis and Niqaabis everywhere. Of course, little Hijabis and Niqaabis already know that.\n\nIt was more of a lesson for those who doubted it in the first place.", "id": "9824076", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-18", "title": "storyUri": "eng-3368046", "body": "Senator Pauline Hanson has been widely condemned after wearing a full-length black burka as part of her campaign to have it banned.\n\n\"We have a national security risk here, we need to address it,\" Ms Hanson said.\n\n\"The burka is not accepted by the majority of Australians, they find it confronting and they don't want the burka.\"\n\nShe claimed the garment was \"not Australian\" and that wearing it \"is incompatible with our culture and our way of life\".\n\n\"If people want to live in a country wearing the full burka, which is not a religious requirement, then go back to an Islamic country where you can wear that,\" she said.\n\nThere are around half a million people of Islamic faith living in Australia and her call for a ban on the burka was met with a swift rebuttal from her fellow parliamentarians.\n\nThe country's attorney-general, George Brandis, said the government had no plans to introduce a ban and criticised her actions.\n\n\"To ridicule that community, to drive it into a corner, to mock its religious garments, is an appalling thing to do and I would ask you to reflect on what you have done,\" Mr Brandis said.\n\nMs Hanson is the leader of Australia's One Nation party, which is anti-Muslim and anti-immigration.\n\nSpeaking to Sky News, she claimed her identity was not checked before she went into parliament and said terrorists could use burkas to avoid detection.\n\nBut her statement contradicts that of Australia's senate president, Stephen Parry, who said her identity was confirmed before she entered the chamber.\n\nMs Hanson blamed political correctness for Australia's unwillingness to introduce a burka ban as, she claimed, many other countries around the world have already done.\n\nShe also rejected claims her actions were a stunt to raise her profile and reinforce her reputation with her base in Queensland.\n\n\"It was proving a point,\" she said. \"It was lack of {"timeCrawl": "03:01:00", "uri": "711220860", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T03:01:00Z", "sim": 0.5137255191802979, "source": {"title": "Saudi Gazette", "uri": "saudigazette.com.sa", "id": "5204"}, "url": "http://saudigazette.com.sa/article/515295/Opinion/Editorial/Australia", "eventUri": "eng-3368046", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368046", "body": "As political stunts go the appearance of an Australian far-right politician in the Canberra parliament wearing a burqa is hard to beat.\n\nWhen Pauline Hanson, leader of the Islamophobic One Nation party walked in completely cover in black there were gasps from assembled legislators and one was heard to cry, \"Oh, what on earth!\".\n\nThe speaker of the House of Representatives might have been tempted to order the racist politician from the chamber and will surely be seeking to find out how security had permitted Hanson to enter in this attire. But it was probably a good thing that this woman was allowed to stay and hear the reaction of virtually every other MP to her outrageous mockery of Islam. Indeed she had probably been hoping that she would be expelled, which would have allowed her to claim she had been victimized.\n\nInstead after she had delivered a stumbling speech endeavoring to justify her conduct and calling for the burqa to be banned, she was exposed to withering criticism from all sides of the house.\n\nThe condemnation was led by the government's Attorney General George Brandis. The Australian parliament is known for the scathing comments and rudeness that members dish out to each other. Yet however much anger and contempt he may have felt for Hanson's wicked piece of theater, Brandis was notably moderate in his response, but that very moderation gave his words extra power.\n\nHe said that the racist politician's actions had risked the more than half a million Muslims in Australia's population. To ridicule this community, to mock its religious garments was an appalling conduct and he suggested she reflect on what she had done. He concluded by telling her that the government of Malcolm Turnbull in which he served had no intention of banning the burqa.\n\nHanson, who had sat awkwardly throughout Brandis' dignified skewering of her insulting stunt and objectionable racist policies, then had to endure a rare demonstration of parliamentary unity when all opposition politicians joined government members in standing and applauding the attorney-general's words.\n\nThere is an argument that the election of bigots like Hanson, Gert Wilders in the Netherlands and Marine Le Pen in France has the benefit of exposing the contorted, ugly face of intolerance for all the world to see. Their poisonous propaganda when exposed to public view in national legislatures can be seen for the disfiguring threat it poses to all decent and civilized values. Had Hanson been thrown out of the chamber in Canberra she would have carped on about her right of free speech. Perhaps she was so hesitant in delivering her bile-filled speech against the wearing of the burqa because she had not expected she would be given the opportunity to make it.\n\nBut there is one still very recent lesson from a Europe that prided itself on its sophistication and political maturity, which cannot be ignored. Hitler's Nazi party came to power through the ballot box and in and out of parliament it made no secret of its hatred for Jews. Democracies wring their hands about the right of free speech and insist that even the most deplorable views deserve to be heard. But who would now deny that if there had been an undemocratic way to stop Hitler's Nazis from seizing power and replacing democracy with dictatorship, it should have been taken?", "id": "9813093", {"timeCrawl": "05:55:00", "uri": "710702735", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T05:55:00Z", "sim": 0.501960813999176, "source": {"title": "Stock & Land", "uri": "stockandland.com.au", "id": "13129"}, "url": "http://www.stockandland.com.au/story/4863015/george-brandis-pulls-off-his-finest-speech-by-calling-out-a-dangerous-fool/", "eventUri": "eng-3368046", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368046", "body": "ASIO head Duncan Lewis says it until he's blue in the face. His predecessor David Irvine was just as staunch.\n\nAustralia's Muslim communities are the best ally our security agencies have in their fight against violent Islamist extremism. Alienating them only severs a vital conduit of intelligence and potentially breeds more angry, isolated people vulnerable to corrupted views.\n\nThat is why Attorney-General George Brandis' thundering condemnation of Pauline Hanson's burqa stunt in the Senate on Thursday afternoon was not just a moment of fine moral and political clarity, it was also bloody common sense.\n\nSenator Brandis said Australia's half-million Muslims - the \"vast majority of [whom] are good, law-abiding Australians\" - are vital to intelligence and law enforcement agencies.\n\n\"And to ridicule that community, to drive it into a corner, to mock its religious garments, is an appalling thing to do and I would ask you to reflect on what you have done.\"\n\nSenator Brandis was so angry his voice was actually wobbling with emotion.\n\nRightly so. Senator Brandis, who is a liberal rather than a conservative, has spent the past four years wrestling with how to balance liberty with security.\n\nHe knows - based on genuine expert views - more about the risks of terrorism than virtually anyone else in the country, not least Senator Hanson.\n\nAnd he knows it is absurd to argue we would be safer by banning the burqa on the grounds people would be compelled to show their faces at all times, when weighed against the damage that would be done by infringing the religious rights of a targetted group of Australians.\n\nYes, Australians. That's what they are and that's what Senator Brandis called them in his short but impassioned speech that earned a standing ovation from Labor and the Greens.\n\nAt a time when the President of the United States cannot bring himself to unequivocally condemn neo-Nazis, when the government is on the ropes and when populist right-wing movements are on the march around the world, Senator Brandis did not insert one caveat into his condemnation.\n\nHe called it out for what it was: pointless, stupid and even dangerous division at a time when Australia needs anything but.\n\nThe story George Brandis {"timeCrawl": "08:15:00", "uri": "710760862", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T08:15:00Z", "sim": 0.501960813999176, "source": {"title": "The New Zealand Herald", "uri": "nzherald.co.nz", "id": "1424"}, "url": "http://www.nzherald.co.nz/world/news/article.cfm?c_id=2&objectid=11906135", "eventUri": "eng-3368046", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368046", "body": "One Nation senator Pauline Hanson has been called many things but uncontroversial is not one of them.\n\nThe party founder and leader today carried out what may go down in history as her most outrageous stunt yet. Ms Hanson, who has ferociously campaigned against multiculturalism, took her seat during question time wearing a full burqa ahead of a debate on banning full-face coverings in public.\n\nPoliticians and senators were united in condemning the political stunt as religious mockery.\n\n\"To mock its religious garment is an appalling thing to do and I would ask you to reflect on what you've done,\" Attorney-General George Brandis told Ms Hanson before she removed the burqa and left the chamber with it in hand.\n\nThe former fish and chip shop owner and Dancing with the Stars finalist has become infamous for her political stunts and controversial remarks, some of which critics have labelled racist.\n\nShe first came to prominence after she was disendorsed as a Liberal candidate in 1996 for making racist comments about Aboriginal Australians but secured a victory in the Queensland lower house seat of Oxley anyway because she still appeared on the ballot paper.\n\nIt was during her maiden speech to Parliament in 1996 that she uttered her now infamous words: \"I believe we are in danger of being swamped by Asians\".\n\n\"They have their own culture and religion, form ghettos and do not assimilate,\" Ms Hanson continued.\n\n\"Of course, I will be called racist but, if I can invite whom I want into my home, then I should have the right to have a say in who comes into my country.\n\n\"A truly multicultural country can never be strong or united.\"\n\nBut that was just the beginning.\n\nMs Hanson later appeared in an interview on 60 Minutes when reporter Tracey Curro asked her if she was xenophobic.\n\n\"Please explain?\" she responded.\n\nThe remark became a popular catchphrase that is still used by Australians today. It was also appropriated by satirical character Pauline Pantsdown, played by Simon Hunt, in the song I Don't Like It, which reached the Australian Top 10 charts.\n\nThe following year, Ms Hanson made a video to be released to the public in the event of her assassination. She feared her stance on immigration put her life in danger after launching a new political party, One Nation, in 1997.\n\n\"Fellow Australians, if you are seeing me now it means that I have been murdered,\" Ms Hanson said staring down the barrel of the camera.\n\n\"Do not let my passing distract you even for a moment. For the sake of our children and our children's children, you must fight on.\"\n\nThe \"voice from the grave\" video came after Prime Minister John Howard had been advised to wear a bulletproof vest as he spoke in rural Victoria because of his tough new gun policy in the wake of the Port Arthur massacre. Ms Hanson's video was subsequently derided as a cheap political stunt.\n\nMs Hanson described South African migrants to Australia as having AIDS during a statement about returning to politics following a hiatus.\n\n\"We're bringing in people from South Africa at the moment. There's a huge amount coming into Australia, who have diseases; they've got AIDS,\" she said in 2006.\n\n\"They are of no benefit to this country whatsoever; they'll never be able to work. And what my main concern is: is the diseases that they're bringing in and yet no one is saying or doing anything about it.\"\n\nMs Hanson heralded her political comeback in 2016 by warning Australia was at risk of being \"swamped by Muslims\".\n\nIt was a reference to her maiden speech to Parliament in 1996, in which she made the same claim about Asians.\n\nThe One Nation leader repeated her call for a ban on Muslim immigration and warned Australians would eventually be forced to live under sharia law if something did not change.\n\n\"We are in danger of being swamped by Muslims who bear a culture and ideology that is incompatible with our own,\" she said.\n\nMs Hanson again raised eyebrows when she incorrectly declared there was \"no definition to an Aboriginal\".\n\n\"You know, there's no definition to an Aboriginal,\" Ms Hanson said in a 2016 interview on the Bolt Report.\n\n\"If you marry an Aboriginal, you can be classified as an Aboriginal.\n\n\"Or if the community or the elders accept you into that community, you can be defined as an Aboriginal.\n\n\"And that's not good enough, because then if you make a comment about it, well what are you - are you an Aboriginal, or not an Aboriginal?\"\n\nThe Federal Government defines an Aboriginal person as someone of Aboriginal descent, who identifies as Aboriginal and is accepted as such by the community in which they live.\n\nMs Hanson called for a debate into the definition.\n\nMs Hanson was last year forced to address rumours she was fixated on US President Donald Trump.\n\nThe accusations came after she revealed she had secured tickets to the US President's inauguration and gushed that \"I can see in Donald Trump a lot of me and what I stand for in Australia ... I think he's great\".\n\nShe later tweeted: \"Mr President my door will always be open.\"\n\nHer praise was so effusive she told Karl Stefanovic on Channel 9's Today: \"I swear to God I don't have a crush on Donald Trump\".", "id": "9640191", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-17", "title": "Pauline Hanson's most controversial moments", "image": {"timeCrawl": "19:08:00", "uri": "711064505", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T19:08:00Z", "sim": 0.501960813999176, "source": {"title": "ABC News", "uri": "abc.net.au", "id": "19269"}, "url": "http://www.abc.net.au/news/2017-08-18/pauline-hansons-burka-stunt-damaging-for-national-security/8818226", "eventUri": "eng-3368046", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368046", "body": "National security experts say One Nation Senator Pauline Hanson's burka stunt may undermine intelligence agency ASIO's work with Islamic communities.\n\nSenator Hanson wore the full Islamic dress during Question Time on Thursday and called on the Federal Government to ban it.\n\nHer actions prompted an emotional rebuke from Attorney-General George Brandis who said Senator Hanson had acted appallingly.\n\nJohn Blaxland from the Australian National University said Senator Hanson's comments were \"toxic\" and counterproductive.\n\nProfessor Blaxland, who wrote a history of domestic spy agency ASIO, said the comments could damage its relationship with the Islamic community.\n\n\"It is so important that people who are wavering, who know something really dodgy, can have confidence they can go to the authorities and be treated with respect,\" he said.\n\n\"It is important [they] know that what they communicate will be treated with confidence and used appropriately.\"\n\nDeradicalisation expert Clarke Jones said Senator Hanson's comments would make Islamic youth feel unwelcome in Australian and could radicalise them.\n\n\"Comments like that, the language she used, stunts like this, is damaging kids' spirits and making them question where they are and if they belong,\" he said.\n\n\"It's a terrible thing and it's got to stop.\"\n\nSenator Hanson defended her actions, saying it was an extreme way of getting her message across to attempt to highlight what she sees as security risks.\n\n\"It is not a religious requirement. This is brought in by men who want to cover up their women. It is oppressing women,\" she said.\n\nBut Coalition frontbencher Simon Birmingham accused Senator Hanson of undermining the work of Australia's law enforcement agencies.\n\n\"It was an appalling stunt. It was an insult to Senate conventions and practice. It was an insult to many thousands of hard-working, law-abiding Australians,\" Senator Birmingham told Lateline.\n\n\"It was something that undermines the hard work of our law enforcement agencies.\"\n\nBoth Dr Clarke and Professor Blaxland praised Senator Brandis' response to Senator Hanson, which drew applause from all sides of politics.\n\n\"To ridicule that community, to drive it into a corner, to mock its religious garments is an appalling thing to do,\" Senator Brandis said.\n\n\"I would ask you to reflect on that.\"\n\nMr Blaxland said Senator Brandis put \"a wet blanket on the flames\".\n\n\"It was pretty damn impressive, actually,\" he said.\n\nASIO and the Australian Federal Police were contacted for comment.", "id": "9759488", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-17", Ms Hanson, who has ferociously campaigned against multiculturalism, took her seat during question time wearing a full burqa ahead of a debate on banning full-face coverings in public.\n\nPoliticians and senators were united in condemning the political stunt as religious mockery.\n\n\"To mock its religious garment is an appalling thing to do and I would ask you to reflect on what you've done,\" Attorney-General George Brandis told Ms Hanson before she removed the burqa and left the chamber with it in hand.\n\nThe former fish and chip shop owner and Dancing with the Stars finalist has become infamous for her political stunts and controversial remarks, some of which critics have labelled racist.\n\nShe first came to prominence after she was disendorsed as a Liberal candidate in 1996 for making racist comments about Aboriginal Australians but secured a victory in the Queensland lower house seat of Oxley anyway because she still appeared on the ballot paper.\n\nIt was during her maiden speech to Parliament in 1996 that she uttered her now infamous words: \"I believe we are in danger of being swamped by Asians\".\n\n\"They have their own culture and religion, form ghettos and do not assimilate,\" Ms Hanson continued.\n\n\"Of course, I will be called racist but, if I can invite whom I want into my home, then I should have the right to have a say in who comes into my country.\n\n\"A truly multicultural country can never be strong or united.\"\n\nMs Hanson later appeared in an interview on 60 Minutes when reporter Tracey Curro asked her if she was xenophobic.\n\n\"Please explain?\" she responded.\n\nThe remark became a popular catchphrase that is still used by Australians today. It was also appropriated by satirical character Pauline Pantsdown, played by Simon Hunt, in the song I Don't Like It, which reached the Australian Top 10 charts.\n\n'IF YOU ARE SEEING ME NOW IT MEANS I'VE BEEN MURDERED'\n\nThe following year, Ms Hanson made a video to be released to the public in the event of her assassination. She feared her stance on immigration put her life in danger after launching a new political party, One Nation, in 1997.\n\n\"Fellow Australians, if you are seeing me now it means that I have been murdered,\" Ms Hanson said staring down the barrel of the camera.\n\n\"Do not let my passing distract you even for a moment. For the sake of our children and our children's children, you must fight on.\"\n\nThe \"voice from the grave'' video came after Prime Minister John Howard had been advised to wear a bulletproof vest as he spoke in rural Victoria because of his tough new gun policy in the wake of the Port Arthur massacre. Ms Hanson's video was subsequently derided as a cheap political stunt.\n\n'THEY'VE GOT AIDS'\n\nMs Hanson described South African migrants to Australia as having AIDS during a statement about returning to politics following a hiatus.\n\n\"We're bringing in people from South Africa at the moment. There's a huge amount coming into Australia, who have diseases; they've got AIDS,\" she said in 2006.\n\n\"They are of no benefit to this country whatsoever; they'll never be able to work. And what my main concern is: is the diseases that they're bringing in and yet no one is saying or doing anything about it.\"\n\n'WE ARE IN DANGER OF BEING SWAMPED BY MUSLIMS'\n\nMs Hanson heralded her political comeback in 2016 by warning Australia was at risk of being \"swamped by Muslims\".\n\nIt was a reference to her maiden speech to Parliament in 1996, in which she made the same claim about Asians.\n\nThe One Nation leader repeated her call for a ban on Muslim immigration and warned Australians would eventually be forced to live under sharia law if something did not change.\n\n\"We are in danger of being swamped by Muslims who bear a culture and ideology that is incompatible with our own,\" she said.\n\n'THERE'S NO DEFINITION OF WHAT AN ABORIGINAL PERSON IS'\n\nMs Hanson again raised eyebrows when she incorrectly declared there was \"no definition to an Aboriginal\".\n\n\"You know, there's no definition to an Aboriginal,\" Ms Hanson said in a 2016 interview on the Bolt Report.\n\n\"If you marry an Aboriginal, you can be classified as an Aboriginal.\n\n\"Or if the community or the elders accept you into that community, you can be defined as an Aboriginal.\n\n\"And that's not good enough, because then if you make a comment about it, well what are you -- are you an Aboriginal, or not an Aboriginal?\"\n\nThe Federal Government defines an Aboriginal person as someone of Aboriginal descent, who identifies as Aboriginal and is accepted as such by the community in which they live.\n\nMs Hanson called for a debate into the definition.\n\nMs Hanson was last year forced to address rumours she was fixated on US President Donald Trump.\n\nThe accusations came after she revealed she had secured tickets to the US President's inauguration and gushed that \"I can see in Donald Trump a lot of me and what I stand for in Australia ... {"timeCrawl": "07:20:00", "uri": "710738197", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T07:20:00Z", "sim": 0.4901960790157318, "source": {"title": "The Telegraph", "uri": "telegraph.co.uk", "id": "220"}, "url": "http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/08/17/uproar-australian-parliament-firebrand-anti-immigrant-mp-pauline/", "eventUri": "eng-3368046", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368046", "body": "Pauline Hanson, the Australian anti-migrant firebrand MP, has been condemned for an \"appalling\" stunt in which she wore a burka in Parliament as part of her push to ban it, prompting a rare standing ovation from MPs in support of a speech denouncing her.\n\nThe controversial MP, who leads the One Nation party, was widely condemned after she attended the Senate chamber in a black Islamic body covering, prompting gasps of shock from fellow MPs.\n\nAs she removed the covering, she said: \"This is not what should belong in this Parliament.\"\n\nShe then asked George Brandis, the attorney-general: \"In light of the national security of this nation will you work to ban the burka in Australia?\"\n\nMr Brandis responded: \"No.\"\n\nDuring an emotional session, Mr Brandis received a standing ovation from the opposition - and applause from his fellow Coalition MPs - after he delivered a stinging rebuke of Ms Hanson.\n\nReferring to calls by police and security agencies to co-operate with the Muslim community, Mr Brandis said: \"To ridicule that community, to drive it into a corner, to mock its religious garments is an appalling thing to do.\"\n\n\"I am not going to pretend to ignore the stunt that you have tried to pull today by arriving in the chamber dressed in a burka when we all know that you are not an adherent of the Islamic faith,\" he said.\n\n\"I would caution and counsel you with respect to be very, very careful of the offence you may do to the religious sensibilities of other Australians.\"\n\nIn an uncharacteristic display of support, Richard Di Natale, the Greens leader, rose to thank Mr Brandis for \"showing leadership ... that is so often lacking in this Parliament\".\n\nSam Dastyari, a Labor MP, said in a tweet that Ms Hanson was a \"disgrace\" and the Senate had become a \"circus\".\n\n\"George Brandis was just brilliant in the chamber,\" he wrote. \"Just brilliant. Strongest I have ever heard him.\"\n\nMs Hanson rose to notoriety during her first term in Parliament in the 1990s after she claimed that the country risked being swamped by Asian migrants. But she has since turned her attention to attacking the nation's Muslims.\n\nFollowing her appearance in a burka, she released a statement saying \"this was a debate that was happening across the world and Australia could not hide from a difficult conversation out of fear of causing offence\".\n\nShe later said she had considered wearing the burka into the chamber for months, saying it was \"really horrible\" and \"uncomfortable\".\n\n\"I just felt cut off from the rest of the world,\" she said.\n\nThe Coalition and opposition have rejected calls for a ban on the burka.", "id": {"timeCrawl": "00:55:00", "uri": "711186737", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T00:00:00Z", "sim": 0.47843137383461, "source": {"title": "The Australian", "uri": "theaustralian.com.au", "id": "292"}, "url": "http://at.theaustralian.com.au/link/ba9ea64494e78c68de2c38c3e97afab3?domain=theaustralian.com.au", "eventUri": "eng-3368046", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368046", "body": "George Brandis, the government minister who famously told us Australians have a right to be bigots, proved yesterday he is anything but.\n\nAt a time when politics has become increasingly confected, Brandis's emotional rebuke of Senator Hanson's burka stunt was a moment of straightforward moral clarity.\n\nThere was no angle, no manoeuvring, no political advantage.\n\nThe sad fact is that had Brandis's speech had been war-gamed in advance by the government's tactics committee, it probably would have been discarded. It has become an article of faith among coalition strategists that One Nation is to be respected and tolerated, irrespective of how offensive its politics becomes.\n\nPerhaps that's why Hanson did it. Like a toddler whose poor behaviour is ignored by its parents, Senator Hanson is forced to engage in ever more outlandish stunts as a means of gaining our attention.\n\nComparisons are already being drawn with Julia Gillard's misogyny speech. These should be ignored. Gillard's speech was in defence of Peter Slipper, the discredited former speaker to whom Gillard's faltering minority government was entirely beholden. It was a cynical exercise in political survival, not a heartfelt expression of principle.\n\nBrandis's speech was directed against a key government ally, someone whom the government must do business with if it's to pass its legislative agenda. It's difficult to see what Brandis or the government had to gain in attacking Hanson.\n\nIn decrying Hanson's mockery of Islam -- for that is what it was -- Brandis drew from the deepest traditions of classical liberalism, for which freedom of religion is a core tenet.\n\nIn this sense he distinguished mainstream political conservatism from the rabble-rousing conservatism of the populist right. For this alone Brandis deserves praise.\n\nThe populist right might make a show of their love of freedom, but when it comes to defending one of its core elements -- freedom of worship -- their conviction always seems to stop shy of the mosque gate. This is no freedom at all.\n\nSenator Hanson's burka stunt was notionally about national security, but this is of course is rubbish. There is no threat to national security that cannot be managed with sensible screening procedures.\n\nFor the populist right the burka is a Trojan horse; a device through which a larger anti-Islamic agenda can be smuggled into public life.\n\nTo its credit, One Nation makes no bones of this. It is upfront about calling for a ban on Muslim migration.\n\nBut others are not quite so honest and it was this anti-Muslim xenophobia that Brandis identified in the Senate yesterday. The truth is Senator Hanson couldn't give a toss about the burka. It's Muslims she's after.\n\n'Pauline Hanson couldn't give a toss about the burka. It was Muslims she was after.'\n\nSome have said Brandis overreacted to Hanson's provocations. But what else was he supposed to do?\n\nBrandis is the head of the government in the senate. Either the government stands for religious tolerance or it does not. It either opposes a ban on the burka or it does not. It either represents the interests of Australia's Muslim community or it does not.\n\nIt is possible to deplore the burka as an instrument of female oppression, as I do, but respect the right of women to wear it.\n\nThis is another thing that separates Burkean conservatives from the populist right -- the latter sees the law as a convenient means of expressing their disapproval while the former sees it as an intrusion into individual liberty whose power must be used sparingly.\n\nBrandis didn't overreact to Hanson's stunt. {"timeCrawl": "00:30:00", "uri": "711180632", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T00:30:00Z", "sim": 0.4666666686534882, "source": {"title": "ABC News", "uri": "abc.net.au", "id": "19269"}, "url": "http://www.abc.net.au/news/2017-08-18/community-reacts-to-hansons-burqa-stunt/8819050", "eventUri": "eng-3368046", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368046", "body": "Senator Pauline Hanson's decision to wear a burka to Question Time has many in the Muslim community shaking their heads.\n\nNail Aykan, the executive director of the Islamic Council of Victoria, said his immediate reaction was disbelief.\n\n\"I was actually in a meeting when a Twitter message appeared on my screen, and I thought, 'Oh my god' and I had to look twice, thinking 'is this real?'\" he said.\n\n\"The quote that you can never underestimate the predictability of stupidity, it came to my mind. But this a new low.\"\n\nIt is a sentiment shared by his close friend Kazim Ates.\n\n\"As far as I'm concerned, she's just made fool of herself. No ... I'm not insulted,\" he said.\n\n\"Australians don't believe that the burka, the wearing of the burka by a handful of women, is jeopardising the security of Australia.\"\n\nWhile Senator Hanson may have wanted all of the attention, for Almir Colan, the most memorable part was the response by Attorney-General George Brandis.\n\nSenator Brandis flatly rejected the One Nation leader's call for the Government to ban the garment and condemned the \"stunt\".\n\n\"I think human raw emotion, Brandis. Somebody is actually expressing what they feel and believe and think about a particular issue. And I think that's what people want.\"\n\nMr Aykan's daughter, Merve Aykan, a teaching student, said she expected such \"nonsense\" from Senator Hanson.\n\n\"My dad told me about it in the car when I was coming back home. I didn't really ask him what really happened, because I was expecting nonsense,\" she said.\n\nHer sister, Nesibe Aykan, said: \"It is something typical from Pauline Hanson.\"\n\nDavid Borger, the Western Sydney director of the Sydney Business Chamber, said Senator Hanson's burka appearance was a \"cheap shot\".\n\n\"I think it's an attempt to drive a wedge between Australians of different groups, different religions and frankly I don't think it plays out very well in places like Western Sydney,\" he said.\n\nVince Movizio from the Fairfield Chamber of Commerce said some would agree with Senator Hanson's stance.\n\n\"Personally I think that's a rude way of doing it,\" he said.\n\n\"But you can understand her point to an extent. The security one, I'm sure many would agree with ... the safety of the nation would have to come first in anyone's mind.\"\n\nOn Friday morning, commuters in Western Sydney had mixed reactions.\n\nStephen Barnes said: \"She was trying to prove a point but that's not the way to do it.\"\n\n\"All she's going to do is just antagonise another sector of the community and we need to build bridges and not antagonise and make things worse,\" he said.\n\nNarelle McCann said she understood the move could upset the Muslim community but added \"something's got to be done\".\n\n\"If we went over there, we would have to wear what they wear, so why can't they wear what we wear?\"\n\nBruce Burke said: \"It was a bit of a stunt but it proved a point.\"\n\n\"She was making a point about security and I've gotta agree with her,\" he said.\n\nHowever, Liam Farquharson said Senator Hanson was \"disrespectful to a whole community\".\n\n\"It is a part of someone's religious belief so we shouldn't go too far to ban the burka,\" he said.\n\n\"That was an aggravating move, it probably upset quite a lot of people because she didn't wear it with respect,\" he said.", "id": "9800318", {"timeCrawl": "07:50:00", "uri": "710749511", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T07:36:00Z", "sim": 0.4627451002597809, "source": {"title": "The Guardian", "uri": "theguardian.com", "id": "260"}, "url": "http://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2017/aug/17/george-brandis-decency-burqa-stunt-senate-pauline-hanson", "eventUri": "eng-3368046", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368046", "body": "The most dispiriting thing about Pauline Hanson's little stunt on Thursday is not that she entered the Senate chamber in a burqa, and then swirled it off like a coy extra in a Star Wars movie, looking to steal some sneaky love from the camera.\n\nOffensive, reckless, dangerous and dumb behaviour from Hanson is, let's be honest, par for the course.\n\nIt's an art form she's slowly perfected during her fits and starts in public life.\n\nBut offensive, reckless, dangerous and dumb is, sadly, not the worst of it.\n\nThe worst of it is Hanson got exactly what she wanted.\n\nOn Thursday Hanson wanted what she always wants: to surf the persistent vacancy and hollowness of the contemporary political discussion, and the febrile 24/7 news cycle, with its voracious appetite for sensation, to project herself, nimbly, to centre stage.\n\nThe objective is to be at once the centre of attention, and to be mocked and shunned and shamed and scapegoated by her parliamentary colleagues.\n\nWith a Queensland state election coming up, presumably it would be helpful to the looming campaign to once again hang a giant lantern over her self-styled outsider status, to be spurned by the political mainstream.\n\nAnyone watching politics this week knows it has been a cluttered, chaotic, high octane week in Canberra, and the competition to grab your little moment in the spotlight in all the swirling insanity has been intense.\n\nIt was clear that Hanson entered the Senate with a simple objective.\n\nShe wanted to use the chamber as a platform to project herself onto the television news bulletins, onto outrage central, 2GB in Sydney - and to amplify her direct communication with voters.\n\nThat's what the alleged outsiders do in modern politics - they occupy the life, accept the benefits, and pretend that they are somehow quantifiably different from the other inhabitants of the circus.\n\nHanson beamed as she was soundly rebuked by a clearly infuriated George Brandis in one of the attorney general's finest parliamentary contributions on the hop.\n\nBetter yet when folks across the chamber leapt to their feet to reward Brandis for his full-throated rebuke with a standing ovation.\n\nHanson's smile widened, the eyes flashed.\n\nBrandis stood up without hesitation or qualification for decency, tolerance, for basic Australian values of respect and inclusion - even if the Coalition colleagues sitting behind him hesitated.\n\nAs well as insisting that Muslim Australians should not suffer the gross indignity of being mocked in their own parliament, Brandis also stood up for practicality and good sense, given terrorism is a real and present threat, and agencies require cooperation from the Islamic community in order to combat it.\n\nCometh the hour, cometh the man.\n\nBut despite the correct thing being done, Hanson's delight at her success brimmed like a fountain.\n\nA perfect bit of mischief, managed.\n\nDepressing doesn't even begin to describe it.", "id": "9635405", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-17", "title": "Brandis stands up for decency after burqa stunt - but that's exactly what {"timeCrawl": "19:53:00", "uri": "711084472", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T12:02:00Z", "sim": 0.43529412150383, "source": {"title": "Financial Review", "uri": "afr.com", "id": "3541"}, "url": "http://www.afr.com/opinion/editorials/pauline-hanson-should-debate-not-denigrate-20170817-gxymbn", "eventUri": "eng-3368046", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368046", "body": "Donald Trump's brazen equivocation on racism was echoed in Pauline Hanson's outrageous stunt in wearing a burqa to Senate question time yesterday.\n\nThe reaction of the political mainstream was correct in both cases. The two living former Republican presidents, George H.W. Bush and George W. Bush, both said there was no place for bigotry in their party. In the Australian Senate, Liberal Attorney-General George Brandis told Hanson that \"to ridicule that [Islamic] community, to drive it into a corner, to mock its religious garments, is an appalling thing to do\".\n\nIn rightly defending free speech, Brandis has supported the \"the right to be a bigot\". Now he has rightly let a bigot know - to a standing ovation - exactly what he thought of her. And so reaffirmed the importance of free speech.\n\nYet it would be a mistake to dismiss the actions of Trump and Hanson as simple cases of deplorable racism, ignorance and prejudice. {"timeCrawl": "10:19:00", "uri": "711380411", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T10:19:00Z", "sim": 0.4313725531101227, "source": {"title": "The Age", "uri": "theage.com.au", "id": "1999"}, "url": "http://www.theage.com.au/comment/the-age-letters/senate-stunt-attention-seeking-antics-a-threat-to-our-safety-20170818-gxzpbr.html", "eventUri": "eng-3368046", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368046", "body": "Disgust is not a strong enough word. Senator Hanson does not speak for me or Australians. The Attorney-General was right to point out that she and her attention-seeking antics are a real threat to our national security.\n\nWilliam Chandler, Surrey Hills\n\nWalk a mile in another's shoes\n\nSo Senator Hanson proves it's safe for a woman to choose to wear a burqa into our Parliament, good for her! Now I would like to see her walk round an area that has a high number of One Nation supporters dressed like that and with no TV or security so she can experience what her followers are like to Muslim Australians.\n\nDoug Steley, Heyfield\n\nResponse was an overreaction\n\nGeorge Brandis' response to Pauline Hanson's Senate stunt was somewhat of an overreaction. Parliament is not the place to take the mickey out of someone's religious clothing, but should we in a liberal society allow for a little mockery to be made about the attire religious people wear on some occasions? One only has to go into a fancy dress shop and you can hire the full range of garments there for a whole variety of faiths.\n\nHenk van Leeuwen, Elwood\n\nAdvertisement Dress based on conviction\n\nFor 45 years I have covered myself in the modest clothing of an Orthodox Jewish woman. I am luckier than Muslim wearers of the burqa, niqab and hijab in that my garments don't single me out for verbal abuse or worse. However, we are united in that our style of dress is based on personal religious conviction, practice of which is permitted and protected in Australia. Pauline Hanson's empty charade is offensive to anyone of either sex who demonstrates faith by their clothing choice.\n\nElizabeth Morris, Elsternwick\n\nYou will now receive updates from Breaking News Alert Breaking News Alert\n\nGet the latest news and updates emailed straight to your inbox.\n\nBy submitting your email you are agreeing to Fairfax Media's terms and conditions and privacy policy .\n\nAdvocate for women's rights\n\nSenator Hanson may have become an accidental advocate for women's rights. Knowingly or not she has spearheaded the issue of women's health, identity and sexuality right into Australia's centre stage. A covered face is an identity stripped away and oppresses self expression. Australia has come so far with the progression of women's rights, the wearing of head and face coverings pulls us back a thousand years. Senator Hanson was unfairly accused of disrespecting a religious minority. Open honest and respectful debate needs to happen now.\n\nSusan Gay, Lake Wendouree\n\nBrandis to be congratulated\n\nGeorge Brandis is to be congratulated for showing leadership against Hanson's offensive stunt. It's unfortunate he and others have not also spoken out against the anti-Muslim \"dog-whistle\" and the government's proposed citizenship changes, both of which are more sophisticated attempts to marginalise Muslims with far more serious consequences.\n\nSusie Latham, Preston\n\nHanson challenges Parliament\n\nI commend Pauline for her burquest stunt. The automatic outrage was predictable. She had challenged the Parliament to think about the problem, and the response was: \"It's too difficult for us. We are only simple parliamentarians.\" And the House returned to its usual shambles.\n\nPaul Drakeford, Kew\n\nShame on Liberals for not standing\n\nCongratulations to the Labor Party and crossbench senators for endorsing Attorney-General Brandis, by giving him a standing ovation. Shame no Liberal stood, and very few managed to clap. Could it be they don't want to lose Pauline Hanson's vote?\n\nRon Reynolds, Templestowe\n\nTHE FORUM Glimmer of hope\n\nIn the same week I have found myself supporting an opinion piece by Amanda Vanstone and a speech by George Brandis. I'm not sure which parallel universe I have entered but it appears there is at least a glimmer of hope in this one.\n\nSteve Roddis, Ringwood East\n\nClash of symbols\n\nHow is our national celebration of Australia Day different from the statues in the US celebrating the institution of slavery? Both are deeply hurtful to the people who are targeted; both prolong that hurt by continually flaunting it before them. It's time to quietly abandon such outdated, insensitive and divisive symbols. When we become a republic in our own right (hopefully before our head of state is King Charles - out-dated, un-Australian symbols, indeed), we can have an Australia Day that includes every Australian citizen.\n\nRose Marie Crowe, Ormond\n\nWe know better\n\nSuch was our collective blindness to Aboriginal culture and history, our ignorance or denial of the facts about our dispossession and oppression of them, and our apparent lack of concern for their feelings, our leaders probably did not consider their perspective when they chose the national day.\n\nBut we know better now.\n\nThe recent Uluru Statement by Indigenous leaders is one of the most inspiring yet tragically honest self-assessments of their plight and the hope they hold for constitutional recognition or treaty to improve their position. If, as a result of our listening, one outcome is to change the date of our national celebration, it should cause no great offence to us as the majority. It may give comfort to these brothers and sisters who are offended by the celebration of January 26, 1788.\n\nPat Love, Newport\n\nDivisive day\n\nNo, Mr Turnbull, January 26 does not unite us. It divides us. It commemorates the day Europeans took the land of Indigenous Australians without even recognising their existence. And they are expected to celebrate this? In years to come, when we have changed the date, we will ask: How could we have been so insensitive?\n\nRobert Salter, Clifton Hill\n\nLaw without force\n\nMandatory reporting of confessions to priests of child sexual abuse might seem a way of stopping this repugnant and damaging crime and changing the misuse of a ritual which allows paedophiles to feel better about their actions. But, sadly, such a law may be unenforceable, will almost certainly be self-defeating, and it would create an undesirable legal precedent to which no one seems to have given thought.\n\nIf a priest did not accept the state's authority in the matter, how would you know he had heard something? And what is to prevent abusers from confessor-shopping? Or finding a darker confessional, not in their parish?\n\nEven if priests were universally co-operative, what paedophile would confess where exposure was a certainty?\n\nA legal rubicon will be crossed if the mandate is legislated: the government will be making a law regarding the conduct of religion, something I don't think has been done before in Australia. We lack a bill of rights guaranteeing, among other things, freedom of religion, even if it is to have none. And how to justify mandating only with child abuse?\n\nLet's hope this is just a signal from the royal commission for the church hierarchy to toughen up and change the ritual to \"absolution only after submission to a supervised program of atonement and restitution\" for child abusers.\n\nBrian McGuire, Glen Waverley\n\nEnergy profiteers\n\nThe energy retail sector review ('State paying far too much for its power', The Age, 14/8) is the first high-level bipartisan acknowledgment of full retail competition being bad public policy, wrongly adopted and retained by successive Victorian governments. Energy Minister Lily D'Ambrosio's initial response \"there's something wrong with our system\" misses the mark. The energy retail system was designed and belongs to the privatised energy industry: it's their system, not ours. It was built fit for their purpose, to maximise profits. It needs replacing with a system designed to deliver affordable, accessible, safe, secure, quality energy supplies operated in the public interest.\n\nCheryl Wragg, Moe\n\nWrong lovesong\n\nKevin Donnelly ('This is why I'll be saying 'no', The Age, 18/8) in arguing for the centrality of heterosexual marriage to family and culture quotes T.S. Eliot, who is a strange choice. Eliot never once visited his first wife when she was hospitalised for years; he conducted two long-term affairs, declining to marry the women, then married his 30-year-old editor when he was 70, writing smutty poems about the advantages of being a short man to his tall wife. He had no children - all in all, T. S. Eliot was hardly a poster boy for family.\n\nMary Cahill, Brunswick\n\nIt won't go away\n\nEven if the non-binding opinion poll of some Australians results in a \"no\" vote, which leads to not having a conscience vote by our elected representatives in Canberra, does anybody really think that this issue will just go away?\n\nEldert De Graaf, Wheelers Hill\n\nMuddled thinking\n\nIt is truly astonishing that Kevin Donnelly still thinks being gay is a life \"choice\". To support this he cites census figures suggesting that about 2 per cent of the population are gay. This is very questionable evidence indeed, but even if accurate it means that hundreds of million people globally are homosexual: clearly it is natural and as such not a choice.\n\nDonnelly makes much of the fact that gay couples can't have children. We all know this, but we shouldn't worry: the human race is not presently in danger of extinction and if it is it won't be because of gay marriage. Donnelly stresses the \"special union of body and soul\" that is marriage. But every time the beauty of marriage is advanced in support of its traditional form, one has to wonder why this gift should be denied gay people.\n\nFinally on whose authority should the \"unique ritual\" and \"sacred compact\" that is marriage be confined to one section of the population, even if it is the majority? Is the spontaneous expression and ritual consecration of love to be circumscribed by arbitrary rule and custom?\n\nMichael Read, Ashburton\n\nChanging city\n\nRather than being purely profit driven, good governance must attain an appropriate balance between competing interests and outcomes.\n\nHowever, as a result of foreign developers and purchasers buying as much as 40 per cent of all new apartments in Melbourne as reported in The Age (15/8), we are undergoing an unprecedented population boom that is having a severe impact on the city's infrastructure, housing affordability and unique character. The \"canyons\" of large towers are obliterating the marvellous qualities experienced in the city until recent times, not the least being a diverse variety heritage precincts, a greater degree of human-scale and pedestrian comfort, and more interesting building form to complement the open spaces and celebrated laneway culture.\n\nGary Bateman, North Melbourne\n\nNot about safety\n\nI just don't accept the excuse of Alyssa's special school in St Albans ('Locked gate keeps family apart', The Age, 18/8) that it's about children's safety. Its response ranges from a lack of imagination to outright ignorance and obstruction.\n\nJanny Ryan, Carlton\n\nLook into banks\n\nIs the government so flush with funds that it can have a postal survey on same-sex marriage costing $120 million when it's not compulsory, not binding and still needs to go back to Parliament for a vote? Wouldn't it be more productive spending the money on a royal commission into the banking industry?\n\nGiuseppe Corda, Aspendale\n\nWhere's the train?\n\nSo the paddocks of Truganina are to be transformed into the \"Glen Waverley of Melbourne's west\", but without the guarantee of a railway station when the residents move in. ('The new view from the fringe', The Age, 16/8) Perhaps if less infrastructure money from the state's coffers had been spent removing level crossings that aren't really dangerous or congested, a station could be provided.\n\nRoss Bardin, Williamstown\n\nAND ANOTHER THING Pauline Hanson\n\nPauline; it is so easy to propagate hate and fear; you will always have a following.\n\nGary Bryfman, Brighton\n\nBan the burqua-wearing senator.\n\nGreg Bradshaw, Dandenong North\n\nWell done Pauline. You've actually proven that wearing a burqua poses no undue threat.\n\nSteve Melzer, Hughesdale\n\nAmazing how much Pauline Hanson revealed about herself while covered in a burqa.\n\nLawrence Habegger, Ballarat\n\nPauline by name, appauline by nature.\n\nNick Neary, Armadale\n\nIt is obvious Pauline Hanson's chosen method of dress had prevented her from seeing how far she had overstepped the mark.\n\nBarbara Abell, Ringwood North\n\nFirst Amanda Vanstone (Monday), then George Brandis (Thursday): this Greens voter starts to like the Liberals.\n\nEd Castenmiller, Airport West\n\nSenator Brandis once said \"people have a right to be bigoted\". Or has Hanson's bigotry gone too far George?\n\nIan Dale, Rosebud\n\nOther matters\n\nGerard Ridsdale would have to live longer than Methuselah in order to serve enough jail time for his abhorrent heinous crimes.\n\nMartin de Boerr, Coburg\n\nA former Tattersalls boss chairing an AFL working party on pokies? Talk about putting Dracula in charge of the blood bank.\n\nLindsay Zoch, East Melbourne\n\nAustralia became a nation on May 27, 1967. Those who see in Senator Hanson someone willing to speak their minds, and voice their fears, congratulated her. These supporters won't be found in most newsrooms, boardrooms, corporate offices, political party rooms or other spaces of power in Australia. There are probably few in Canberra, insulated as it can be from regional grievances.\n\nHer stunt resonated with her base, impatient with financial and cultural elites that Hanson supporters believe have tilted the odds against them and robbed them of control over their destiny. This is only more troubling because so few of Senator Hanson's critics are likely to know just where her theatrics were welcomed, and why. Most of the nation is talking across One Nation's supporters. On their part, Hansonites despise what they see as the arrogance and naivety of opponents who shout down their racist slurs, a response they see as the muzzle of \"political correctness\".\n\nIn the crossfire of this battle are Muslims living in Australia. There can be no mistake: the onslaught of grubby tabloid smears, misinformed public attacks and unwarranted hostility not only besiege and marginalise Muslims in this country. They also do nothing to make Australia safer; in fact, they do the opposite. ASIO head Duncan Lewis has made clear how pivotal his agency's relationship with Muslim communities is to protect national security. To use words from Liberal senator George Brandis' commendable speech on Thursday, driving Muslims into a corner will only damage the country's counterterrorism efforts.\n\nAside from its obvious offensiveness, Senator Hanson's burqa stunt and the case she made against Islam afterwards were riddled with nonsense and irrationality. First, most victims of terrorism are actually Muslims. The so-called Islamic State has made massacres against Shi'ite Muslims a priority, and the Global Terrorism Index ranks Iraq as the country worst-affected by terror, followed by Afghanistan, Nigeria, Pakistan and Syria. All are Muslim-majority countries.\n\nSecond, Islam does not make its followers more likely to be fundamentalists, just as being white is not in itself the cause of neo-Nazism and ethnic supremacism. Extremism is caused by other forces, largely economic and political. Both these points bear repeating every time Senator Hanson attacks Muslims.\n\nHer power lies in that base she performed her stunt for. Unless she implodes - which is not unlikely - those voters will keep listening to her. How the rest of Australia handles that is another question, but it could start by doing what it can to show that Senator Hanson's actions are nothing about Australia's security or the harmony of its communities. {"timeCrawl": "08:21:00", "uri": "710762943", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T08:21:00Z", "sim": 0.4156862795352936, "source": {"title": "Brisbane Times", "uri": "brisbanetimes.com.au", "id": "1278"}, "url": "http://www.brisbanetimes.com.au/comment/pauline-hanson-the-insult-that-shocked-a-nation-20170817-gxym94.html", "eventUri": "eng-3368046", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368046", "body": "When Pauline Hanson appeared, burqa-clad in Parliament on Thursday, it was Liberal senator Jonathon Duniam's gasp of \"what the hell?\" that echoed throughout media reports, tweets and around water coolers across the nation. He said what all of us were feeling.\n\nBut as attention-grabbing as her stunt may have been, there was nothing particularly original about Hanson's little game of dress-ups: even her attempt at mockery is plagiarised. Burqas have been a favourite costume at far-right rallies throughout the world for years. If Hanson continues to go down this path, we can expect she and her fellow One Nation senators to stage ISIS-style \"mock\" executions in the Parliament House forecourt by this time next week.\n\nAs always, Muslim women feel obligated to respond to these insults by explaining (again) why we do not represent a threat to the safety of the Australian public - while noting the infinitely small proportion of Muslim women who actually cover their faces in Australia.\n\nAnyone who doesn't know this by now has made a deliberate choice not to listen.\n\nThis is all so very, very familiar that it's difficult to generate any shock value. Why, then, has Hanson's little routine made such an impact?\n\nThe shock is not that she mocked Australia's Muslim community. That's absolutely routine. It's difficult to imagine that George \"people have the right to be bigots\" Brandis would have been moved to tears over the offence caused to the Muslim women of Australia.\n\nNo - the shock is that Hanson mocked the national Parliament by using it as a stage for her own alt-right pantomime.\n\nMuslim women are more than used to mockery, to being made the national punching bag at regular intervals. We are not the ones in shock now.\n\nDr Shakira Hussein is a writer and researcher at the National Centre for Excellence in Islamic Studies, University of Melbourne. I was definitely in solidarity with someone coming in, in what they're entitled to wear and when you see them being pursued by security guards.\n\n\"It's a bit weird. I am totally weirded out by it.\"\n\nMs Hanson claimed she wore the Islamic garment in the chamber to highlight what she said were the security issues it posed, linking it to terrorism as fellow senators heckled her.\n\n\"Is it extreme? Yes. Is it getting my message across? I hope so,\" she said.\n\nThe stunt has been heavily criticised, with Independent senator Derryn Hinch labelling Ms Hanson's conduct \"disgusting\".\n\nAnti-immigrant group confuses bus seats for women wearing burkas\n\nHate to think how many future Jihadi's Pauline Hanson has single handedly recruited for ISIS today.
